a L_Non-punitive L_Paradigm of L_Probation L_Practice : Some L_Sobering Thoughts L.R. L_SINGER
L_Lawrence L_Singer is an L_Assistant L_Chief L_Probation L_Officer with L_Merseyside L_Probation L_Service .

L_Beforehand he L_worked as a L_probation L_officer for L_Berkshire L_Probation L_Service and L_later as a L_research L_officer for L_Somerset L_Probation L_Service where he L_undertook the L_research L_reported here .

The L_paradigm which is L_described M_originates from L_doctoral L_research into L_generic L_probation L_practice and has been M_presented in a L_book L_Adult L_Probation and L_Juvenile L_Supervision : M_Beyond the L_Care-Control L_Dilemma ( 1989 , L_Gower ) .
L_SUMMARY
The L_Government L_White L_Paper L_Crime , L_Justice and L_Protecting the L_Public M_proposes a L_radical L_change for L_probation L_practice .
L_Henceforth L_probation L_work will no L_longer be an L_alternative to L_punishment but an L_alternative M_form of L_punishment .
This L_article M_challenges the L_conceptual and L_practical L_appropriateness of M_applying the L_notion of L_punishment to the L_probation M_context .
L_Probation L_officers , it is L_argued , are L_concerned with L_establishing M_rules for L_probationers and not L_inflicting M_pain on them .
An L_alternative L_non-punitive L_paradigm of L_probation L_practice is L_described .

The L_paradigm is M_based on the L_joint L_supervisory M_aims of M_support and L_surveillance which are L_implemented through the L_methods of L_counselling , L_assisting , L_directing , and L_monitoring .
To M_illustrate the L_paradigm , L_reference is M_made to an L_alcohol L_education M_course L_developed for L_offenders in L_trouble through L_drink .
The L_efficacy of the L_alcohol L_project and the L_non-punitive L_paradigm is L_demonstrated by the L_results L_reported from a three L_year L_evaluation L_study M_covering 152 L_offenders .

The L_article M_concludes with an L_affirmation of the L_disciplined but L_non-punitive M_character of L_current L_probation L_work and M_argues that , to L_successfully L_protect the L_public and L_reintegrate L_offenders into the L_community , the L_probation L_officer 's L_employment of L_established L_social L_work L_knowledge , L_skills , and L_values is a M_strength not a M_weakness .

The M_aim of this L_article is to M_challenge the L_assertion M_contained in the L_White L_Paper L_Crime , L_Justice and L_Protecting the L_Public ( L_Home L_Office , 1990a ) that L_probation L_practice can be M_conceived of as a M_form of L_punishment in the L_community .

L_Issue will be M_taken with the L_appropriateness of M_applying the L_concept of L_punishment to the L_probation M_context through L_reference to a M_demanding and M_successful L_probation L_project M_concerned with L_offenders in L_trouble through L_drink .
In L_describing the L_project , a L_non-punitive M_model for L_understanding L_probation L_practice will be L_developed .

This L_non-punitive L_paradigm will M_provide a M_framework for L_contrasting the L_efficacy of L_current L_practice with L_future M_plans L_inappropriately to M_transform L_probation L_work into ‘ a L_new M_approach to L_punishment in the L_community ’ ( p. 18 , para. 4.3 ) .

The L_punitive M_approach L_anticipated for the L_Probation L_Service in the L_White L_Paper is M_underpinned by a L_definition of L_punishment that M_resides ‘ in the L_restrictions on L_liberty and in the L_enforcement of the M_orders ’ .

The L_White L_Paper M_goes on to M_emphasize : ‘ It is the M_loss of L_liberty L_involved in L_carrying out the M_terms of the M_order L_rather than the L_activities L_carried out during the M_order which is the L_punishment ’ ( p. 18 , para. 4.4 ) .

Notwithstanding the L_popular L_appeal and L_political M_capital to be L_derived from such a humane-sounding L_statement , this L_definition is L_nevertheless at L_variance with the L_traditional L_understanding of the L_meaning of L_punishment .

L_Discourses on L_punishment and L_dictionary L_definitions of the M_term M_clearly L_specify the M_central M_feature of L_punishment as being the L_infliction of M_pain L_rather than the M_loss of L_liberty per se ( L_Hudson , 1987 ) .
The L_conceptual and L_practical L_implications of this L_discrepancy will be L_examined in the L_third and L_final M_section of this L_article .
L_Beforehand , L_however , L_consideration will be M_given L_first to the L_probation L_project and L_second to its L_evaluation .

In these M_sections L_punishment will be L_understood to L_mean the L_infliction of M_pain and the L_review of the L_project will M_seek to L_demonstrate that the L_probation L_practice L_described is not only more M_demanding but L_also more L_effective than this L_traditional L_understanding of L_punishment .

At a L_time when the M_Home L_Secretary is M_inviting the L_Probation L_Service to ‘ M_move M_centre M_stage in the L_Criminal L_Justice M_System ’ ( L_NACRO , 1990 , p. 17 ) it may L_seem L_misguided and L_unnecessarily L_pedantic to M_take L_issue with the L_White L_Paper 's L_notion of L_punishment .

L_Punishment is just a L_word after all : L_nothing more than L_convenient L_political L_rhetoric L_meriting only M_lip-service from L_probation L_managers and L_practitioners L_poised at the ‘ M_window of L_opportunity ’ .
L_However , this L_fails to L_acknowledge a L_fundamental L_axiom of L_social L_work L_practice ; L_namely that L_language not only M_reflects but L_also M_shapes L_social L_reality .
As L_Davies ( 1981 ) has M_pointed out , L_speech is the L_basic M_tool of the L_social L_worker .
What we L_say L_influences what we L_think and in M_turn , what we do .
If L_punishment is M_assimilated into the L_probation L_glossary it will L_inevitably L_influence the L_sort of L_practice the L_Service M_undertakes .

In the M_sections to M_follow the M_stark L_question is L_therefore M_put ‘ Is the L_Probation L_Service in the L_business of L_inflicting M_pain ? ’ and the L_answer which M_unfolds may be L_summarized ‘ No , because it L_neither M_aspires nor M_wishes to ! ’
THE L_PROJECT : MORE M_DEMANDING THAN L_PUNISHMENT
L_Government L_concern about the L_problem of L_drink-related L_offending is as L_old as the L_Probation L_Service .

L_Indeed , as L_Bochel ( 1976 ) has M_shown , the L_establishment of a L_Probation L_Service in L_England and L_Wales was L_inextricably M_linked with L_work L_undertaken with L_offenders in L_trouble through L_drink .

L_Almost a L_century L_later the L_new M_approach to L_punishment in the L_community M_outlined by the L_White L_Paper once again M_presents L_alcohol L_misuse as a L_key L_problem L_requiring L_community-based L_intervention .

‘ L_Alcohol ’ , the L_White L_Paper M_states , ‘ is L_implicated in a M_wide L_variety of L_crimes , L_drunken L_driving , L_offences of L_public L_disorder and L_domestic L_violence ’ ( p. 21 , para. 4. 14 ) .
In M_describing its M_vision of L_effective L_supervision the L_White L_Paper M_goes on to M_note :
L_offenders M_take M_part in L_alcohol L_education L_programmes so that they can L_learn to L_drink L_sensibly .

They L_learn about the L_relative M_strength of L_different L_drinks , the L_amount which is L_safe to L_consume , and the L_pitfalls to L_avoid ( e.g. L_competitive L_drinking and L_buying ‘ M_rounds ’ ) ( p. 37 , para. 7.11 ) .
As a L_summary of L_alcohol L_education L_programmes , this is L_something of a L_simplification .
L_However it does M_provide a L_useful M_introduction to the L_origins of the L_Alcohol L_Education M_Course L_reported here .

L_Furthermore , it M_highlights the L_suitability of L_referring to this L_type of L_project for M_testing out the L_appropriateness of M_applying the L_notion of L_punishment to L_probation L_practice .

In 1985 the L_management of L_Somerset L_Probation L_Service was M_faced with the L_fact that L_nearly one in three of the L_offenders L_supervised in their L_area were L_either L_known to be or L_suspected of L_misusing L_alcohol ( L_Singer , 1985 ) .

L_Aware of L_practitioners ' L_frustration in not being L_able to L_work L_effectively with these L_problematic L_clients , L_Probation M_management , in L_partnership with the L_voluntary M_sector , L_determined to L_develop an L_Alcohol L_Education M_Course ( L_AEC ) .

By 1986 , when L_social L_inquiry L_report L_monitoring L_information M_covering 1,257 L_offenders L_indicated that the L_problem of L_drink-related L_offending was L_virtually as L_great for L_pre- as for L_post-sentence L_clients , that is , L_alcohol was L_cited as a L_pre-offence L_problem in L_twenty-nine per L_cent of L_cases , a L_specialist L_project L_worker had been L_appointed .
Towards the M_end of 1986 an L_AEC was M_launched and has been M_running L_ever since .
The M_aim of the M_course is to L_educate L_offenders about L_alcohol to L_facilitate a L_lasting L_change in their L_subsequent L_use of this L_drug .

This M_aim is M_underpinned by three L_interrelated L_objectives and it is not without M_significance how they L_complement and M_serve to L_implement the L_White L_Paper 's own L_trinity of ‘ M_aims of L_supervision ’ , that is , L_protection of the L_public , L_prevention of L_reoffending and L_successful L_reintegration of the L_offender in the L_community ( p. 35 , para. 7.3 ) .
These were :
To M_increase L_knowledge about L_alcohol so that L_future L_alcohol L_use can be more L_informed and L_therefore more L_prudent .
To L_instil or M_reinforce L_responsible L_drinking M_attitudes and L_behaviour .
To M_encourage the M_maintenance of , or , where L_appropriate , a L_reduction to a L_personally and L_socially L_safe L_level of L_alcohol L_unit L_intake .

To M_meet these L_objectives the L_AEC has a L_structured L_programme L_involving L_group and L_individual M_contact , that is , six L_group L_sessions M_sandwiched between L_one-to-one L_interviews M_held L_immediately before and after the L_group .
The L_initial L_one-to-one L_meeting , M_held with one of the two L_group L_leaders , M_serves to L_clarify what L_participants can L_expect from the M_course and what is L_expected of them .
A M_standard L_contract which M_covers L_conditions of L_attendance and an L_agreement to L_complete L_various L_assignments between L_group L_sessions is L_signed by each L_participant .

The L_final L_interview M_entails a L_personalized L_review of the M_course , as L_well as the M_formulation of a L_follow-up M_plan to be L_undertaken with the L_offender 's L_supervising L_officer .

The M_course M_employs a L_variety of M_materials and L_techniques M_including the L_use of L_checklists , L_magazine and L_newspaper L_clippings , L_quizzes , L_videos , L_brainstorm M_exercises , L_discussions , L_drink L_diaries , and L_role L_plays ( L_Menary , 1986 ) .

The L_AEC is L_primarily L_intended for L_young L_adults L_subject to a L_probation M_order with a L_special L_condition of L_attendance ( L_Schedule 11 4A(II) L_Criminal L_Justice L_Act 1982 ) and M_reflects the L_fact that most L_Somerset L_offenders in L_trouble through L_drink M_commit M_serious L_offences and/or L_possess a M_substantial L_number of L_previous L_convictions .
In L_short , they are L_seriously at L_risk of M_committing further L_offences and L_becoming L_trapped in the M_revolving M_door of L_custody .
The L_development of the L_Somerset L_AEC both L_accords with and L_constitutes a L_practical L_example of the L_Home L_Office 's L_recent L_guidance to L_sentencers :
In L_recent L_years the L_probation L_service has L_devoted L_increasing M_resources to M_supervising the more M_serious and L_persistent L_offenders .

L_Probation M_orders which are M_combined with M_constructive , L_disciplined and L_effective L_programmes of L_supervision are L_increasingly being L_used for L_offenders who M_stand to L_receive L_custodial L_sentences ( 1990b , p. 35 ) .
From the M_description of the L_AEC L_already M_given the M_demanding and L_disciplined M_nature of the M_course can be L_appreciated .
L_However , the M_course is not L_punitive ; it is not M_concerned with the L_infliction of M_pain .
L_Instead , it is M_concerned with the L_establishment of M_rules .
This is M_plainly L_evident from the M_section of the L_contract L_signed by each L_participant where what is L_expected of them is M_spelt out :

You will be L_expected to L_keep a L_drink L_diary throughout the M_course , and M_make L_attempts at L_reducing the L_amount you L_drink if it is L_greater than L_accepted L_healthy L_drinking L_levels .
You must be L_willing to be L_helped and L_help L_others — your L_experiences will be L_useful to other L_group M_members .
You must L_attend 8 L_sessions ( these will L_consist of : an L_introductory L_session , six L_group L_sessions and a L_final L_assessment L_interview ) .
You must not L_drink before the L_session .
You must be on L_time — L_lateness will M_count as an L_absence .
Unlike the L_prison L_inmate , L_AEC L_participants can not M_sit M_back and L_passively do their L_time .
L_Probation L_practice is not , L_however , L_solely M_concerned with the L_establishment of M_rules .

As has been L_demonstrated L_elsewhere with L_regard to the L_generic L_probation M_setting ( L_Singer , 1989 ) , the L_supervision of L_offenders L_involves two L_overarching M_aims : L_namely M_support and L_surveillance .

M_Support L_refers to L_anything which is L_said or done to L_help the L_offender L_solve or L_mitigate their L_personal or L_social L_problems : L_surveillance to L_anything which is L_said or done to L_induce the L_offender to L_conform to L_socially L_acceptable M_standards of L_behaviour .
These M_aims are L_implemented through the L_practice of four L_distinguishable but L_related L_methods .
In L_terms of M_support , there is L_counselling and L_assisting : in L_terms of L_surveillance , there is L_directing and L_monitoring .
Each of these four L_methods are M_employed during the eight L_sessions .

Although L_summarized as an L_alcohol L_education M_course , the L_sessions are not just M_concerned with M_giving L_information but L_also with L_enabling L_participants to M_make L_practical L_use of it .

In the L_first L_group L_session the L_counselling L_method is L_registered in the M_course L_tutor 's L_notes ( L_Menary , 1986 ) by the L_explanation : ‘ This L_session M_aims to M_get L_participants to L_consider the M_subject of L_alcohol in M_ways they had not L_thought of in the L_past ’ ( p. 3 ) .
During this L_session the L_importance of L_monitoring is L_also M_emphasized :

L_Drinks M_exercises M_introduce the L_notion of L_measurement , L_concentration of L_alcohol L_content ; L_information which will be L_necessary to L_carry out the L_recording of L_alcohol L_consumption throughout the L_duration of the M_course ( p. 3 ) .
In the L_fifth L_group L_session L_entitled ‘ M_Focus on the L_Individual ’ , the L_counselling and the L_monitoring L_combine with the L_directing and L_assisting L_methods .
At the L_start of the L_session the L_tutor 's L_notes M_make M_clear that M_directing M_extends beyond L_enforcing the L_conditions of L_attendance :
This L_session M_allows for an in L_depth L_examination of the L_drinking L_diaries over the L_last five L_weeks — L_identifying the L_risky L_circumstances or M_situations … .
The M_aim at the M_end of the L_session is to L_encourage L_participants to M_make L_rules for their L_future L_drinking which will M_lead to a L_lessening of L_identified L_problems ( p. 4 ) .
L_Similarly , the L_assisting M_extends beyond L_simply L_providing L_handouts of L_useful L_information :
It is L_important that L_participants are L_provided with the L_skills to M_reduce their L_drinking L_levels or M_handle more L_effectively ‘ L_pub L_centred ’ L_problems .

The L_use of L_role L_play , L_incorporating L_previously L_discussed L_difficulties ( i.e. L_homework L_assignment L_session 4 ) in ‘ L_real ’ or M_set up M_situations L_provides an L_opportunity for L_testing these L_skills .

L_Probably the L_best M_illustration of the L_assisting L_method in L_action during the M_course M_comes in the L_fifth L_session when L_Somerset L_practitioners M_take the L_logic of L_working with the L_problem in the L_community to its L_ultimate L_conclusion .

In the L_second M_half of the L_session , M_course L_leaders L_sponsor L_participants to an L_evening at the L_pub for the L_purpose of L_practising L_drinking L_skills and L_purchasing L_non-alcoholic L_drinks .

The L_counselling , L_assisting , L_directing , and L_monitoring on the L_AEC M_give M_substance to the M_aims of M_support and L_surveillance and L_provide the L_basis for L_establishing a M_model of L_probation L_practice .
L_Punishment has no M_place in this M_model .
L_Instead the L_AEC can L_best be L_understood as an L_example of a L_non-punitive L_paradigm of L_probation L_practice .

Twenty L_years ago the L_Advisory L_Council on the L_Penal M_System M_observed that L_notions of L_punitiveness do not L_accord with ‘ the L_British L_concept of L_probation as an L_alternative to , L_rather than a M_suspension of , L_punishment ’ ( L_quoted in L_Bochel , 1976 , p. 238 ) .
Twenty L_years L_later the L_AEC M_demonstrates that this L_remains no L_less L_true now than it was then .
But does the L_AEC M_work ?
M_BRINGING L_FOSSILS M_BACK TO M_LIFE

In this L_chapter some of the M_ways in which L_palaeontologists L_determine the M_way L_fossil L_animals L_lived are L_described , M_reanimating the L_dead L_fragments to M_build up a M_living M_creature .

Since L_popular L_ideas of L_life in the L_past are L_often M_founded on M_vividly M_coloured M_reconstructions of ‘ The L_World in the L_Jurassic L_Period ’ and the L_like , it is L_important to L_remember that these L_imaginative M_scenes are all L_inferences from L_bones , and L_similar L_fragments .

In L_fact there is L_nothing M_fixed about such L_interpretations , because the M_way the L_fossils are L_understood may M_change over the L_years , but it is L_usually some L_time before L_new L_discoveries M_percolate into the L_popular L_presentations .
L_Even the most L_solid-looking L_dinosaurs may have M_changed their M_habits in the L_last few L_years !
L_Many L_different M_lines of L_evidence may be L_used to L_flesh out the L_bare L_bones of the L_fossils .
The L_first of these is the L_evidence of the L_rocks from which the L_remains were L_recovered .
The L_sediments themselves M_reveal L_much about the L_environment of L_deposition , as was M_shown in L_Chapter 3 .

It is L_important to L_establish whether the L_fossil L_animal L_actually L_lived in the L_environment which M_furnished its L_sedimentary L_cover , or whether its L_remains were M_swept in from some other L_place .
L_Fortunately it is L_usually L_easy to L_spot such M_intruders .

The L_type of L_sediment and the L_associated L_fossils will M_show whether the L_environment was L_marine , L_freshwater or L_terrestrial , L_providing the L_basic L_information into which the L_ecology of the L_animal has to be M_accommodated .
The L_sediments themselves may have M_preserved some of the L_tracks L_left by the L_animal ( p. 20 ) to M_give M_direct L_evidence of its L_past M_activities .
From the L_tracks L_alone it is L_possible to be L_certain of the L_bipedal M_stance of L_certain L_dinosaurs , and to L_measure their M_stride .

The M_character of the L_rocks , and their L_setting in the L_past L_geography at the L_time when they L_accumulated , M_diagnoses the L_climatic L_setting in which the L_extinct L_fauna L_lived , and L_climate M_imposes L_certain M_restraints on L_possible L_modes of L_life .
L_Savannah L_animals L_differ from those of L_tropical L_rain L_forests , and these again from M_inhabitants of the L_tundra at M_high L_latitudes .
L_Looking at the L_fossil L_animal itself , the L_first L_necessity is to L_reconstruct it as L_accurately as L_possible from its L_fragmentary L_remains .
L_Sometimes this is a very L_complex L_business , L_particularly for L_vertebrates with L_numbers of L_small L_bones .
To M_proceed from the M_reconstruction to an M_assessment of L_probable L_life M_habits two L_different but L_complementary M_approaches are L_used .
One L_method M_attempts to L_compare the L_structures of L_teeth or L_limbs or some other L_feature of the L_extinct L_animal with L_living L_analogues .
These do not have to be L_biologically M_related L_organisms .
The L_basic L_argument is that L_structures that are M_closely L_similar were L_probably L_adapted to a L_similar L_function .

L_Sometimes these L_similarities are L_quite L_obvious : the M_ferocious L_teeth of a L_predatory L_dinosaur are a L_sure L_indication of L_hunting M_habits , with L_hardly a L_glance at the L_fangs of L_living L_mammalian L_carnivores .

But the L_structure and L_functioning of L_grinding or L_chewing L_teeth in other L_mammals , in which M_opposing L_teeth M_co-operate in L_action , and which can be L_matched in L_extinct , M_unrelated L_mammals , is a L_much more L_subtle L_matter , L_involving L_detailed L_studies on the L_operation of L_living L_dental L_systems to L_help L_elucidate the L_functioning of L_fossil L_ones .

The L_technique of ‘ M_hunt the L_analogue ’ is a L_favourite one L_practised by L_palaeontologists , but it is L_certainly not a L_foolproof one , because there are L_many L_fossil L_animals that M_defy L_comparison with L_living L_organisms , and some L_analogues do not M_stand up to L_detailed L_scrutiny .
The L_second L_method M_tries to L_analyse the L_structure of the L_fossil L_almost as if it were a M_piece of M_engineering .
If the L_fossil is L_constructed in a L_certain M_way , then there are only a L_limited L_number of ‘ M_jobs ’ that the L_structure could M_perform .
The L_idea here is to L_decide which of the L_possibilities is the most L_likely one .
This M_assumes that L_nature only M_manufactures L_efficient M_designs .
For the most L_part this is a L_reasonable L_assumption to M_make .

Most L_animals M_today do L_seem to have L_bodies that M_accord L_well with the L_functions they have to L_carry out to L_survive : M_flyers are L_aerodynamically L_efficient , L_active M_swimmers have L_suitable L_streamlining , L_herbivorous L_mammals have L_teeth L_appropriate for L_grinding L_plant L_food , and so on .

L_Ideally one could L_construct a L_model of the L_fossil to L_test out these L_various L_functions in L_experiments , but the L_number of L_examples where the L_analysis has been M_pursued this M_far are L_limited .

Of L_course it can L_never be L_known whether the L_right M_answer has been M_reached ( unless L_somebody L_dredges up a ‘ L_living L_fossil ’ from the L_depths of the L_ocean ) — there are only L_varying L_degrees of L_probability .

But the L_best M_answers are L_probably M_obtained where the L_functional M_design of the L_fossil M_points to the same L_life M_habits as a L_living L_analogue , and where both are M_consistent with the L_geological L_circumstances in which the L_fossil L_remains L_occur .
L_SWIMMING L_TRILOBITES
There are L_thousands of L_different L_kinds of L_trilobites .
All of them were L_marine and all of them are L_extinct .

Since L_many L_kinds of L_trilobites L_co-existed at any one L_time they were L_probably M_occupying L_different L_ecological M_niches , L_behaving in L_different M_ways , L_corresponding with the M_wide L_variation in L_shape that they M_show .
We can L_use the L_methods L_described above to L_elucidate some of these M_occupations , and M_get a M_glimpse , albeit an L_imperfect one , of the L_trilobite as it L_lived .
I will M_take an L_example where all the L_methods can be L_used , and where all M_point in the same M_direction , so that the M_answer is L_probably L_correct .
Most L_trilobites were L_broadly L_oval-shaped being L_rather L_longer than L_wide , not L_greatly L_convex , and with L_eyes that M_occupy L_perhaps a L_quarter of the L_length of the L_head .
There are a few L_trilobite L_species , L_however , with L_enormous , L_globular L_eyes ( L_see below ) .
By L_examining the M_way these L_animals were M_put M_together it is L_possible to L_suggest a L_likely M_mode of L_life .
L_Giant-eyed L_Ordovician L_trilobite , L_seen from the L_top and L_side .
L_Twice its L_natural L_size .
L_Enlargement M_shows a L_section through the L_lenses to M_show the L_direction of the M_field of L_view .
We can M_take the L_eyes L_first .
The L_trilobite L_eye was of a L_compound L_type , and each L_lens was M_made up of a L_calcite L_crystal .
From the L_optical L_properties of this L_mineral we L_know that the L_lens was M_able to M_interpret L_light M_coming from a L_direction more or L_less at L_right-angles to the L_lens L_surface .
So we can L_deduce what the M_field of L_vision of our L_globular-eyed L_trilobite was , by L_looking at the L_directions in which all the L_lenses L_face .

It M_turns out that our L_animal was M_able to L_see in L_almost every L_direction — L_upwards , L_downwards , L_sideways and L_forwards , and L_even L_backwards , because the L_eyes L_bulged out beyond the M_line of the L_rest of the L_body .
Most other L_trilobites have a L_predominantly L_lateral M_field of L_view .

If the L_animal L_lived on the L_sea L_bottom , it L_seems L_unlikely that it would have L_eye L_lenses L_specialized for L_looking L_downwards , and we L_begin to M_suspect that the L_animal M_habitually L_dwelt above the L_sea L_floor .
Other L_features of its L_shape are M_consistent with this .
At the– L_edge of the L_eyes are a L_pair of L_long L_spines , and these M_point L_downwards at a L_steep L_angle , at very L_awkward L_attitude for L_resting L_comfortably on the L_sea L_floor .
Most ‘ L_normal ’ L_trilobites have a more or L_less L_horizontal L_rim around the L_forward L_margin , which may have L_rested on the L_sediment L_surface .
The L_thorax of the L_large-eyed L_trilobite is L_remarkably L_long L_compared with the L_average L_trilobite ( L_compare Fig. 33 ) .

The L_convex , L_middle L_part of the L_thorax L_contained the L_musculature that M_operated the L_appendages ( which , as L_usual , are not L_preserved ) , and the L_relatively L_large L_volume of this L_region M_shows that the L_musculature was L_powerful .
The L_construction of this L_giant-eyed L_trilobite M_suggests that it L_lived an L_actively L_swimming L_life L_well above the L_bottom , and L_possibly in the L_surface L_waters of the L_sea .

Of L_course because there are no L_living L_trilobites we can not M_find M_direct L_confirmation of this L_hypothesis , but we can M_look for other L_arthropods that have the same M_modifications of the L_eyes , for L_example , in the L_present L_day L_oceans .

The L_analogy is M_found in such L_ocean-going L_amphipods ( a L_kind of ‘ L_shrimp ’ ) as L_Cystosoma , which L_also has L_enormously L_expanded L_eyes , L_looking like M_headlamps , L_compared with its L_bottom-dwelling M_relatives ( L_see above ) .
In L_fact L_many of the L_arthropods that L_inhabit the L_water M_column have L_large , L_globular L_eyes of this L_kind .
49 L_Fossil L_bony L_fish , Lates gracilis , L_Eocene .
This L_fish is L_preserved in a L_fine-grained L_limestone which M_preserved most of the L_skeletal L_details of the L_fish ( but not its L_colours ) .

This is a L_stout-bodied L_fish , L_something like a L_perch in L_general L_proportions , with L_long , L_low L_fins on L_upper and L_lower L_rear of the L_body ( L_fin M_rays L_finely L_divide near their L_ends ) .
L_Head to L_tail the L_fish L_measures 17 L_cm .
50 L_Vertebra of the L_Jurassic L_pliosaur , L_Liopleurodon L_species , L_Kimmeridge , L_southern L_England .
This is only one L_vertebra of an L_animal L_much too L_bulky to L_appear in a L_book of this L_size !
The L_original L_porous L_bone has been L_consolidated to L_become L_much L_heavier than it would have been in L_life .
L_Diameter of the L_vertebra is about 10 L_cm .
51 L_Fossil L_frog , L_Rana L_species , L_Miocene , L_Spain .
This L_species is L_preserved in a L_soft L_shale , but one which M_allows for the L_skeletal L_anatomy to be L_preserved in its L_entirety .
The L_outline of the L_soft L_parts are L_also L_clearly L_displayed , so that the L_animal has been L_preserved L_almost in M_frozen L_motion .
L_Frogs are one of the more L_numerous of L_amphibian L_fossils .
L_Specimen 12 L_cm L_long .
52 L_Fossil calcareous alga , M_belonging to the L_genus L_Coelosphaeridium , L_Ordovician , L_Ringsaker , L_Norway .
These L_spherical L_algae are L_preserved as L_internal L_moulds in a L_mudstone , the L_original L_calcite having L_disappeared .
M_Canals within the L_algae L_stand out as M_rods in this L_kind of L_preservation , which is L_common in L_Ordovician L_rocks .
There is a L_central L_sphere L_visible on one of the L_specimens .
M_Related L_forms are M_spread over L_much of the L_world in L_Ordovician and L_Silurian L_times .
L_Individual L_globes have a L_diameter of 1½–2 L_cm .
53 Fossil lycopod L_bark , L_Lepidodendron L_rimosum , L_Carboniferous , L_Newcastle , L_England .
This is a L_typical ‘ L_coal L_shale ’ ; L_shales and L_silts L_occurring between L_productive L_coal M_seams L_often L_contain L_impressions of the L_plants that M_went to L_form the L_coal .
The L_plant L_material itself is L_converted to L_black L_carbon .

6 L_cm L_long .

59 A ‘ L_prefern ’ , Archaeopteris hibernica , L_Devonian , L_Kilkenny , L_Ireland .

L_Giant-eyed L_living L_crustacean ( L_Cystosoma )

If it is L_correct that our L_trilobite L_lived above the L_sea L_bottom , L_actively L_swimming in the L_water , there are L_certain L_predictions we can M_make about its L_geological L_occurrence which can be L_tested by L_looking in the L_rocks .
Most L_bottom-dwelling L_trilobites M_preferred to L_live at a L_particular L_water L_depth , or on a L_particular L_type of L_sea L_bottom ( L_mud , L_sand or L_lime ) .
No such L_restriction should L_apply to our L_large-eyed L_species ; it should be M_found with all other L_different L_kinds of L_trilobite L_assemblages without L_preference .

This has been L_proved in L_several L_places : in some L_arctic L_localities it is M_found with L_trilobites that L_lived at L_great L_depths in the L_muds of the L_Ordovician L_ocean , while in L_Canada the same L_species L_occurs L_mixed with the L_inhabitants of the L_shallow-water L_seas , where L_limestones were L_accumulating .
By the same M_token the L_free-swimming L_trilobite may be L_expected to have a very L_wide L_geographical L_distribution , for L_oceans would be no M_barrier to it .

And again this L_proves to be the L_case : our L_example is L_found in L_Arctic L_Canada , in the L_high L_Arctic L_island of L_Spitsbergen , L_thousands of L_miles L_away in what is now the L_desert L_country of L_Nevada and L_Utah in the L_United L_States , in L_western L_Ireland , in L_Russia , and in L_northwestern L_Australia .

So in this L_case the L_different M_sources of L_evidence all M_point in the same M_direction , whether L_derived from a L_detailed L_consideration of the M_way the L_trilobite is M_constructed , or by L_analogy with L_living L_animals with L_similar L_adaptations , or from the L_evidence of the L_rocks or the L_distribution of the L_fossils .
These L_giant-eyed L_trilobites of the L_Ordovician were L_active M_swimmers in the L_surface L_waters , as M_near L_certainly as we can L_ever L_know .
There are all L_kinds of L_different L_questions we can L_ask about the L_life M_habits of these L_trilobites , which are not L_subject to the same L_kind of M_careful L_scrutiny .
What did they L_eat , for L_example ?
Because we do not have the L_legs L_preserved , it is not L_possible to L_see how the L_mouth L_appendages L_functioned in L_feeding , and neither are the L_stomach L_contents L_preserved .
So here there are only more or L_less L_likely L_speculations .

L_Active M_swimmers in the L_surface L_waters of the M_present L_oceans are L_likely to L_feed L_directly on the L_plankton , and the L_trilobites may have had a L_method of M_harvesting M_large L_quantities of L_minute L_food .

Or they may have been L_hunters after L_larger L_prey , in which L_case when L_appendages are L_eventually L_discovered they may L_prove to have L_adaptations for L_grasping and L_manipulating L_larger L_food .
M_Puzzles M_remain , L_even though we can be L_certain of the L_rudiments of the L_story .
L_CONTROVERSY AMONG THE L_GIANT L_DINOSAURS

The L_giant L_sauropod L_dinosaurs like L_Brachiosaurus were the L_largest L_land L_animals the L_world has M_seen they L_weighed more than 80 L_tonnes and M_present L_quite L_different L_problems in the L_interpretation of their L_life M_habits from the L_diminutive L_trilobites .

Such L_spectacular L_animals have L_obviously M_attracted L_much L_attention , and one L_might L_suppose that the L_problem of how they L_lived would have been L_satisfactorily L_solved L_long L_ago .

Most of the L_popular L_books M_showing the L_Mesozoic M_giants in their L_natural L_setting L_portray them L_wallowing about in L_swamps L_flanked by L_deep L_vegetation , their L_bodies L_largely under L_water .

L_Surely an L_animal of this L_bulk , it was L_argued , must be L_partly L_supported by L_water , and their L_relatively L_inconsequential L_teeth must have been L_adapted for L_chewing on the L_kind of L_soft , L_luxuriant L_vegetation that L_flourishes in and around L_swamps .
Because their L_nasal L_openings were on the L_top of their L_heads they could L_even L_continue to L_breathe if it L_became L_necessary ( L_see p. 115 ) to L_totally L_submerge .
L_Recently the L_life M_habits of the M_giants have been M_looked at in a M_way that M_disproves most of these L_traditional L_notions .
L_Consider the M_structure of their L_legs .

The L_sauropods have L_relatively L_long , M_pillar-like L_legs , L_resembling those of the L_elephant , the L_largest L_living L_land L_animal , and may have been L_well L_adapted for L_supporting the L_huge L_bulk of the L_animal .

The L_feet of the L_sauropod are L_small ( L_relatively M_speaking ! ) , with L_short , L_stubby L_toes , yet L_animals that L_walk on L_soft L_mud M_tend to have L_spreading L_feet to L_distribute their L_weight more L_evenly .
It is L_difficult to M_see how the L_compact L_feet of the L_sauropod could M_avoid L_becoming L_stuck L_fast in the L_soft , L_muddy L_bottom of a L_lake .

If the L_dinosaur did , after all , L_live on L_dry L_land , then the L_long L_neck could have L_usefully L_functioned to M_allow the L_animal to L_browse the L_high L_foliage of L_trees ( L_see p. 116 ) .
It has been L_suggested that an L_animal of the L_size of L_Brachiosaurus could not have L_breathed under L_water because of the L_pressure on the L_lungs .
Their L_fossil L_remains L_seem to L_occur with other L_animals and L_plants , which are L_generally L_accepted as L_terrestrial .
There is L_even some L_evidence from the L_tracks they have L_left behind that L_Diplodocus and its M_allies L_moved about in L_herds .

They may have been the L_gigantic L_reptilian L_analogue of the L_elephant , and it may be no L_coincidence that the L_elephant L_also has its L_nasal L_openings on L_top of the L_skull , with the L_nostrils in this L_case M_sited at the L_end of the L_trunk it has been L_suggested that some L_sauropods may have had a L_proboscis of some L_sort .
The M_balance of L_evidence L_seems to be M_swinging M_away from the L_original L_idea of L_swamp-dwelling L_giant L_dinosaurs to L_fully L_terrestrial M_habits .
But other M_aspects of the L_dinosaur L_living M_habits are L_still more M_strongly L_debated .

In the L_last few L_years a M_powerful L_controversy has M_arisen over whether the L_dinosaurs as a L_whole were L_cold-blooded , like all L_living L_reptiles ( and there is no L_doubt that L_dinosaurs were L_reptiles ) , or L_warm-blooded , L_resembling L_mammals in this L_respect .
L_Cold-blooded L_animals have to ‘ M_warm up ’ before they can be L_fully L_active ; that is why L_lizards and L_snakes L_bask in the L_sun in L_temperate M_climates .
For this L_reason they can not M_cope with L_climates having L_greatly M_extended L_winters .

L_Warm-blooded L_animals have the same L_body L_temperatures at all L_times , and can be more M_continuously L_active , but they M_use M_far more L_energy — and L_hence L_need more L_food — than L_cold-blooded L_animals of the same L_size .

The M_posture of L_many L_dinosaurs , and L_particularly the L_carnivorous L_theropod L_dinosaurs , was L_fully L_erect with the L_legs beneath the L_body , and unlike the L_sprawling L_legs of L_living L_reptiles ( L_see p. 116 ) .

The L_long L_back L_legs of such M_hunters L_look L_highly L_suitable for L_running , and as they did so the L_long L_tail may have been L_held L_erect as a L_kind of L_counter-balance ( L_see p. 116 ) .
For any L_kind of L_prolonged L_activity , L_warm-bloodedness would have been a L_distinct L_advantage .
Under the L_microscope L_even the L_bone M_structure of these L_dinosaurs L_looks more like that of L_living L_mammals than L_cold-blooded L_reptiles .

On the other M_hand it can be L_argued that the L_sauropods like L_Brachiosaurus were so L_large , and with a L_relatively L_small L_surface L_area through which to L_cool L_compared with their L_enormous L_volume , that their L_cooling L_rate could have been L_slow L_enough to M_allow them to L_sustain more M_continuous L_activity than L_smaller , L_living L_reptiles .

It has L_also been L_argued that the L_small L_mouths of the M_giants L_simply could not have downed L_enough L_food to M_support a L_warm-blooded L_metabolism , L_particularly L_plant L_food that L_needs a L_lot of L_processing before it L_becomes L_available as L_energy .

The M_armoured or M_plated L_dinosaurs L_include some L_species that L_seem too L_heavily L_burdened with L_protective M_armour to have been very L_active , but this does not L_necessarily L_mean that they had to be L_cold-blooded .
M_Protagonists of the L_warm-blooded L_theory will L_show some of the L_horned L_dinosaurs L_charging over the L_Cretaceous L_plains like M_furious M_reptilian M_rhinoceroses !
One L_idea about the L_life M_habits of the L_dinosaur M_giants , L_published in L_Joc and L_Colette at the L_Natural L_History L_Museum in 1935
The M_warm-blooded L_supporters M_tend to L_ally themselves with the L_supporters of a L_theory about the L_relationships of the L_dinosaurs .
This is that the L_dinosaurs , or a M_close L_dinosaur L_relative , L_included the L_ancestors of the L_living L_birds .

Some of the L_smaller , and most L_certainly L_highly L_active L_dinosaurs were about the L_size of a L_chicken , and there is more than a M_passing L_similarity between a L_running L_ostrich and the L_kind of M_reconstruction that M_shows L_fleet-footed , L_running L_dinosaurs .

The M_point is that L_birds themselves are L_warm-blooded , like L_mammals , and if L_birds and L_dinosaurs are as M_closely L_related as now L_seems L_likely , then it L_obviously L_increases the L_likelihood that the L_dinosaurs themselves may have been L_warm-blooded .

The M_pros and M_cons of this L_theory are the M_subject of L_much L_contentious L_debate by L_experts , but it would L_probably be L_correct to M_say that the M_greater L_number of L_specialists L_believe that at L_least the more L_bipedal of the L_dinosaurs , L_including L_small and L_large L_carnivores , were L_warm-blooded , L_active L_animals .

A M_lot of the L_argument among the L_authorities on these L_animals is about the L_equivalence or L_otherwise of L_certain L_bones in L_dinosaurs and L_bird L_skeletons ( and L_particularly the L_Jurassic L_bird L_Archaeopteryx ) ; this M_makes for L_rather M_dry L_reading for the M_layman .
But the M_end-product is the M_accurate M_reconstruction of the L_Jurassic and L_Cretaceous L_terrestrial M_world , over which the L_dinosaurs were L_indisputably L_dominant .
L_Action and L_Inaction in the L_Cities
L_Susanne L_MacGregor and L_Ben L_Pimlott
The L_essays in this L_book do not M_amount to a L_programme : but they are L_intended to L_provide a M_springboard for one .
The M_aim is to L_analyse a L_problem which L_economic M_growth L_alone has M_failed to M_cure — and to M_consider L_possible L_new M_forms of L_public L_action .
The M_biggest L_single L_difficulty in M_drawing L_attention to L_urban L_poverty is that it is not L_new , but L_simply — in some of its most L_worrying L_manifestations — L_getting L_worse .
Like the L_poor themselves , the L_inner L_city has L_long been with us .
L_Ever since the L_Industrial L_Revolution L_created a L_mass L_urban L_society , the M_conditions of the L_poorest L_city L_dwellers have M_given M_rise to L_anxiety among the L_better off .
The L_inner L_city has been L_variously M_regarded as a L_cause for L_moral L_outrage , a M_threat to L_public M_order , or as a M_stain on the L_nation 's M_conscience .

L_Meanwhile L_bad L_housing , L_bad L_sanitation , L_lack of L_education , and other M_perennial L_ills L_associated with L_overcrowding and L_poverty have been L_routinely L_denounced by L_political L_leaders and L_social L_reformers .

A M_central L_objective of the L_post-war L_welfare L_state was , L_indeed , to L_alleviate the L_problems of the L_urban L_poor , over whom L_Beveridge 's Five M_Giants ( L_Want , L_Disease , L_Ignorance , L_Squalor , and L_Idleness ) had for so L_long M_held M_sway .

In the L_early 1940s and 1950s , the L_belief was L_widely M_held that a L_combination of L_government L_intervention — in the M_form of L_town L_planning , L_housing and L_health L_programmes , and the M_provision of L_social L_security — and L_permanent L_male M_full L_employment , M_together with an L_increase in L_real L_wages , would M_reduce L_suffering L_due to L_poverty to L_manageable M_proportions .

The 1964 L_Labour L_Government was L_elected on a M_tide of L_impatience at the M_slackening M_pace of L_social L_reform , but L_also of L_optimism that L_little more than L_economic M_growth , M_fuelled by L_technological L_change , was L_needed to M_remove the L_main L_causes of L_urban L_deprivation ( L_MacGregor , 1981 ) .
L_Disillusion M_swiftly M_followed .

The L_work of L_Peter L_Townsend and L_others M_showed that , M_far from L_presiding over the M_elimination of L_poverty , the L_Wilson L_Government L_actually M_failed to M_prevent some of its M_features from L_worsening ( L_Townsend and L_Bosanquet , 1972 ) .
L_Evidence L_began to M_mount that L_much of the L_social L_welfare L_paternalism of the L_post-war L_period had L_created L_almost as L_many L_problems as it M_solved .
Neither the L_Butler L_Education L_Act of 1944 , nor the M_introduction of L_comprehensive L_schools , M_prevented a M_high M_proportion of L_children from under-achieving .
L_Post-war L_reconstruction and L_housing L_programmes L_seemed to do L_nothing to M_prevent , and L_seemed L_even to M_encourage , a M_rise in L_crime and L_mental L_illness .

L_Meanwhile , in L_many L_parts of the L_country , a L_problem as M_old as L_cities themselves — M_tension between L_cultural M_groups , between L_earlier L_immigrants and L_newer L_ones , between L_black , L_brown , and L_white , and ( L_increasingly ) between M_large M_sections of L_urban L_youth and the L_police — M_came to be L_identified as the L_key L_inner-city L_issue .
M_Rising L_unemployment M_turned a L_lingering and M_growing M_malaise into a M_crisis .
As in the L_United L_States , so in L_Britain it was an L_outbreak of L_violence that M_dramatically M_brought the L_plight of the L_inner L_cities to L_public L_notice .

In the L_early 1980s , at a L_time when L_manufacturing L_industry was M_collapsing and the M_outlook for the L_unskilled M_looked L_particularly M_bleak , L_frustration M_boiled over in a L_series of L_riots in L_London , L_Bristol , L_Birmingham , L_Liverpool , and L_elsewhere .

All were L_spontaneous L_outbursts : L_none , L_contrary to some L_claims , were L_politically L_inspired or M_orchestrated ( except in L_Northern L_Ireland where L_urban L_problems L_existed on a L_grander , more M_devastating M_scale , and where there was a L_unique L_heritage ) .
L_Many had an ‘ L_ethnic ’ M_dimension , in the M_sense that L_many of the L_rioters were L_black .
Unlike , L_however , the 1958 L_Notting L_Hill L_riots , few of those L_involved were L_immigrants — the M_vast L_majority were L_British L_born .
And the L_disturbances could not L_strictly be L_called L_racial : the most M_prominent M_feature was that of M_violent M_clashes between L_young L_people and the L_police .
The L_problems , L_however , were not M_confined to M_violent L_upheavals of this L_kind .

L_Paul L_Harrison 's L_Inside the L_Inner L_City : L_Life under the M_Cutting M_Edge M_focused on L_Hackney , a L_London L_borough M_ranked among the L_worst off on any M_scale of L_urban L_deprivation ( L_Harrison , 1983 ) .
L_Harrison L_describes ( p. 369 ) the M_way in which the L_inner L_urban L_powder-keg M_leads to a M_vicious M_circle , with L_many M_victims , but few L_individual M_villains :

The L_police L_force M_face the L_virtually L_impossible L_task of M_keeping the M_lid on the M_explosive M_mixture of M_ingredients that the M_dynamics of L_British L_society have M_assembled in the L_inner L_city .
This M_mixture , M_heated by L_recession and M_high L_unemployment , L_inevitably M_generates a M_high M_level of L_crime .

This L_necessitates , in M_turn , a M_far more L_numerous and L_ubiquitous L_police L_presence than in other L_kinds of L_area , M_far more L_frequent L_unpleasant M_contact with the L_public as L_potential L_suspects , and M_far M_greater L_opportunities for L_police L_misjudgment or L_abuse .

The L_inevitable L_sufferers , of L_course , are the L_poor , of whom those who L_actually M_commit the L_offences that L_concern the L_police are a M_tiny L_minority and whom , L_indeed , it should be the L_purpose of the L_police to L_protect .
Not only are the most L_disadvantaged on the M_receiving M_end of most L_crime , L_argues L_Harrison , they L_also have to L_put up with the M_heaviest L_police L_presence .
They are more L_likely to be L_stopped and L_searched , and to be the M_victim of L_mistaken L_arrest or L_conviction .

At the same L_time , the L_residents of the L_poorest L_areas have to M_suffer , in a M_way that is not L_true of those who L_live L_elsewhere , a M_growing L_fear of L_attack on themselves or their L_property .
L_Improved L_police L_methods might M_help , L_writes L_Harrison , to M_contain the L_problem .
But , without other L_changes , the L_result is L_likely to be a ‘ L_society of M_barricaded L_self-defence , and a M_steady M_erosion of L_civil M_liberties ’ .
And he L_concludes , ‘ of all the L_warnings that the L_inner L_city has to M_offer for the M_direction L_British L_society is M_taking , this is L_perhaps the most L_sinister ’ .

L_Harrison 's M_vision of a L_nightmarish L_future for L_inner L_cities , M_locked in a M_cold or M_hot L_war between L_have-nots and the M_forces of L_public M_order , was L_echoed by L_Robert L_Chesshyre ( 1987 , p. 95 ) , who L_concluded that by the L_late 1980s :

The L_basic L_social L_contract , whereby L_citizens M_enjoy L_certain L_rights — L_including L_health L_care , M_decent L_education and L_housing and a L_job — in L_return for which they M_observe the M_rule of L_law , was M_breaking down .

As a L_consequence an L_underclass was M_evolving — L_football L_hooligans , L_muggers , L_inner L_city L_rioters — L_somewhat more L_frightening than their L_Dickensian L_forebears because they were L_mobile and all too L_visible .
L_Recently , of L_course , there has been an M_added M_dimension — L_part L_media-and-politician M_inflated , L_part L_real : L_drugs .
The M_spiral in L_drug L_abuse and L_trafficking , with M_direct L_consequences for the L_AIDS L_epidemic , has L_created a L_new L_kind of L_alarm .
The L_early 1980s M_witnessed a L_radical L_change in M_patterns of L_heroin L_taking , alongside the L_global L_increase .

L_Sensational L_media and L_police L_reports in 1989 L_seemed to M_suggest an L_increased L_use of ‘ M_crack ’ among L_young L_people in L_parts of L_south L_London , L_Liverpool , and L_Birmingham — with M_attendant L_fears that this L_particularly L_dangerous L_substance might L_become L_widespread , as it was L_reported to be in L_parts of the L_United L_States .

for the L_moment , L_however , the M_pattern of L_drug L_abuse in L_Britain L_remains as L_varied as L_ever — with M_home-produced L_drugs such as L_amphetamines as M_serious a L_problem as those that M_hit the L_headlines .

It is a M_symptom of L_public L_anxiety about L_urban L_squalor — and , L_less L_creditably , of L_class and L_racial L_prejudice — that ‘ L_drugs ’ and ‘ L_inner L_cities ’ are M_automatically M_linked in the L_popular M_consciousness ( L_MacGregor , 1989a ) .
L_Nevertheless , L_drug-taking and more L_particularly the L_disruptive L_social L_consequences of L_addiction , are L_especially M_serious in L_areas of L_city L_poverty ( L_Burr , 1989 ) .

In L_short , if L_life was L_always M_harder in the L_inner L_cities than L_elsewhere , and if M_conditions may L_temporarily have been L_alleviated by the M_impact of the L_welfare L_state and M_rising L_incomes , the L_last L_decade has been L_widely M_represented as a L_period of L_deterioration .

L_Moreover , few would L_dispute that this L_apparent L_decline is a L_reality : the L_first L_words of the L_Prime L_Minister herself , after the L_result of the 1987 L_election was L_known , were an L_acknowledgement of the M_challenge L_posed to L_Government by the ‘ L_inner L_cities ’ .
What has been L_lacking L_however — as L_well as the L_political will to do L_something — has been any M_shared L_agreement on the L_cause .
Can the L_problems of L_urban L_poverty be L_blamed on L_individual L_pathology ?
On L_feckless L_parents and L_grandparents ?
Or on the L_social or L_physical M_environment — the L_replacement of M_companionably L_unhygienic L_slums by M_soulless L_tower L_blocks with L_broken L_lifts ( L_Coleman et al . ,
Or would a L_simple M_injection of M_resources L_transform L_Kafkaesque M_honeycombs into M_happy L_living-spaces , with a L_consequent L_decline in L_inner-city L_ills ?
‘ A L_duke can L_live L_comfortably in a L_castle , after all ’ , the L_architect L_Cedric L_Price is L_quoted as L_saying .
‘ You and I would L_die of L_frostbite .
Same L_building — just a L_matter of L_money and L_management ’ ( L_Parkin , 1989 ) .
The M_view that only ‘ L_outstanding L_management ’ could M_meet the L_problem was M_held by the L_Audit L_Commission ( 1987 ) .

The M_picture M_painted by the L_Commission 's L_report on L_inner L_London is as L_gruesome as any L_ever M_presented ( and is itself M_revealing of L_common L_prejudices in its L_choice of L_indicators of L_deprivation ) :
In some L_London L_boroughs , L_unemployment among L_young L_men L_exceeds 45% ; in some L_places , among L_young L_blacks , it L_exceeds 60% .
More than one L_child in three is L_born into a L_single L_parent L_family .
M_Half the L_school L_leavers have no O L_levels or their L_CSE L_equivalents .
L_Homelessness , L_housing M_conditions , L_crime are L_worsening L_year by L_year , as the L_cycle of L_urban L_deprivation L_becomes more L_established ( p. 1 )

M_Drawing on L_North L_American L_experience , the L_Commission M_concluded that ‘ M_poor L_management was an L_important L_contributory M_factor to L_New L_York 's L_problems ’ , and M_sought to M_apply the same L_lessons here ( p. 2 ) .

The L_Government 's post-1987 L_initiatives have , to some M_extent , M_reflected a M_diagnosis M_based on the L_need for L_better L_management — though on the L_principle that M_central L_authorities can L_provide a M_firmer M_grip than L_local L_ones — but M_combined with an L_anti-collectivist L_belief in the L_restorative M_powers of L_capitalism .
L_Leech and L_Amin ( 1988 , p. 14 ) L_summarize this M_approach , not L_unfairly , in the M_following L_terms :

the L_encouragement of L_private L_investment and the M_liberation of the M_market ; the L_containment of the M_forces of L_social L_discontent ; the M_control of the M_powers of the L_local L_authorities ; and the L_encouragement of the L_movement of the L_wealthy into the L_inner L_city L_thus L_creating M_buffer L_areas of L_Tory M_support , M_accentuating L_inequalities and L_injustice and ( L_hopefully though not L_necessarily ) M_reducing the L_potential for L_conflict among the L_urban L_poor .

The L_main M_thrust of the L_Government 's L_policy is M_contained in the L_January 1988 L_White L_Paper on L_Regional L_Policy and the L_Enterprise L_Economy , in the L_new L_Employment M_Training L_programme , and L_especially in the L_March 1988 L_Action for L_Cities L_programme — all M_resting on M_wider L_reforms to L_local L_government M_structure and L_finance , and to L_education and L_housing .
The most L_striking M_feature of this M_package , L_apart from its M_aim L_actively to L_involve L_employers and L_entrepreneurs , is a M_sharp M_reduction in the M_role of L_local L_government .

Despite the L_contemporary M_tone of L_much of L_Action for L_Cities , the L_programme 's L_heritage can be M_traced to the L_early 1960s L_studies which L_provided the L_basis for the 1965 Milner–Holland L_Report on L_housing and the 1967 L_Plowden L_Report on L_education , as a L_result of which L_general L_improvement L_areas and L_education L_priority L_areas were L_established .
The 1970s ‘ L_Urban L_Programme ’ had a L_social , L_rather than L_economic , M_emphasis and was M_administered by the L_Home L_Office .

It was L_initiated L_partly in L_response to the L_furore L_caused by L_Enoch L_Powell 's 1969 ‘ L_rivers of L_blood ’ L_speech , L_much as L_disturbances at the 1976 L_Notting L_Hill L_Carnival M_prompted further M_steps on the L_part of the L_Department of the L_Environment — ‘ A L_riot M_makes a L_much M_bigger M_impact on L_government L_thinking ’ , as L_Donnison ( 1987 ) has M_pointed out , ‘ than any L_amount of M_earnest and M_accurate L_research ’ .

The L_Urban L_Programme L_consisted of L_grants and L_initiatives under the 1969 L_Local L_Government L_Grants ( L_Social L_Need ) L_Act , which was L_intended as a M_flexible M_instrument to L_provide L_supplementary L_help to L_local L_authorities in the M_fields of L_housing , L_education , and L_health .
L_Originally , the L_Programme L_supplemented L_existing M_central and L_local L_government L_schemes M_designed to M_meet L_special L_needs in L_urban L_areas .

The L_scope was M_extended in an ‘ L_enhanced ’ L_Urban L_Programme , which L_included L_economic and L_environmental as L_well as L_social L_projects , and was L_specifically M_directed at the L_inner L_urban L_areas where the L_problems were most M_severe .

L_Earlier , the L_change of M_emphasis from a ‘ L_social ’ to an ‘ L_economic and L_environmental ’ M_focus had been M_reflected in a M_switch of L_responsibility for the L_Programme from the L_Home L_Office to the L_Department of the L_Environment .

The ‘ L_enhanced L_Programme L_resulted from the 1978 L_Inner L_Urban L_Areas L_Act , M_based on a L_White L_Paper , L_published the L_previous L_year , on L_Policy for the L_Inner L_Cities ( L_DoE , 1977 ) , the L_first L_comprehensive L_policy L_statement on the M_subject to L_acknowledge it as a M_definable and L_cohesive L_problem .

The L_White L_Paper M_drew on L_studies M_conducted L_earlier in the L_decade in L_Liverpool , L_Birmingham , and L_London which M_pointed to a M_debilitating M_flight of L_capital and L_skilled L_labour from the L_critical L_areas of L_deprivation .
A L_key M_aspect of the 1977 L_White L_Paper was the M_stress it M_placed on the M_wider L_effects of L_poverty : that it was not just those with L_acute L_needs who L_suffered .

It M_argued that in L_talking about L_inner L_cities it was M_vital to L_think in L_terms not just of L_individuals , but of L_society ; that the L_multiple L_deprivations of the L_worst M_hit L_areas L_affected all the L_residents ; that the L_consequences L_included a L_pervasive M_sense of L_neglect and M_decay , a L_decline in L_community M_spirit , a M_low M_standard of L_neighbourhood L_facilities , and an L_increase in L_crime and L_vandalism ; and that , without L_government L_intervention , the L_future was one of M_reduced L_job L_opportunities , L_deteriorating L_housing , and a L_decline in L_public L_services .

The L_document , and the L_legislation that M_derived from it , M_pointed to a L_positively L_discriminatory M_approach : with both M_central and L_local L_government L_supplementing L_existing L_programmes in such a M_way as to M_strengthen L_local L_economies , as L_well as the L_physical and L_social M_environment .
Such M_measures M_constituted the L_present L_Government 's L_heritage , when it M_took M_office in 1979 .

L_None of them , of L_course , L_anticipated the M_scale of the L_problems which were L_caused by the L_slump and M_collapse of L_much of what M_remained of L_inner L_urban L_manufacturing L_industry in the L_early 1980s .
L_Neither , at L_first , did the M_incoming L_administration M_foresee the M_impact of M_rising L_unemployment , which was to be L_especially M_serious among the L_urban L_young .

L_True , the L_new L_Secretary of L_State for the L_Environment M_laid M_stress , from the L_outset , on the L_need for L_economic M_regeneration , and M_indicated his L_sympathy for the L_voluntary M_sector in the M_tackling of L_urban L_problems .
The L_previous L_Government , L_however , had L_already M_pointed to the L_need to M_revitalize L_urban L_economies , and at L_first the L_shift was more L_rhetorical than L_real .

L_Michael L_Heseltine ( 1987 , p. 138 ) has since L_claimed that ‘ we M_set a M_new L_objective : to L_make the L_inner L_cities L_places where L_people would L_want to L_live and L_work and where the L_private L_investor would be L_willing to M_put his L_money ’ .
L_Partnership L_became his L_slogan — the M_partnership of L_public and L_private L_brains and L_money .
A L_new L_Urban L_Development L_Grant was L_devised , to L_pump-prime with L_public L_funds L_schemes which would then M_attract L_private L_investment .

L_Heseltine 's M_vision was of ‘ L_partnerships which M_recognise that there are some M_things that only L_governments can M_pay for , but L_also that the L_ingenuity and M_flexibility of the L_private M_sector is L_indispensable ’ ( p. 156 ) .

He L_claims that M_serious L_work on L_inner-city L_policy L_began in 1979 : but it was , L_undoubtedly , the L_riots of 1981 , L_coinciding with the M_biggest M_drop in L_employment and L_job L_vacancies since the L_war , which M_gave M_impetus to the M_new M_approach .
L_Urban L_Development L_Corporations were L_introduced in 1981 in L_London L_Docklands and L_Merseyside , and the L_Urban L_Development L_Grant M_came in L_late the M_following L_year .
L_Conservative L_instincts were , of L_course , to M_minimize — within the ‘ M_partnership — L_state L_involvement and L_expenditure , L_relative to that of L_private L_enterprise .

L_Yet , the L_irony of the L_early 1980s — as a L_deteriorating , but L_perennial , L_urban L_problem L_rapidly L_became the most L_acute M_aspect of the M_crisis of L_mass L_unemployment — was that a L_Tory L_government , L_willy-nilly , M_found itself L_presiding over an L_increase in L_state L_intervention through a M_variety of L_agencies .
The L_increased M_scale of M_operations L_also M_ushered in another L_fashion of the 1980s — M_new L_management M_structures .
L_Thus in 1985 L_City L_Action> L_Teams were L_introduced to each ‘ L_Inner L_City L_Partnership ’ L_area to M_co-ordinate the L_work of the three L_government L_departments L_involved .
L_Task M_forces , L_meanwhile , were M_directed to M_tackle L_youth L_unemployment .
By 1986/7 the L_Urban L_Programme was M_supporting 1,380 L_starter L_units and 400 L_business L_starts in L_enterprise M_workshops .

It was L_providing 27,500 M_training M_places ( L_often in L_conjunction with the L_Manpower L_Services L_Commission ) : some 2,500 L_buildings were being L_improved ; L_estate L_action M_aimed to M_tackle L_run down L_housing ; and a M_large L_number of M_new ‘ L_partnerships ’ ( which some might M_see as L_subsidies , or M_discredited L_regional L_grants , in a M_new L_guise ) were in M_operation , in an L_effort to M_bring L_private L_investment to L_run-down L_urban L_areas .

By 1988 it was L_claimed that £200 million of L_Urban L_Development L_Grant and L_Urban M_Regeneration L_Grant had L_successfully ‘ M_levered ’ more than £800 million of L_private L_investment into the L_inner L_cities ( although how L_much of the L_latter L_sum might have been L_invested in any L_case is L_difficult to M_say ) .

L_Meanwhile , there were other L_incentive L_schemes — L_Enterprise L_Zones , for L_example , and L_simplified L_Planning L_Zones , which M_aimed to M_lift L_tax and L_planning ‘ M_barriers ’ in L_order to L_facilitate L_investment .

L_Indeed , while with one M_hand L_trying to M_hold down L_expenditure by L_local L_authorities , the L_Government M_found itself by the L_late 1980s L_involved with the other M_hand in M_massive L_ear-marked L_spending on L_inner L_urban L_areas .

The L_Department of the L_Environment L_alone by 1988 was M_spending half a billion L_pounds out of an L_Action for L_Cities L_total , L_involving most M_Home L_departments , L_estimated at £3 billion .
L_Perhaps a L_Labour L_government would have M_spent L_even more : it would L_certainly have M_spent it in L_different M_ways .

It is a M_curious L_comment on L_Thatcherism , L_however , that the L_administration most M_committed to a M_reduction in the M_role of the L_state , and in the L_need for an M_independent L_private M_sector , has M_spent more on L_specific L_urban M_regeneration and L_employment L_schemes and L_incentives to L_private L_investment in L_urban L_areas than any other in L_recent L_history .

One of the most L_bizarre M_aspects of L_government L_policy has been the L_effective M_murder of the L_voluntary M_sector , and its M_appropriation , by L_subterfuge , into the L_Tory M_version of the L_corporate L_state .
L_Conservatives have L_always L_lauded the ‘ L_voluntarist ’ L_principle in L_welfare , and M_encouraged it from M_platforms .

M_Faced , L_however , with the M_catastrophic L_increase in L_unemployment and the L_need to M_occupy M_large L_numbers of L_workless L_people without M_directly L_employing them ( which would have M_run M_counter to the L_economic L_doctrine which had M_led to the L_redundancy of L_many of them in the L_first M_place ) , the L_Government M_poured L_money into any ‘ L_voluntary ’ L_agency M_willing to M_put in a L_bid for L_government-funded L_cheap L_labour .
One L_result was the M_triumphant M_expansion of some M_charitable L_organizations , which M_rejoiced both at their L_new-found L_importance and at the L_Government 's L_munificence .

Another was the L_transformation of L_many such M_bodies , L_already M_heavily L_subsidized from L_public L_funds , into de facto L_agencies of the L_state , which M_financed them and L_indirectly M_determined their L_policy .

L_Nowhere was the M_impact of this M_clumsy M_sleight of M_hand more L_evident than in the L_inner L_cities , where L_voluntary L_organizations had been most L_active , and where the L_Government was most M_anxious for them to M_mop up L_unemployment .

L_However , the L_later M_withdrawal of L_government M_support , with the M_scrapping of the L_Community L_Programme as L_unemployment M_receded , M_left L_many of these L_voluntary L_organizations M_high and M_dry .

The L_National L_Council for L_Voluntary L_Organizations ( L_NCVO ) has M_suggested from a L_recent M_survey that around 3,000 L_projects had been L_affected and had M_lost £285 million in L_funding ( L_MacGregor , 1990 ) .
There was , of L_course , a L_crucial M_element in the L_Government 's M_anxiety : the M_high L_concentration of L_ethnic L_minorities in the L_areas of L_concern .
In 1981 L_nearly 40 per L_cent of L_ethnic L_minorities in the L_UK L_lived in ‘ L_partnership ’ or ‘ L_programme ’ L_areas .
There is a M_danger in L_reading M_back from this L_figure another L_stereotype , L_similar to the L_Pavlovian ‘ L_drug addiction/inner L_city ’ M_assumed M_link .
Some L_urban L_areas have M_serious L_problems without a L_major L_ethnic M_dimension ( L_Newcastle , L_Teesside ) ; not all M_members of L_ethnic L_minorities are L_poor or L_deprived .

L_Nevertheless , the L_high L_proportion of L_inner L_urban L_populations L_composed of L_people from L_ethnic L_minorities , and the L_high L_incidence among these L_groups of all the L_indices of L_poverty and L_social and L_environmental L_hardship — L_combined with the L_specific L_problem of L_inter-racial L_rivalry , L_harassment , and L_tension — L_make L_race and L_ethnicity an L_aspect that is L_central to any L_analysis of the L_inner L_cities and of any L_ameliorative L_approach .
MAKING M_SENSE OF THE 1981 L_RIOTS
M_Reactions to the L_riots have M_concentrated on a M_number of L_key L_variables that are L_said to L_characterize the L_localities in which the L_riots have L_occurred .

L_Lord L_Scarman 's L_report on the 1981 M_disorders M_highlighted the L_importance of L_unemployment , L_urban L_deprivation , L_racial L_disadvantage , L_relations between L_young L_blacks and the L_police , the L_decline of L_civic L_consent , and L_political L_exclusion as the L_key L_issues .
Other M_reactions have M_concentrated on the L_issue of the M_interplay between L_inner-city M_decay and L_racial L_disadvantage in L_contemporary L_Britain .
L_Yet L_others have L_argued that the L_unrest can be M_seen as a M_symptom of the M_breakdown of L_law and M_order in L_British L_society ( L_Gaffney , 1987 ; L_Hall , 1987 ; L_Keith , 1987 ) .
The L_main L_issues that were M_prominent in L_debates during 1980–1 were ‘ L_race ’ and ‘ L_law and M_order ’ .

This was by no L_means an L_accident , since throughout the 1970s a M_powerful M_body of L_media , L_political , and L_academic L_opinion had been M_constructed around the L_theme of how L_Britain was M_drifting into a ‘ L_violent L_society ’ , and how the L_basis of L_consent was being M_shifted by the M_pressures of L_immigration and the M_growth of L_multi-racial L_inner L_city L_areas .
A M_glimpse of the M_impact of the 1980–1 L_riots at this M_level can be L_achieved through two L_important L_debates in L_Parliament .
The L_first M_took M_place in the M_midst of the L_July 1981 L_riots , and had as its L_theme : ‘ L_Civil L_Disturbances ’ .

The M_tone of the L_debate was M_set by L_Home L_Secretary L_William L_Whitelaw 's L_introductory L_statement in which he L_spoke of ( a ) the L_need to ‘ M_remove the M_scourge of L_criminal L_violence from our L_streets ’ , and ( b ) the L_urgency of L_developing ‘ L_policies M_designed to M_promote the L_mutual L_tolerance and L_understanding upon which the M_whole L_future of a L_free L_democratic L_society L_depends ’ ( L_Hansard , vol. 8 , 16 L_July 1981 : col. 1405 ) .

The ‘ M_scourge of L_criminal L_violence ’ was , L_Whitelaw L_argued , a L_danger to the M_whole M_framework of L_consent and L_legality on which the L_political L_institutions of L_British L_society were M_based .

In L_reply L_Roy L_Hattersley M_supported the M_call for the L_immediate M_suppression of L_street L_violence , but L_warned that the M_roots of such L_riots could not be L_dealt with until all L_people M_felt they had a M_stake in L_British L_society ( ibid. : cols. 1407–9 )
The L_second L_debate M_took M_place on 26 L_November 1981 , on the L_publication of the L_Scarman L_Report , and had as its L_theme : ‘ L_Law and M_Order ’ .

The L_importance of the L_riots in M_pushing the L_law and M_order L_issue , and L_specifically L_policing , on to the L_main L_political L_agenda was M_emphasized by the L_Liberal L_leader , L_David L_Steel , who L_argued that ‘ L_urgent L_action ’ to L_prevent a M_drift into L_lawlessness was L_necessary from both a L_moral and a L_political M_perspective ( L_Hansard , vol. 13 , 26 L_November 1981 : cols. 1009–11 ) .

A L_subsequent L_debate on the same L_issue in L_March 1982 was L_also M_full of L_references to the L_experience of 1981 , the M_impact of L_street L_violence , L_crime , M_decaying L_urban L_conditions , the M_breakdown of L_consent between the L_police and L_many L_local L_communities , and the M_spectre of ‘ more L_violence to L_come ’ if L_changes in both L_policing M_tactics and L_social L_policy were not M_swiftly L_introduced ( L_Hansard , vol. 20 , 25 L_March 1982 : cols. 1107–81 ) .

The L_need to M_support the L_police was L_accepted by both the L_Labour and the L_Conservative L_speakers in the L_parliamentary L_debate on the L_riots , and was L_established as a L_benchmark for the L_official M_response to the L_riots M_long before the L_Scarman L_Report was L_published in L_November 1981 .
Any L_substantive L_disagreement M_centred around the L_issue of what M_role L_social L_deprivation and L_unemployment had in M_bringing L_young L_people to L_protest L_violently on the L_streets .

L_Intermingled with the L_discourses about L_race and L_law and M_order were M_constant L_references to L_unemployment , L_particularly among the L_young , and L_various M_forms of L_social L_disadvantage and L_poverty ( L_Solomos , 1988 , pp. 186–911 ) .

Throughout 1980 and 1981 L_debates about the L_riots in the L_media , in L_Parliament , and in L_various L_official L_reports M_hinged around the L_interrelationship between L_racial , L_law-and-order , and L_social M_factors .

The L_importance of this L_debate can be L_explained , L_partly , by the L_political M_capital which the L_Opposition could M_make from M_linking the L_social and L_economic M_malaise of the L_country at L_large with L_violent L_street L_disturbances .
L_Conversely , throughout this L_period L_Government L_Ministers L_strenuously L_denied that L_unemployment and L_social L_deprivation were L_significant L_causes of L_urban L_unrest .

Although the L_Scarman L_Report is L_often M_taken to be the M_central L_text which M_argues for a M_link between ‘ L_social L_conditions ’ and ‘ M_disorder ’ , the L_terms of the L_debate were by no L_means M_set by L_Scarman .

During both L_April and L_July 1981 M_vigorous M_exchanges M_took M_place in the L_press and in L_Parliament about the M_role that L_deteriorating L_social L_conditions and L_unemployment may have M_played in L_bringing about the L_riots .

During the 16 L_July L_parliamentary L_debate on ‘ L_Civil L_Disturbances ’ , L_Roy L_Hattersley 's M_formulation of this M_linkage L_provided a L_useful L_summary of the ‘ L_social L_conditions ’ L_argument .

After some L_preliminary L_remarks about the L_Labour L_party 's M_support for the L_police , he L_went on to M_outline his L_opposition to the M_view of the L_riots as L_essentially L_anti-police L_outbursts :
I L_repeat that l do not L_believe that the L_principal L_cause of L_last L_week 's L_riots was the L_conduct of the L_police .

It was the L_conditions of L_deprivation and L_despair in the M_decaying L_areas of our L_old L_cities — L_areas in which the L_Brixton and L_Toxteth L_riots M_took M_place , and L_areas from which the L_skinhead M_invaders of L_Southall L_come .
( L_Hansard , vol. 8 , 16 L_July 1981 : col. 1408 )
L_Much of the L_subsequent L_controversy about this L_analysis M_centred on the L_question of L_youth L_unemployment .

L_Hattersley had L_suggested that the L_riots were a ‘ M_direct M_product ’ of L_high M_levels of L_youth L_unemployment , and a L_furious L_debate L_ensued in both L_Parliament and the L_media about this L_assertion .

The L_final L_symbolic M_cue L_used to M_make M_sense of the 1980–1 L_protests is more L_difficult to L_categorize , but its L_basic L_meaning can be M_captured by the L_term ‘ L_political L_marginality ’ .

While a M_number of L_discussions of the M_roots of L_urban L_unrest in the L_United L_States have M_noted the L_salience of L_political L_marginality in L_determining L_participation in L_violent L_protests ( L_Skolnick , 1969 ; L_Fogelson , 1971 ; L_Edelman , 1971 ; L_Knopf , 1975 ) , this L_issue has M_received L_relatively L_little L_attention in L_Britain .
L_Nevertheless , during the 1980–1 L_events and their L_aftermath the L_political M_context was L_discussed from a M_number of M_perspectives .

The L_Scarman L_Report , for L_example , M_located M_part of the L_explanation for the L_riots in the L_feelings of L_alienation and M_powerlessness which were L_experienced by L_young L_blacks L_living in M_depressed L_inner-city L_areas .

A L_successful L_policy for M_tackling the M_roots of L_urban M_disorder was M_seen as one which M_sought to L_involve all the L_community in L_dealing with the L_problems of each L_area so that they could M_come to M_feel that they have a M_stake in its L_future ( L_Scarman , 1981 , para. 6.42 ) .

Where such L_arguments did not L_fit in with the L_overarching L_themes of L_race , L_violence and M_disorder , and L_social L_deprivation they were L_either M_sidelined or M_pushed into the L_sub-clauses of L_official L_reports .

The L_Scarman L_Report , for L_example , M_contained the L_following L_policy L_proposal : ‘ I L_recommend that L_local L_communities must be L_fully and L_effectively L_involved in M_planning , in the L_provision of L_local L_services , and in the L_management and L_financing of L_specific L_projects , ( L_Scarman , 1981 , para. 8.44 ) .

Such a M_move towards M_greater L_political L_integration was M_seen by L_Lord L_Scarman as L_essential if the M_gap between L_inner-city L_residents and the M_forces of L_law and M_order was to be M_bridged .

But the L_concern with M_overcoming L_political L_marginality M_remained on the M_sidelines of the L_main L_public L_debate because it M_questioned the L_perception of the L_rioters as M_driven by L_irrational , L_uncivilized , and L_criminal L_instincts .

This did not , L_however , M_stop the L_question of L_political L_marginality and the L_need to L_reform L_existing L_policies from being M_raised at all , as can be M_seen L_subsequently by the L_attempts after 1981 to L_introduce both L_locally and L_nationally M_measures which were L_meant to M_address some of the L_grievances of the L_rioters and to L_ensure that further L_disturbances did not L_occur .
M_Aspects of these M_measures are L_considered further on in the L_chapter .
M_PERSPECTIVES ON THE 1985 L_RIOTS

Despite L_widespread L_predictions of further L_unrest in the L_aftermath of 1981 , the M_scale and the L_location of the 1985 L_riots L_seem to have L_surprised L_even some of the most L_astute L_commentators .
L_Handsworth , for L_example , was M_presented L_even L_shortly before L_September 1985 as a ‘ L_success L_story ’ in L_terms of L_police — L_community L_relations .
The L_outbreak of L_violence in this L_area was L_therefore L_widely M_presented as an L_aberration .

L_Similarly the M_spread of L_violence in L_London to L_areas such as the L_Broadwater L_Farm L_Estate in L_Tottenham was M_seen as a M_break from L_previous L_experience , which had M_centred on L_areas such as L_Brixton .
There are L_many M_continuities between 1980–1 and 1985 in L_relation to the L_common-sense M_images L_used in the L_press and L_television to M_cover the L_events .

But M_responses in 1985 were L_different , at L_least in L_terms of M_degree , and L_probably in L_relation to the M_extent to which the L_riots were M_seen as a ‘ L_race ’ L_phenomenon by a M_wider M_body of L_opinion .

The L_ambiguities and L_sub-clauses to be M_found in L_much of the L_press L_coverage during 1980–1 had at L_least M_acted as a L_countervailing L_tendency against the more L_extreme M_forms of L_discourse which M_blamed the L_riots L_completely on L_black L_people .

During the 1985 L_riots and their L_immediate L_aftermath , the M_imagery of ‘ L_race ’ was M_used by M_sections of the L_press without the M_sense of L_ambiguity which could L_still be M_found in 1980–1 .
The ‘ L_silence over L_race ’ was M_breached in 1980–1 , but in 1985 L_debate about L_racial L_issues was M_taken a M_step further .

L_Peregrine L_Worsthorne , for L_example , L_used the L_ferocity of the L_confrontations in L_Handsworth , L_Brixton , and L_Tottenham to L_argue that there was a L_major M_question M_mark over the L_possibility of L_assimilating the ‘ M_coloured L_population ’ into L_mainstream ‘ L_British L_values ’ ( L_Sunday L_Telegraph , 29 L_September 1985 ) .

To be L_sure there was L_still a M_strong M_response L_opposing L_Enoch L_Powell 's M_call for L_repatriation , from all M_shades of L_political L_opinion , but the L_racialization of L_public L_debate about the 1985 L_riots M_went L_much further than 1980–1 .

In this M_context it was the M_externality of L_British L_Afro-Caribbeans and L_Asians which was M_highlighted L_rather the L_racist L_institutions and L_processes which M_worked against L_blacks at all M_levels of L_society .

The L_usage of ‘ L_race ’ during the L_September-October 1985 L_period M_took on L_new L_meanings , which had L_little if L_anything to do with the M_impact of L_racism as such , since the M_emphasis was on the L_cultural L_characteristics of the L_minority L_communities themselves .

After L_Handsworth M_part of the L_press M_response was to L_blame the L_riot on L_rivalry between L_West L_Indians and L_Asians , and L_even after the L_arguments were L_criticized by L_local L_residents ; and L_community L_leaders , they were L_used to ‘ L_explain ’ ' what L_happened .

In L_addition , the L_question whether the L_cultures and L_values of the L_black L_communities , their L_family M_structures , and their L_political M_attitudes ‘ M_bred L_violence ’ was L_constantly M_raised ( L_van L_Dijk , 1988 ) .

The L_actual L_facts ' of who was L_arrested during the L_riots , whether L_black or L_white , were L_hardly L_debated since it was M_assumed that they were L_mostly L_black and L_mostly L_unemployed and L_involved with L_crime ( L_Keith , 1987 ) .

The M_imagery of the ‘ L_black L_bomber , L_used in L_Handsworth was M_extended to the L_notion that there were L_groups of L_alienated and L_criminalized L_young L_blacks who M_saw the L_riots as a L_chance to M_engage in an ‘ M_orgy of L_looting ’ .
The L_Dear L_Report on L_Handsworth M_captures this M_image and M_links it to the L_social L_condition of L_young L_blacks :
The L_majority of L_rioters who M_took L_part in these M_unhappy L_events were L_young , L_black and L_Afro-Caribbean M_origin .

M_Let there be no L_doubt , these L_young L_criminals are not in any M_way L_representative of the M_vast L_majority of the L_Afro-Caribbean L_community whose L_life has M_contributed to the L_life and L_culture of the L_West L_Midlands over L_many L_years and whose L_hopes and L_aspirations are at one with those of every other L_law-abiding L_citizen .
We M_share a L_common M_sorrow .
It is the L_duty of us all to L_ensure that an L_entire L_cultural L_group is not M_tainted by the L_actions of a L_criminal L_minority .
This ‘ L_black ’ L_criminal L_minority was M_constructed not only into the L_leading M_force behind the L_riots , but L_sometimes as the only L_force .
