L_Indeed , throughout L_September and L_October 1985 , and during the L_following L_months , the M_imagery of L_race M_continued to M_dominate L_debate about both the L_causes and the L_policy L_outcomes of the L_riots .

As M_pointed out L_earlier , the ‘ L_social L_causes ’ L_argument was another L_major M_plank of L_public L_debate about the 1980–1 L_riots , L_particularly in L_relation to the L_highly L_politicized L_issue of L_unemployment .
During 1985 this L_issue was M_raised once again , though by then the M_extent of L_mass L_unemployment and L_urban L_de-industrialization and M_decay was more M_stark than it had been in 198l .

M_Images of ‘ L_urban M_decay ’ , ‘ M_tinderbox L_cities ’ , and ‘ M_ghetto L_streets ’ M_linked up with the M_images of ‘ L_race L_inequality ’ and ‘ M_black M_ghettos ’ to M_produce an L_analysis more L_complex but L_also more L_contradictory .

An L_interesting M_mixture of the L_various M_images was L_provided by a L_story in the L_Daily L_Telegraph under the L_headline : ‘ L_Broadwater L_Farm : Like the M_Divis M_Flats with M_Reggae ’ ( 8 L_October 1985 ) .
The L_Mirror M_described the L_estate as ‘ M_Living M_Hell ’ , and M_quoted one L_resident as L_saying that ‘ You 've no L_idea how L_awful L_daily L_life is ’ ( 8 L_October 1985 ) .
Such M_images were L_reworkings of L_arguments L_already L_used about L_Toxteth in 1981 and L_Brixton in 1981 , but they were L_used more L_widely than in 1980–1 .

L_Even the L_Daily L_Mail , which M_deployed the M_clearest M_use of ‘ L_race ’ and ‘ M_outside L_agitator ’ L_arguments , M_ran a L_major L_story on L_Broadwater L_Farm under the L_headline : ‘ M_Burnt-out M_hulks M_litter this L_concrete M_jungle … L_despair M_hangs M_heavy ’ ( 8 L_October 1985 ) .

A M_number of L_stories L_using such M_imagery were M_run by both the L_quality and the L_popular L_press during this L_period , but L_similar L_arguments are to be M_found in L_parliamentary L_debates ( L_Hansard , vol. 84 , 21 L_October 1985 , cols. 30-.46 , 388 ) , and L_even in L_official L_reports L_produced by the L_police on the L_riots in L_Birmingham and L_London .

The ‘ L_cities of M_inner L_despair ’ were M_conceived as the M_breeding M_ground for M_disorderly L_protest , and L_however M_hard the L_Government L_tried to M_break the L_causal M_link between the two , it was M_forced to M_take on M_board the L_need to M_restore M_order not only through the L_police but through L_promises of L_help for the L_inner L_cities .
L_Much as in 1980–1 , the ‘ L_social L_causes ’ L_argument can not be M_seen M_separately from the M_broader L_debate about the L_future of the L_British L_economy and L_society .

The L_Government 's L_record on L_unemployment was a M_heavily L_politicized L_issue , and just as in 1981 it L_vehemently M_denied any L_responsibility for the L_riots through its M_pursuit of M_free-market L_policies .

But the L_Government did M_find a M_way of L_accepting a M_link between the L_riots and L_social L_problems without M_bringing its L_main L_policies into the L_debate : L_namely by M_linking the M_growth of L_violent M_disorder to L_crime and L_drugs .
The M_emphasis on ‘ L_crime ’ and the ‘ L_criminal M_acts ’ of the L_rioters in the L_official M_responses to the 1985 L_riots M_took a L_general and a L_specific M_form .

The L_general M_form M_relied on the L_argument that the L_riots were not a M_form of L_protest against the L_insufferable L_social L_conditions of L_inner-city L_areas or the L_actions of the L_police , but a ‘ L_criminal M_act ’ or a ‘ M_cry for M_loot ’ .

This was an L_argument M_put most L_succinctly by L_Geoffrey L_Dear , L_Chief L_Constable of the L_West L_Midlands ( L_Dear , 1985 ) and by L_Douglas L_Hurd , the L_Home L_Secretary , in L_relation to L_Handsworth .
But it L_recurred as a L_theme in L_official and L_press M_responses to the other L_riots .

The L_specific M_form was M_built upon the L_notion that the L_outbreak of L_violence in L_Handsworth and L_Brixton , in L_particular , was L_brought about by ‘ L_drug L_barons ’ who M_saw the L_police L_attempting to L_curb their L_activities and L_control ‘ their L_territory ’ .
L_Numerous L_examples of this M_line of L_argument can be M_found in L_Dear 's L_report on L_Handsworth , and in L_press L_coverage during the L_riots .
M_Taking the L_specific L_argument about the M_role of L_drugs and ‘ L_drug L_barons ’ in L_stimulating the L_riots , this L_seems to have M_served two L_purposes .

L_First , it M_distanced the L_riots from the L_social , L_economic , L_political , and other M_grievances which had been M_linked to them by M_locating the L_cause outside the ‘ L_social L_problems ’ of L_inner-city L_dwellers and in the ‘ L_simple L_greed ’ of the L_drug M_barons to L_accumulate ‘ M_loot ’ .

L_Second , just as L_Dear 's M_image of a few hundred ‘ L_young L_black L_criminals ’ was L_used to L_explain what L_happened in L_Handsworth , the L_problem of L_drugs was L_used to L_explain what L_happened at a L_national M_level .

The L_issue of L_drugs L_provided an L_everyday M_image , L_already a L_national L_issue through M_saturation L_media L_coverage and L_public L_debate , around which the L_police , the L_Home L_Office , and other L_institutions could M_depoliticize the L_riots .

L_Responding to the L_Handsworth L_events L_Douglas L_Hurd was M_moved to L_argue M_forcibly that such L_events were M_senseless and M_reflected more on those who L_participated in them than on the L_society in which they M_took M_place : ‘ The L_sound which L_law L_abiding L_people in L_Handsworth L_heard on L_Monday L_night , the M_echoes of which I M_picked up on L_Tuesday , was not a M_cry for L_help but a M_cry for M_loot ’ ( L_Financial L_Times , 13 L_September 1985 ) .

The L_Chief L_Constable for the L_West L_Midlands , L_Geoffrey L_Dear , M_took this L_argument further by M_pointing out that the L_day before the L_riots a L_successful L_carnival had M_taken M_place , with the M_support of L_local L_community L_leaders .
He M_drew the L_conclusion from this that the L_riot ‘ M_came like a M_bolt out of the M_blue ’ ( L_Guardian , 21 L_November 1985 ) .

Such L_language M_focused L_attention on the L_individuals or L_groups who were ‘ M_breaking the L_law ’ , ‘ M_committing L_criminal L_acts ’ , and M_threatening the L_interests of the L_law-abiding ‘ L_majority ’ .
L_Potential M_Applications
L_Overview
L_Ian L_Masser

L_Given the M_extent to which L_geographic L_information L_management is M_applications L_driven , it is L_important to M_consider in some M_depth the L_characteristics of some L_potential M_application M_fields .

In the L_process it will be L_necessary to M_examine not only the M_extent to which L_geographic L_issues L_feature on the L_policy L_issues L_agenda in these M_fields but L_also the L_institutional M_context which M_governs L_decision-making and the M_extent to which L_data are L_available for L_research and L_policy L_analysis L_purposes .
M_Questions on L_data L_availability are L_likely to be L_particularly L_important where L_users are M_heavily L_dependent on L_secondary M_sources .
In M_situations of this L_kind M_provisions M_governing M_access and M_format may M_exert M_powerful L_constraints on the L_use that can be M_made of these L_data .
The L_first four L_chapters in this M_part M_examine L_issues L_relating to L_geographic L_information M_handling in L_terms of four L_potential M_applications M_fields .

The L_authors were L_asked to L_review the L_current M_state of the M_art in their M_fields with L_particular L_reference to the L_likely L_requirements of the L_future L_policy L_issues L_agenda in L_terms of the L_demands that they M_make on L_geographic L_information L_management .

L_Authors were L_also L_asked to L_evaluate L_critically the M_state of L_geographic L_information L_provision in L_terms of the L_needs of L_users and to M_consider the M_impact of L_user L_requirements on the L_development of L_geographic L_information M_handling L_methodology .
In this M_way the L_chapters in this M_part M_present a L_number of M_perspectives which L_essentially L_complement and M_amplify the M_discussion in the L_previous M_part .

In this L_case , L_however , L_methodological L_issues are M_tackled from a L_largely L_user L_standpoint , whereas in the L_previous M_part they were M_viewed as L_substantive L_problems in their own L_right .
In L_effect the M_product of the M_discussion in both M_parts is a M_matrix where the L_methodological L_issues are M_listed along one M_axis and L_particular M_applications M_fields on the other .
L_Figure 8.1 M_summarizes the L_main M_features of this L_matrix .

There are L_important L_differences between the L_chapters in this M_part both in the M_nature of the L_demands that they M_make on L_geographic L_information and L_also in the L_relative L_importance that is M_attached to L_geographic L_criteria as against other L_issues by L_planners and L_decision-makers in these M_fields .

The L_first three L_chapters M_dealing with L_environmental L_monitoring , L_natural and L_technological L_hazards and L_settlements and L_infrastructure M_applications M_make L_use of a very M_wide M_range of L_geographic L_information .
A L_major M_feature of these M_applications is the M_extent to which they L_involve M_overlays of a L_variety of L_information M_drawn from L_different M_sources on a L_topographic L_map M_base .

for this L_reason they M_make L_particularly M_heavy L_demands on L_current L_GIS L_technology both because of the M_size of the L_data L_sets and the L_diversity of the L_data M_structures that are L_involved .

L_Brown 's L_chapter on L_geodemographics M_discusses an M_application M_field where L_primary L_data M_collected for L_operational L_purposes are L_typically L_evaluated in L_relation to L_secondary L_data M_derived from M_sources such as the L_Census of L_Population .

The M_range of L_data L_sets L_involved and the L_demands that are M_made on L_GIS L_technology in M_applications of this L_kind are L_often more L_limited than those of L_previous M_applications M_fields .
L_However , this is L_offset by the L_demands that are M_made on L_spatial L_analysis and M_modelling L_methodology .

L_Rhind 's L_chapter on L_environmental L_monitoring and L_prediction M_discusses the M_role of L_geographic L_information L_management in L_promoting L_sustainable L_development on a L_global M_scale in the M_context of the L_issues M_identified in the L_Brundtland L_report .
It M_points to the M_impact that the L_findings of L_global L_environmental L_research are L_likely to have on most M_sectors of the L_UK L_economy .

This M_contribution L_also M_indicates the M_wide L_variety of L_groups that are L_involved in L_monitoring L_environmental M_change and M_draws L_attention to the M_role that the L_European L_Community is L_increasingly M_playing in M_co-ordinating these L_efforts .
One of the L_examples of L_work in M_progress M_discusses L_research that has been L_carried out for the L_European L_Commission as M_part of the L_CORINE L_Project .

This M_highlights the M_challenges for L_research in a M_field L_categorized by a L_lack of L_data for some L_countries , L_varying L_definitions and M_standards in L_use , and L_unreasonably M_high L_user L_expectations .
The L_chapter as a L_whole M_draws L_attention to a L_number of L_key L_methodological L_issues that are L_involved in L_environmental L_monitoring and L_prediction .

These M_include the L_highly L_specialized M_nature of L_much of the L_technical L_analysis , the L_limited M_capacity for L_checking the L_accuracy of L_many of the L_findings of this L_kind of L_research and the L_consequent L_need for the L_development of M_knowledge-based L_inference L_machines for M_extracting L_useful L_information from L_secondary and L_often L_proxy L_data .

In L_Chapter 10 L_Gatrell and L_Vincent L_consider a L_wide L_range of L_natural and L_technological L_hazards L_including L_industrial L_hazards , L_risk L_assessment , L_hazardous L_waste L_disposal , L_emergency L_planning , L_natural L_hazards and L_environmental L_epidemiology .
The L_substantive L_content of L_much of this L_research L_straddles the L_social , L_environmental and L_mathematical L_sciences .

To L_model the L_dispersal of a L_plume of L_toxic L_gas L_generated by a L_chemical L_explosion and its L_impact on the L_surrounding L_area , for L_example , an L_understanding of L_atmospheric L_dispersion L_models , L_epidemiology and L_population L_distribution would be L_required .

In L_applications of this L_kind the L_authors L_argue that L_geographic L_information L_management in L_general and L_GIS in L_particular have an L_important L_role to L_play and they L_give a L_number of L_examples from L_research in L_progress to L_illustrate the L_current L_state of the L_art in this L_field .

The L_discussion of L_operational L_problems and L_prospects further L_amplifies L_many of the L_issues L_raised in L_preceding L_chapters , L_particularly with L_respect to the L_problems L_caused by the L_dependency on L_secondary L_data L_sources and the L_need for L_much more L_detailed L_geographic L_information to L_overcome some of the L_problems L_associated with L_linking L_data L_sets .

Like most of the other L_contributors to this L_section , L_Gatrell and L_Vincent L_see L_decision L_support L_systems as a L_major L_area for L_future L_development in the L_geographic L_information L_management L_field .

L_Given that ‘ most L_GIS are L_rather L_dumb L_systems , L_requiring L_intelligent , very L_computer L_literate L_users ’ , L_managing L_natural and L_technological L_hazards L_means that this L_knowledge L_base must be L_built into the L_system so that it can be L_utilized L_quickly by L_untrained L_users after a L_disaster has L_taken L_place or in an L_emergency .
The L_settlement and L_infrastructure L_field is L_also L_characterized by a L_wide L_range of L_users with a L_great L_diversity of L_interests .
These L_include not only L_central and L_local L_government but L_also L_major L_utility L_companies and L_transport L_suppliers .

L_According to L_Shepherd these L_users L_share a L_common L_need for L_up-to-date L_information on the L_amount , L_capacity and L_condition of L_urban L_land , L_transport L_networks , L_utilities , L_hospitals , L_schools and other L_major L_communal L_facilities .

In L_addition to these L_data L_requirements , such L_users are L_also L_interested in L_developing their L_capabilities for L_modelling the L_changing L_relationships between the L_supply and L_demand for L_infrastructure in the L_context of both L_public and L_private L_sector L_decision-making .

L_Shepherd , more than any other L_contributor to this L_section , L_draws L_attention to the L_extent to which L_current L_efforts in the L_geographic L_information L_management L_field are L_constrained by the L_highly L_fragmented L_nature of both L_data L_suppliers and L_users both in L_sectoral and L_spatial L_terms , the L_great L_diversity of L_data L_sets in L_varying L_formats and the L_difficulties L_presented by L_institutional L_factors such as L_copyright L_provision , L_data L_ownership and the L_control of L_access to L_data .

L_Digital L_data L_occupy a L_central L_position in this L_applications L_field and a L_number of L_examples are L_given to L_illustrate the L_extent to which their L_development has been L_hampered or L_facilitated in L_various L_countries by the L_policies of the L_organizations with L_responsibility for L_digital L_data L_provision .
In L_Chapter 12 L_Brown L_reviews the L_development of L_geodemographics from its L_origins in the L_computer-based L_social L_area L_analysis of L_US L_census L_tract L_data from 1950 L_onwards .

He L_describes the L_features of the four L_main L_systems that are L_currently in L_use in the L_UK and L_illustrates their L_application with L_reference to L_examples L_drawn from L_retail L_analysis and L_store L_location , L_market L_research , L_credit L_rating and L_target L_marketing .

L_Brown L_demonstrates the L_extent to which the L_growth of L_research L_activities in this L_field has L_led to the L_emergence of L_improved L_cluster L_analytic L_methods for the L_multidimensional L_classification of L_people L_according to the L_type of L_area in which they L_live .
In the L_last L_part of this L_contribution , L_Brown L_identifies a L_number of L_priorities for L_future L_research .

Like L_Gatrell and L_Vincent and L_Shepherd before him , he is L_concerned with the L_lack of L_detailed L_geographical L_information L_particularly in this L_case with L_reference to the L_years between L_censuses .
L_Spatial L_linkages L_also L_feature L_prominently in L_Brown 's L_discussion which L_amplifies L_many of the L_points L_made in the L_earlier L_contribution from L_Openshaw in L_Chapter 3 .
The L_analysis L_points to the L_need for the L_development of a L_fuzzy L_geodemographics L_methodology which L_takes L_account of the L_effects of L_different L_types of L_spatial L_errors .

Other L_major L_research L_priorities for the L_future in this L_applications L_field are the L_development of L_response-modelling L_techniques to L_explore the L_factors L_affecting L_consumer L_choice .
This is L_particularly L_important in a L_field where L_many of the L_demands L_made by L_users are L_highly L_specialized in L_nature .

In L_summary , then , as fig. 8.1 L_shows , L_many of the L_issues L_raised by this L_review of L_geographic L_information L_handling in the four L_potential L_application L_fields are L_essentially L_complementary to those L_discussed in the L_part on L_methodological L_developments .
L_Spatial L_analysis L_features L_particularly L_prominent on the L_research L_agenda L_relating to L_natural and L_technological L_hazards and L_geodemographics .
L_Questions L_relating to L_data L_integration L_emerge as being L_particularly L_critical in L_terms of L_environmental L_monitoring and L_settlement and L_infrastructure L_applications .
L_Spatial L_linkages and L_questions L_relating to L_spatial L_representation L_feature L_prominently in the L_settlements and L_infrastructure and L_geodemographics L_fields .
The L_evaluation of L_error L_propagation is a L_matter of L_considerable L_significance in the L_environmental L_monitoring and L_settlements and L_infrastructure L_fields .
L_Finally , in all L_applications L_fields , the L_findings of the L_reviews above L_suggest that there is a L_need for L_improvements in L_user L_interfaces of all L_kinds .
This is L_particularly L_evident in the L_demand for the L_development of L_knowledge-based L_decision L_support L_systems and L_modelling L_capabilities .

Such L_demands L_highlight the L_extent to which L_geographic L_information L_management must be L_regarded as a L_means to an L_end L_rather than an L_end in itself when L_viewed from the L_standpoints of the L_needs of L_planners and L_decision-makers .

The L_final L_chapter in this L_section L_rounds off the L_discussion of L_applications-related L_research with an L_examination of L_organizational L_issues that L_need to be L_taken L_account of in L_handling L_geographic L_information .
L_Campbell L_presents a L_conceptual L_framework for the L_analysis of the L_organizational L_issues L_involved in the L_development and L_implementation of L_GIS .

This L_contribution L_cuts L_across L_many of the L_questions L_relating to L_particular L_applications that were L_raised in L_preceding L_chapters and L_draws L_attention to the L_dangers of L_neglecting L_institutional and L_personal L_considerations in L_practice .

All too L_often , as the L_experience of L_many L_mature L_applications L_indicates , L_technical and L_data-related L_matters L_dominate the L_system L_development L_phase and L_technically L_elegant L_solutions are L_devised which L_fail to L_take L_enough L_account of L_user L_needs and L_capabilities .
L_Campbell L_discusses the L_role of L_geographic L_information in L_organizations and the L_process of GIS diffusion L_drawing upon L_research from a L_variety of L_social L_science L_disciplines .
The L_findings of the L_analysis are L_summarized in two L_sets of L_research L_questions for all L_applications L_fields .

In this L_way she L_sets out a L_research L_agenda for L_applications-related L_research which L_serves a L_similar L_function to the L_spatial L_analysis L_research L_agenda L_set out by L_Openshaw at the L_beginning of L_Part Two .
L_Environmental L_monitoring and L_prediction
L_David L_Rhind
L_Introduction
L_Monitoring of the L_state of and the L_changes in the L_environment is now L_universally L_recognized as being of L_profound L_importance to L_mankind ( L_Tickell 1986 , 1989 ) .

This L_awareness is most L_obviously L_manifested by the L_frequent L_appearance of L_press L_reports on L_ozone L_depletion , on the L_greenhouse L_effect and L_possible L_global L_warming , on L_nitrate L_pollution , on L_deforestation in the L_Tropics , on L_decreasing L_biological L_diversity and on L_many other L_environmentally L_related L_topics .
L_Usually these L_reports L_concentrate on L_prophecies of a L_forthcoming L_Armageddon but L_many L_also L_describe a L_dire L_contemporary L_situation .

L_Thus the L_algal L_bloom off the L_Italian L_Adriatic L_shore in 1989 is L_reckoned to have L_caused the L_holiday L_trade and L_local L_fisherman L_losses L_running into L_tens if not L_hundreds of L_millions of L_pounds .
More L_globally , the L_Brundtland L_Report ( L_WCED 1987 ) L_noted that , in the 900 L_days during which the L_World L_Commission was at L_work ,
The L_African L_drought L_put the L_lives of 35 million L_people at L_risk and may have L_killed 1 million of them ;
The L_Bhopal L_accident L_killed 2000 and L_injured 200 000 more ;
The L_Chernobyl L_disaster L_caused L_environmental L_damage across L_Europe ;
A L_chemical L_fire in L_Switzerland L_caused L_toxic L_materials to be L_transported by the L_Rhine at L_least as L_far as the L_Netherlands ;
At L_least 60 million L_people L_died of L_diarrhoeal L_diseases L_caused by L_malnutrition and L_dirty L_water .

As a L_consequence of these and other L_disasters , of L_rapid and L_world-wide L_broadcasting of them and of the L_concerned L_action of L_many L_individuals , the L_environment is now ‘ L_moving L_fast up the L_political L_agenda ’ ( L_Patten 1989 ) .

The then L_Prime L_Minister L_also L_emphasized the L_political L_awakening to the L_environment in L_statements such as : ‘ it is L_possible that with all these L_enormous L_changes ( L_population , L_agricultural , L_use of L_fossil L_fuels ) L_concentrated into such a L_short L_period of L_time , we have L_unwittingly L_begun a L_massive L_experiment with the L_system of this L_planet itself ’ ( L_Thatcher 1988 ) .
The L_political L_concern is not L_altruistic .

L_Mrs L_Thatcher , a L_recent L_convert to L_environmental L_conservation , L_clearly L_held the L_opinion that L_environmental L_problems are not only L_soluble but that L_solving them can be L_shown to be L_cost-effective :
In the L_past when we L_identified L_forms of L_pollution , we have L_shown our L_capacity to L_act L_effectively .
The L_great L_London L_smogs are now only a L_nightmare of the L_past .
We have L_cut L_airborne L_lead by 50 per L_cent .
We are L_spending £4 billion on L_cleansing the L_Mersey L_Basin L_alone , and the L_Thames now has the L_cleanest L_metropolitan L_estuary in the L_world .

L_Even though this L_kind of L_action may L_cost a L_lot , I L_believe it to be L_money L_well and L_necessarily L_spent because the L_health of our L_economy and the L_health of our L_environment are L_totally L_dependent upon each other … .
The L_Government L_espouses the L_concept of L_sustainable L_economic L_development .
L_Stable L_prosperity can be L_achieved throughout the L_world L_provided the L_environment is L_nurtured and L_safeguarded ( L_Thatcher 1988 ) .
The L_primary L_official L_manifestation of this L_UK L_commitment to the L_environment has been the L_government 's L_White L_Paper ( L_HMSO 1990 ) .

While L_criticized by L_many on the L_grounds that it had few ‘ L_teeth ’ and L_represented a L_compromise between the L_DoE and all other L_departments ( L_notably those of L_Agriculture and of L_Transport ) , it was L_none the L_less a L_major L_achievement .

Its L_main L_sections L_dealt with the L_government 's L_approach to the L_environment ( L_nationally , at the L_European L_level and L_globally ) , the L_nature and L_effects of the L_greenhouse L_effect , L_environmental L_problems in both L_rural and L_urban L_areas ( L_especially in L_relation to L_land-use L_matters ) , L_pollution L_control and L_enhancing L_awareness of L_environmental L_matters .
L_Central to this L_approach is L_said to be an L_emphasis upon L_guidance from the L_best L_available L_scientific L_evidence .
There is L_also a L_clear L_recognition of the L_need for L_monitoring and L_modelling of the L_state of the L_natural and L_man-influenced L_environment .

Though there has been a L_change of L_Prime L_Minister and of the L_Secretary of L_State for the L_Environment since the L_publication of the L_White L_Paper , the L_environmental L_cause L_seems as L_strong as L_ever .

L_Thus , The L_Times of 17 L_December 1990 L_reported that a L_group of 40 of the most L_senior L_Civil L_Servants had L_met the L_previous L_weekend to L_discuss ‘ L_ways in which the L_government L_machine could L_respond L_better to L_national and L_international L_problems such as the L_threat of L_global L_climate L_change ’ .

L_Pearce et al. ( 1989 ) have L_argued that the L_effects of L_government , L_commercial and other L_actions on the L_environment can and should be L_assessed on a cost/benefit L_basis and this L_seems L_likely to be the L_basis on which at L_least the L_UK L_government will L_proceed .

L_Given such a L_lead , it is L_scarcely L_surprising that L_British L_scientists have L_sought to L_demonstrate the L_practical and L_financial L_consequences of L_environmental L_events and L_processes ; L_Table 9.1 , for L_example L_illustrates their L_perception of the L_importance of L_global L_environmental L_research to the L_UK L_domestic L_economy .

If it now L_seems L_self-evident that L_monitoring of the L_global L_environment is L_necessary , L_indeed is L_even L_vital , the L_prediction of what is L_likely to L_happen is L_almost as L_important : the 170 000 L_people in the L_Maldives are L_understandably L_worried about the L_prospect of L_global L_sea-level L_change since no L_part of the L_islands is more than 2 m above L_present L_sea-level !

L_Yet , as we shall L_see below , the L_prediction of the L_activities of L_natural and L_man-influenced L_environmental L_systems L_requires an L_understanding of the L_interaction of L_processes that , in L_many L_cases , we L_simply do not L_yet have .
L_Even L_monitoring of the L_present is very L_imperfect , as L_witness the L_order of L_magnitude L_variations in L_estimates now L_current for L_deforestation L_rates .

This L_chapter , then , L_attempts to L_review some of the L_problems in L_environmental L_monitoring and L_prediction , L_describes some of the L_relevant L_scientific and L_organizational L_activities and L_looks L_ahead to what is L_likely to L_happen L_next .
The L_nature of L_environmental L_processes

Notwithstanding L_Mrs L_Thatcher 's L_confidence that we can ‘ L_fix ’ L_environmental L_problems , the L_difficulties L_associated with a L_task L_even as L_apparently L_simple as L_monitoring a L_state L_variable are L_considerable .

Some of the L_reasons for this — the L_difficulty of L_deciding on L_appropriate L_proxy L_variables and on L_economical yet L_non-biasing L_temporal and L_spatial L_sampling L_frameworks , L_taking L_account of the L_relative L_importance of L_aperiodic and L_rare L_events as L_compared to L_near-continuous L_processes , L_processing the L_vast L_volumes of L_data L_usually L_involved and L_organizing the L_multidisciplinary and ( L_often ) L_multinational L_researchers L_involved — are L_discussed L_briefly L_later .
L_Even at this L_stage , L_however , it is L_important to L_stress that we have a very L_incomplete L_understanding of L_many L_processes in the L_natural L_environment .
The L_next L_section L_therefore L_attempts to L_summarize what we do L_know ; it is L_derived L_chiefly from the L_Earth L_System L_Sciences L_Committee ( L_ESSC ) ( 1988 ) .
L_Temporal and L_spatial L_scales of L_operation
L_Even L_ignoring the L_effects of L_man , L_earth L_system L_processes L_operate at a L_variety of L_spatial and L_temporal L_scales ( L_see Fig. 9.1 ; L_see L_also L_Rosswall et al. 1988 ) .

L_Thus L_microclimate L_effects can have L_major L_short-term L_implications for L_local L_populations ( such as those L_brought about by the L_photochemical L_smogs of L_Los L_Angeles ) , are L_often L_applicable only over L_areas of a few L_hectares or L_less and may L_operate on a L_diurnal L_cycle .
In L_contrast , L_soil L_creation ( cf. L_soil L_degradation ) may L_require L_hundreds or L_thousands of L_years .
In between are L_variations in L_phenomena such as L_El L_Nino .
The L_sampling L_theorem L_indicates that we must L_sample these L_phenomena at a L_frequency of no L_less than half their L_wavelength if we are to L_avoid L_bias in L_measurement .
In this L_chapter , the L_primary L_concern is with L_changes L_occurring over L_time L_spans from L_minutes to L_centuries and from L_spatial L_wavelengths from about 1 m to about 100 L_km .

It is , L_however , L_impossible to L_separate out L_processes L_acting at L_different L_scales and over L_different L_periods : a L_single L_volcanic L_eruption L_lasting L_hours or L_days L_sometimes L_leads to L_dust and L_gas being L_ejected into the L_atmosphere over a L_period of L_months and this in L_turn may L_lead to L_global L_climatic L_fluctuations over L_years or L_decades .

L_Conversely , a L_large-scale and L_long-period L_phenomenon such as the L_movement of L_tectonic L_plates can L_lead to L_local L_stress L_accumulation and to its L_release by an L_earthquake in a few L_seconds and with L_highly L_local L_effects .
This L_therefore has the L_following L_consequences :
We should L_know L_something about the L_periodicity of the L_variables we are L_monitoring if we are not to L_risk either L_unnecessarily L_detailed L_data L_collection or L_aliasing of L_trends ;

Since we L_know that the L_periodicity of some L_variables is L_longer than the L_monitoring L_already L_carried out by L_human beings , we must L_make L_use of L_surrogate or L_proxy L_variables to L_extend our L_range of L_knowledge ( such as via L_tree L_rings , L_palynology , L_oxygen L_isotope L_ratios from L_ice L_cores and L_geomorphological L_evidence of L_environmental L_change ) ;

Since we are not L_yet L_able to L_predict all the L_interactions which may be L_important in a L_study of L_environmental L_problems , L_collecting L_potentially L_useful L_data as L_well as those L_believed L_central to the L_problem under L_study is L_often L_wise ;
We must L_accept that most L_data L_collection L_exercises will L_inevitably be a L_compromise on the L_grounds of L_cost and L_hence L_less than L_perfect L_data L_sets will be L_produced ;

L_Irrespective of the L_use of L_surrogates , L_monitoring L_environmental L_processes only L_makes L_sense over L_time-scales which are L_extended by L_human L_standards ( L_hence the L_IGBP ( L_see below ) is L_designed to L_run for two or three L_decades ) ;
L_Changes in L_political L_priorities may L_simply L_result in the L_need for L_informed L_guesswork if L_suitable L_data are not L_available .
L_Much L_attention will be L_given throughout this L_chapter to L_monitoring the L_environment on a L_global L_basis .
This is not L_merely because of its L_topical L_nature .

The L_main L_reason is that — though some L_problems are L_local and are L_best L_studied that L_way — L_many L_others ( L_even L_involving a L_limited L_geographical L_extent ) are L_best L_understood within a L_global L_framework .
L_Thus no L_meteorologist would L_attempt to L_forecast the L_weather 2 or 3 L_days L_ahead without L_using a L_mathematical L_model L_based on L_observations from all around the L_world .

L_Moreover , L_recent L_work has L_shown that L_much of the L_heat L_energy in the L_seas of the L_North L_Atlantic ( every L_square L_kilometre of which L_gives off as L_much L_energy as a L_nuclear L_power L_station and L_hence L_influences our L_weather ) is L_absorbed from L_sunlight in the L_tropical L_Pacific and is L_carried by L_ocean L_currents through the L_Drake L_Passage and up into the L_Atlantic .

L_Thus , to L_understand some L_local and L_many L_regional , L_national and L_continental and all L_global L_environmental L_events , we L_need to have a L_global L_perspective and L_hold L_global L_databases ( L_Rhind and L_Mounsey 1989 ; L_Mounsey and L_Tomlinson 1988 ) .

In no L_way , L_however , does this L_invalidate the L_need for L_microscale L_studies — for L_instance , while L_global L_data L_sets may L_indicate the L_extent of L_algal L_blooms and may L_suggest L_causes of them , only L_detailed L_study of the L_algae themselves can L_provide L_understanding of why the L_bloom is L_occurring .
The L_processes themselves
A L_major L_complication , L_however , is that the L_environment can L_rarely be L_treated as in a L_laboratory L_experiment .
L_Given this , L_determining the L_nature of the L_interactions between the L_variables L_becomes a L_matter of L_major L_difficulty .

L_Figure 9.2 is L_taken from L_ESSC ( 1988 ) and is an L_attempt to L_show the L_interactions between L_environmental L_processes , as L_well as the L_indicators and L_implications of L_change in the L_state of the L_environment .

In L_essence , the L_figure can be L_summarized as L_showing L_processes within the L_physical L_climate L_system and within the L_biogeochemical one , these L_systems being L_interwoven by the L_global L_role of L_water and L_increasingly L_affected by L_human L_activities .

The L_main L_components of the L_first L_system are L_well L_known : the L_atmosphere is its L_engine and L_atmospheric L_circulation is L_driven by L_differences in L_solar L_heating between the L_equatorial and L_polar L_regions .
We are , L_however , L_becoming L_ever more L_aware of the L_massive L_influence of L_oceans on our L_climate ; L_research into ocean/atmosphere L_interactions is now a L_priority .
In L_ocean L_dynamics L_studies , L_important L_topics are L_heat L_storage , L_circulation and the L_role of L_sea L_ice .

L_Atmospheric L_circulation ( and , in L_turn , L_precipitation and L_temperature ) is L_also L_greatly L_affected by the L_balance of L_thermal L_energy at the L_land L_surface , itself L_affected by the L_vegetation and L_terrain L_characteristics .

The L_biogeochemical L_system L_embraces the L_totality of the L_movements of the L_key L_elements L_essential to L_life — L_carbon , L_nitrogen , L_oxygen , L_phosphorus and L_others — through what has been L_described as the L_total L_earth L_system .
The L_oceans and their L_biota L_play a L_central L_role in the L_carbon and L_nutrient L_cycles ; L_global L_ocean L_circulation is L_also L_critical to the L_global L_carbon L_budget .

L_Trace L_gases in the L_atmosphere are L_key L_components of the L_cycles of such L_elements as L_carbon , L_nitrogen , L_oxygen , L_sulphur and the L_halogens ; as is now L_well L_known , their L_concentrations are L_much L_influenced by L_biogenic and L_anthropogenic L_activities and the L_concentrations of such L_gases as L_carbon L_dioxide , L_ozone , L_methane , L_nitrous L_oxide and the L_chlorofluoromethanes ( L_CFMs ) L_strongly L_affect L_radiative L_transfer and L_provide a L_link with the L_physical L_climate L_system .

A L_particular L_cause for L_concern is that the L_concentrations of the two L_main L_CFMs is L_increasing by about 5 per L_cent per L_annum while the L_equivalent L_figures for L_methane , L_nitrous L_oxide and L_carbon L_dioxide are 1 , 0.4 and 0.3 per L_cent .
L_Finally , the L_chemistry of the L_stratosphere is L_dominated by the L_photochemical L_production and L_catalytic L_destruction of L_ozone .
There are L_several L_important L_ways in which L_biogeochemical L_processes can L_influence L_climate and L_hence L_habitability ( except where the L_latter is L_maintained at L_enormous L_cost ) .

If , for L_instance , the L_concentrations of L_certain L_trace L_gases ( L_see above ) L_continue to L_increase , it has been L_predicted that the L_earth 's L_surface L_temperature will L_increase by an L_amount L_comparable to that since the L_last L_major L_phase of the most L_recent L_glaciation ( about 18 000 L_years L_BP ) — though there is some L_dispute about the L_magnitude of the L_likely L_change .

The L_converse L_case — the L_effect of L_physical L_climate L_changes on L_biogeochemical L_processes — is L_also of L_obvious L_importance : L_changes in L_annual L_averages and L_cycles of L_temperature and L_precipitation , L_together with the L_probabilities of L_extreme L_events such as L_prolonged L_droughts or L_frosts , are L_major L_determinants of L_terrestrial L_ecosystem L_type , at L_least in L_areas L_largely L_unaffected by L_human L_activity .
L_Human-induced L_changes to the L_environment have L_increased L_rapidly as a L_consequence of L_growing L_population L_numbers and of L_numerous L_developments in L_technology .

L_fossil L_fuel L_combustion , for L_instance , has L_led to L_increased L_concentrations of L_sulphate in L_precipitation ( ’ L_acid L_rain' ) and L_many L_rivers , L_lakes and L_estuaries have been L_greatly L_affected by L_phosphates from L_agricultural , L_urban or L_industrial L_sources .

It should be L_stressed , L_however , that — while the L_outlines of L_human L_activities are L_clear — there are L_still L_many L_uncertainties : for L_instance , we L_know that the L_atmospheric L_concentration of L_carbon L_dioxide has L_risen about 9 per L_cent since 1959 .

But L_calculations of the L_total L_carbon L_released by L_fossil L_fuel L_combustion L_imply that , if all such L_carbon L_remained in the L_atmosphere , the L_concentration would have L_increased by L_twice as L_much .

The L_absolute L_difference between the two L_figures L_seems to be L_due to two L_different L_factors : L_absorption by the L_oceans and other L_reductions in L_carbon L_stocks in L_living L_biota , the L_latter being L_strongly L_affected by L_human L_activities since the L_Industrial L_Revolution .
Does L_God L_play L_dice ?
L_Much L_environmental L_prediction is L_predicated upon a L_logical L_positivist or L_Newtonian L_deterministic L_basis .

The L_environmental L_systems are L_effectively L_regarded as L_machines whose L_workings can all be L_discovered , L_described in L_differential L_equation L_form and whose L_future L_activities can L_thus be L_predicted in L_detail if their L_initial L_states are L_known .

An L_argument by L_many L_atmospheric L_physicists , for L_example , is that L_shortcomings in the L_accuracy of L_weather L_prediction over L_periods of more than a few L_days L_largely L_results from the L_unsophisticated L_nature of L_existing L_models , the L_lack of L_suitable L_data and L_inadequate L_computer L_power ( L_see Fig. 9.3 , L_derived from L_Tyler 1989 ) .

In L_contrast , the L_advocates of L_chaos L_theory ( e.g. L_Stewart 1989 ) L_argue that some L_natural L_systems are so L_sensitive to L_tiny L_stimuli that L_even ‘ the L_faint L_beat of a L_butterfly 's L_wing could be the L_ultimate L_trigger for a L_hurricane ’ .

In L_essence , they L_argue that L_tiny L_differences in the L_initial L_conditions of L_many L_systems can L_lead to L_widely L_different L_outcomes since the L_systems L_exhibit L_stochastic L_behaviour within a L_deterministic L_framework .
If so , there is L_little L_chance of L_making L_accurate L_long-term L_forecasts of these L_systems .
This has been L_recognized by , among L_others , L_ESSC ( 1988 ) .

The L_authors of that L_report L_accepted that there is a L_theoretical L_limit of 2–3 L_weeks in L_explicit L_prediction of L_day-to-day L_fluctuations in L_weather because of the L_influence of L_small-scale L_turbulence within the L_large-scale L_dynamics ; such L_limits L_imply that L_medium and L_long-term L_prediction must L_inevitably be L_stochastic .

To L_complicate L_matters L_still further , L_however , it L_seems at L_least L_possible that the L_components of the L_earth L_system may L_best be L_predicted L_deterministically at some L_spatial and L_temporal L_scales but L_stochastically at L_others and that the L_basis of L_prediction will L_differ for L_different L_components .

As an L_example , L_atmospheric L_temperature L_shows L_marked L_day-to-day L_variability , a L_strong L_seasonal L_cycle with some L_year-to-year L_variations , a L_weak L_minimum L_variability for 10–20 L_year L_averages and then L_increased L_variation again at L_longer L_time-scales ( L_ESSC 1988 ) .
It need L_hardly be L_pointed out that L_coping with such L_multiple L_databases on which L_modelling is to be L_carried out is not a L_trivial L_exercise .

L_Finally , it is L_perhaps L_worth L_concluding this L_section by L_emphasizing that there is L_still L_much L_controversy among the L_scientific L_community about the L_magnitude of L_many of the L_effects being L_discussed .

In L_general , the L_research L_work of the L_international L_groups of L_scientists , L_including those L_involved in the L_Inter-Governmental L_Committee and in the L_UK 's L_Inter-Agency L_Committee on L_Global L_Environmental L_Change , has L_progressively L_reduced the L_magnitude of the L_predicted L_effects of , for L_example , L_global L_warming .

In L_giving the 1990 L_Robens L_Coal L_Science L_Lecture at the L_Royal L_Institution , L_Sir L_John L_Mason ( a L_former L_Director of the L_Meteorological L_Office ) L_urged L_caution in L_interpreting the L_results of the L_massive L_atmospheric and L_oceanic L_modelling L_exercises ; as the L_equilibrium L_models are L_refined to L_take L_account of the L_thermal L_lag in L_oceans , etc. , L_lower L_values of L_predicted L_changes are L_likely .

L_Thus , while L_almost all L_scientists are — at the L_time of L_writing — L_convinced from the L_evidence that L_change in L_climate is under L_way and that L_regional L_effects may be L_much L_greater than the L_global L_average , the L_magnitude of the L_latter is now L_thought L_likely to be about L_half of what was L_predicted only 5 L_years L_ago .
Who is L_involved and what is L_going on ?

If we L_consider the L_environment in the L_broadest L_sense , L_much L_monitoring of it has been in L_progress for L_many L_years and by an L_enormous L_diversity of L_organizations in the L_UK ; these L_include the L_DoE , the L_Forestry L_Commission , the L_Nature L_Conservancy , the L_Health and L_Safety L_Executive , L_local L_authorities , the L_component L_members of the L_Natural L_Environment L_Research L_Council ( such as the L_Institute of L_Terrestrial L_Ecology and the L_British L_Antarctic L_Survey ) , L_individuals or L_research L_groups in L_academia , the L_CEGB , the L_Friends of the L_Earth , and L_UK L_Centre for L_Economic and L_Environmental L_Development ( L_CEED ) ( 1989 ) .

The L_diversity of L_monitoring L_organizations L_seems just as L_great in other L_countries ; L_numerous L_multinational L_organizations , both L_quasi-governmental ( e.g. the L_UN L_Environment L_Programme ( L_UNEP ) ) and L_non-governmental ( e.g. the L_International L_Union for the L_Conservation of L_Nature ( L_IUCN ) and the L_International L_Institute for L_Environment and L_Development ( L_IIED ) ) are L_also L_active in the L_field .

L_Moreover , L_commercial L_monitoring of the L_environment is now L_also L_routine , L_notably to L_predict L_crop L_yields in the L_main L_grain-growing L_areas and L_hence L_facilitate the L_buying of L_futures .
The L_international L_scientific L_involvement
L_Scientists have both L_promoted and L_responded to the L_increasing L_interest in the L_environment .

L_Thus , at the L_global L_scale , the L_International L_Council of L_Scientific L_Unions ( L_ICSU ) has L_endorsed the L_setting up of the L_International L_Geosphere L_Biosphere L_Project ( L_IGBP ) to ‘ L_describe and L_understand the L_interactive L_physical , L_chemical and L_biological L_processes that L_regulate the L_total L_Earth L_system , the L_unique L_environment it L_provides for L_life , the L_changes that are L_occurring in that L_system and the L_manner by which these L_changes are L_influenced by L_human L_actions ’ ( L_Report of ad hoc L_Planning L_Group for L_IGBP 1986 , L_quoted in L_IGBP 1988 ) .

L_Priority in the L_IGBP is L_intended to be L_given to those L_areas which L_deal with L_key L_interactions and L_significant L_changes on the L_time-scales of L_decades to L_centuries , that most L_affect the L_biosphere , that are most L_susceptible to L_human L_perturbations and those that will most L_likely L_lead to a L_practical , L_predictive L_capability for L_global L_change .
This is to be L_put into L_operation by L_concentrating on four L_themes :
L_Documenting and L_predicting L_global L_change ;
L_Observing and L_improving our L_understanding of L_dominant L_forcing L_functions ;
L_Improving our L_understanding of L_interactive L_phenomena in the L_total L_Earth L_system ;
L_Assessing those L_effects of L_global L_change which will be L_large L_scale and L_cause L_major L_modifications to both L_renewable and L_non-renewable L_resources .
By 1990 , L_IGBP had L_progressed as L_far as L_defining a L_set of seven L_core L_projects ( L_IGBP 1990 ) L_addressing these four L_themes .
In L_addition , L_plans for L_regional L_research L_centres and for the L_data and L_information L_systems for L_IGBP ( L_known as L_IGBP-DIS ) had been L_announced .
The L_latter are L_particularly L_relevant to this L_chapter .

L_Based in L_Paris and L_working under L_Professor I. L_Rasool , it is L_intended to L_concentrate on L_managerial and L_policy L_aspects of the L_task in the L_first 2 L_years ( 1990–92 ) but then to L_expand L_considerably L_thereafter .

L_Tasks L_agreed for the L_IGBP-DIS L_include L_making L_available a ‘ L_directory of L_data L_directories ’ L_modelled on L_NASA 's L_Master L_Directory , L_providing L_data L_sets for L_education and L_training and L_undertaking a L_land L_cover L_pilot L_study .
Until 1990 , L_remarkably L_little L_interaction had L_taken L_place between the ‘ L_hard L_science ’ and the L_social L_science L_communities on L_global L_monitoring and L_prediction .

It is L_noteworthy , L_however , that the L_Royal L_Society L_made a L_plea for just this L_type of L_multidisciplinary L_work in its L_submission on L_greenhouse L_gases to the L_House of L_Lords ' L_Select L_Committee on L_Science and L_Technology ( L_Royal L_Society 1989 : 40 ) .

L_Fortunately , in L_addition to the L_actions of the L_world ‘ L_hard L_science ’ L_community , a L_parallel L_effort is now being L_initiated by L_social L_scientists ( L_Fuchs 1989 ; L_Jacobson and L_Price 1990 ) .

L_Currently this is L_organized and L_sponsored by the L_International L_Social L_Science L_Council ( L_ISSC ) , the L_UN L_University and the L_International L_Federation of L_Institutes of L_Advanced L_Studies .
Its L_objectives are to :
L_Improve L_scientific L_understanding and L_increase L_awareness of the L_complex L_dynamics L_governing L_human L_interaction with the L_total L_Earth L_system ;
L_Study , L_explore and L_anticipate L_social L_change L_affecting the L_global L_environment ;
L_Identify L_broad L_social L_strategies to L_prevent or L_mitigate L_undesirable L_impacts of L_global L_change or to L_adapt to L_changes which are L_unavoidable ;
L_Analyse L_policy L_options for L_dealing with L_global L_environmental L_change and L_promoting the L_goal of L_sustainable L_development .

L_Jacobson and L_Price ( 1990 ) L_provide a L_useful L_summary of the L_ways in which L_human L_factors L_contribute to , and are L_affected by , L_likely L_global L_changes ; in L_particular , they L_stress the L_importance of the L_data-handling L_issues and the L_role of L_GIS in L_coping with some of the L_problems of L_data L_integration and L_manipulation .
The L_ISSC L_proposed its own L_work L_programme in the L_Human L_Dimensions of L_Global L_Change in L_late 1990 .

While these L_organizations L_intrinsically have a L_world-wide L_membership and are L_concerned with L_research into L_global L_environmental L_change , L_others L_share the same L_interest but from a more L_restricted L_geographical L_base .

A L_leading L_example of this is the L_European L_Science L_Foundation which has L_sponsored L_research L_programmes in both the L_physical and L_social L_science L_aspects of L_environmental L_change ( L_ESF 1990 ) .
L_Governmental and L_political L_involvement

The L_spread of L_environmental L_awareness is L_readily L_demonstrated : in 1972 , 26 L_countries had L_environmental and L_natural L_resource L_management L_agencies whereas , a L_decade L_later the L_number was 144 ( L_WEC 1985 ) .

In most L_countries , the L_governmental and L_political L_concern with the L_environment has L_come L_somewhat L_later than that of L_scientists or L_concerned L_lay L_people : the L_early L_development of the L_Green L_Party in the L_Federal L_Republic of L_Germany is L_something of an L_exception .

Such a L_commitment to the L_environment is , L_none the L_less , both L_welcome and L_necessary if L_resources are to be L_made L_available to L_tackle L_existing , L_let L_alone L_forthcoming , L_environmental L_problems .

The ‘ L_conversion ’ of the L_UK L_government has been L_briefly L_described L_earlier ; it is L_manifested in their L_July 1989 L_commitment to L_spend £10m. on L_climate L_change L_research in 1989/90 and the L_confident L_request to them from the L_Advisory L_Board for the L_Research L_Councils ( L_ABRC ) for an L_extra £11m. in 1990 and £13m. in the two L_succeeding L_years for L_additional L_environmental L_research .
L_Perhaps the most L_significant L_development of all , L_however , is the L_increasing L_role of the L_European L_Commission .

Their L_role in L_bringing L_environmental L_impact L_assessment ( L_EIA ) on to the L_statute L_book is L_well L_known , but the L_Commission has now L_made a L_proposal ( L_CEC 1989 ) for the ‘ L_establishment of the L_European L_Environment L_Agency and the L_European L_Environment L_Monitoring and L_Information L_Network ’ .

The L_Commission L_argues that there is at L_present no L_monitoring of L_environmental L_quality and L_trends on a L_European L_scale , nor any L_guarantee that the L_results of L_environmental L_monitoring will be L_comparable on a L_Community-wide L_basis ( a L_realization L_brought about through the L_CORINE L_programme L_described L_later ) .

The L_objectives of the L_new L_agency would be to L_assist the L_Community and the L_Member L_States to L_achieve the L_goals L_set out in the L_Treaty of L_Rome and in L_successive L_environmental L_action L_programmes ; it must L_also , L_however , be L_seen in the L_context of the L_European L_Council 's L_adoption on 2 L_December 1988 of the L_Rhodes L_Declaration on the L_Environment and the L_environment L_chapter in the L_Single L_European L_Act which L_comes into L_effect in 1992 .
The L_detailed L_specific L_roles of ‘ the L_System ’ ( L_comprising both L_agency and L_network ) are L_envisaged as :

To L_provide the L_Community , the L_Member L_States and L_participating L_third L_countries with the L_objective ( L_sic ) L_information L_requested for the L_formulation and L_implementation of L_sound and L_effective L_environmental L_policies ;

In L_particular , to L_provide L_technical , L_scientific and L_economic L_information L_requested by the L_Commission in its L_tasks of L_identification , L_preparation and L_assessment of the L_implementation and L_results of L_environmental L_action and L_legislation ;

To L_stimulate the L_development and the L_application within the L_agency of L_techniques of L_environmental L_modelling and L_forecasting in L_order that L_adequate L_preventative L_action can be L_taken at the L_appropriate L_time ;

To L_help L_ensure the L_harmonization and L_comparability of L_environmental L_data in the L_Community as L_well as the L_integration of L_European L_environmental L_data into L_international L_environmental L_monitoring L_programmes , such as those L_established within the L_framework of the L_United L_Nations and its L_system of L_agencies .
L_Considerable L_stress is L_laid by the L_Commission on L_collaboration with L_national L_data-gathering L_agencies and with L_states L_adjacent to the L_Community 's L_borders .

It is L_envisaged that the L_totality of L_activities will L_extend the L_existing L_State of the L_European L_Environment L_report ( L_CEC 1988 ) through L_addressing the L_issues of the L_quality and L_sensitivity of the L_environment and L_also the L_pressures upon it .

L_Priorities for the L_new L_agency L_include L_study of L_atmospheric L_emissions and L_quality , L_water L_resources and L_quality ( L_including the L_marine L_environment ) , L_soil L_erosion and L_pollution and L_important L_land L_resources , and L_biotopes and L_nature L_conservation .
At the L_time of L_writing , the L_proposal has been L_approved and L_discussions are in L_progress on the L_location of the L_agency 's L_headquarters .
It L_seems L_certain to have L_major and L_growing L_effects upon L_environmental L_monitoring and L_prediction in L_Europe and on the L_policies of L_component L_governments .

L_Yet this is by no L_means the only L_plan which the L_Community has in L_relation to the L_environment : L_Directorate-General L_XII ( that for L_Science , L_Research and L_Development ) has L_published L_details of an L_extensive R&D L_programme ( L_CEC 1990a ) and the L_Commission as a L_whole ( L_CEC 1990b ) has L_made L_public its L_plans to L_develop L_regular L_official L_statistics of the L_environment .
The L_private L_sector
L_Certain L_aspects of L_environmental L_monitoring have L_long been L_carried out by the L_private L_sector , L_notably that of L_crop L_states on a L_world-wide L_basis .
L_Derived from L_satellite L_imagery at L_comparatively L_low L_resolution , L_predicted L_yields for L_different L_crops in L_different L_nation L_states L_become of L_commercial L_value .

L_However , L_significant L_resources are L_also being L_made L_available by the L_private L_sector where there is no L_immediate L_commercial L_gain : L_thus L_IBM L_UK L_Ltd has L_donated £3.5m. of L_computing L_equipment to L_UNEP and L_IBM in L_general is L_actively L_supporting other R&D which can be L_expected to L_facilitate ‘ L_sustainable L_development ’ : L_IBM L_Europe , for L_instance , has L_invested $16m. in its L_Bergen L_scientific L_centre to L_make it the L_focal L_point for the L_company 's L_environmental L_modelling and a L_centre for L_information on the L_environment and L_sustainable L_development .

On a more L_modest L_basis , L_IBM L_UK have L_agreed to L_fund a L_pilot L_global L_population L_database being L_built in L_Birkbeck L_College to L_permit L_assessment of the L_impact of L_environmental L_change on the L_world s L_population .

L_Many other L_companies , of L_course , are L_supporting L_environmental L_work but L_IBM L_seems L_almost to be L_unique in its L_corporate L_commitment to L_use of L_high L_technology for L_facilitating ‘ L_sustainable L_development ’ .
Some L_examples of L_environmental L_monitoring L_projects
The L_local L_scale
At the L_local L_scale , it is L_usually L_impossible to L_neglect the L_effects of L_multiple L_processes L_operating .

An L_example of L_environmental L_modelling and L_prediction where the L_interactions between L_different L_processes and L_dynamic L_feedback is L_taken into L_account is L_given by L_Haber and L_Schaller ( 1988 ) .
Their L_work L_formed L_part of one L_UNESCO L_Man and L_Biosphere ( L_MAB ) L_project , L_carried out in the L_Berchtesgaden L_National L_Park in L_Bavaria .
L_Following L_Holling ( 1978 ) and L_Grossman ( 1983 ) , they L_conceptualized the man/environment L_relationship at a L_series of L_hierarchical L_levels :
The L_lowest , or L_process , L_level , is L_directly and ( L_usually ) L_obviously L_connected to L_perceived L_reality .
L_Thus L_processes and L_interrelationships are L_mostly L_obvious , L_simple and L_linear ; L_data are L_usually L_readily L_available and may be L_voluminous .
This L_level is L_readily L_handled in L_commercial L_GIS ; ,

The L_intermediate , or L_dynamic , L_level is L_concerned with L_less L_frequent and L_often L_irregular L_events , e.g. a L_temporary L_lack of L_water because of L_fire , L_frost or L_excessive L_demand from an L_increasing L_populace .

L_Characteristically , the L_data L_used may be more L_difficult to L_obtain and are L_usually more L_spatially L_aggregated ; L_modelling L_software which L_permits L_feedback L_loops is L_essential ;
The L_top , or L_strategic , L_level is the most L_difficult to L_explore ; the L_external L_influences are L_often L_unpredictable by L_formal L_means .
L_Relevant L_data are L_therefore L_difficult to L_identify and L_scenario L_building is one of the few L_approaches L_available .
The L_Haber and L_Schaller L_approach is to ‘ L_soft-couple ’ these L_different L_levels and their L_accompanying L_approaches L_using an L_ecological L_balance L_model .
L_Results of L_running this with L_different L_scenarios L_include ‘ L_time L_slice ’ L_maps of L_possible L_outcomes and of the L_exchange of L_material and L_energy within the L_study L_area .
While L_ultimately L_qualitative , it L_seems to L_offer a L_method for L_coping with L_different L_types of L_process and L_incorporating L_stochastic and L_truly L_random L_events .
The L_national and L_continental L_scale : the L_CORINE L_project
The L_CORINE L_programme L_represents the L_product of L_much L_activity by the L_European L_Commission 's L_Directorate-General ( L_XI ) for the L_Environment .

It L_originates from an L_Italian L_request to the L_Council of L_Ministers in 1973 to L_identify L_environmentally ‘ L_balanced ’ and ‘ L_unbalanced ’ L_areas in the L_Community ; the L_first L_attempts to do this were L_unsuccessful and , though by 1981 it was L_clear that a L_new L_approach L_based on an L_environmental L_information L_system was the most L_promising one , L_funding for this was not L_secured until 1985 .

A 4-year L_experimental L_programme to ‘ L_collect , L_co-ordinate and L_ensure the L_consistency of L_information on the L_state of the L_environment and L_natural L_resources in the L_European L_Communities ’ was L_set up and L_labelled L_CORINE .

The L_objectives of L_CORINE were to be L_achieved through L_bringing L_together L_existing L_data L_holdings in the L_member L_states , L_developing L_methods for L_holding , L_analysing and L_presenting the L_data , and L_encouraging the L_exchange of L_data .

A L_number of L_priority L_areas were L_identified , L_including L_biotopes of L_importance for L_nature L_conservation , L_acid L_deposition and its L_effects on L_soils and L_biotopes and the L_protection of the L_environment of the L_Mediterranean L_region ( L_Briggs and L_Martin 1988 ) .
L_Many L_achievements can be L_claimed by the L_CORINE L_project L_team .

As a L_result of some 40 L_sub-projects L_involving all the L_Member L_States ( and L_often L_several L_groups within each one ) , L_databases of L_topography , L_soils , L_water L_resources and L_quality , L_biotopes , L_atmospheric L_emissions , L_climate , L_soil L_erosion and L_administrative L_boundaries have been L_built up for the M_whole L_Community and can be L_interrelated ; other L_data L_sets ( such as L_land L_cover , L_derived from L_satellite L_imagery ) have L_already been L_compiled for some of the L_Member L_States .

L_Various L_aspects of the L_CORINE L_project have been L_described in L_papers by L_Rhind L_et al. ( 1986 ) , L_Wiggins et al. ( 1987 ) , L_Briggs and L_Martin ( 1988 ) , L_Briggs and L_Mounsey ( 1989 ) and L_CEC ( 1990c ) .
For the L_present L_purposes , L_however , the L_key L_findings are :
L_Many L_necessary L_data L_sets were L_unavailable for L_reasons of L_administrative L_inadequacies , L_confidentiality L_constraints , L_cost or L_non-collection in L_certain L_countries ;

The L_unavoidable L_reliance upon L_existing L_data L_sets L_led to L_many L_problems L_due to L_non-harmonization L_even of L_commonly L_used L_variables , e.g. eight L_different L_definitions of L_potential L_evapo-transpiration were in L_use in the L_Member L_States and ‘ L_maximum L_temperature ’ at each L_weather L_station was L_defined in at L_least four L_different L_ways ;

The L_compilation of a L_spatially L_coherent L_database from L_mapped L_information L_compiled by L_different L_organizations at L_different L_scales and on L_different L_topographic L_bases ( L_see L_Rhind and L_Clark 1988 ) is L_often L_difficult ;

L_User L_expectations are L_often L_unreasonably L_high ; L_use of L_administrative L_computing L_systems L_encourages L_bureaucrats to L_believe that L_environmental L_data can just as L_readily be L_analysed and L_used to L_support L_decisions .

The ‘ L_fuzzy ’ L_nature of L_much L_geographically L_distributed L_data , the L_inherent L_errors in it , the L_effects of the L_processing L_algorithms L_used and the L_assumption of L_known L_interactions between L_variables L_ensures that L_completely L_routine L_use by L_unskilled L_users is L_unlikely to be L_possible in the L_foreseeable L_future ;
More L_detailed L_data are L_required for L_particular L_tasks as the L_role of L_CORINE L_grows .
The L_European L_Commission 's L_proposal for an L_environment L_agency ( L_see above ) will L_subsume the L_CORINE L_team and L_databases .
The L_global L_scale : L_NASA and GEMS/GRID
Without L_question , the L_largest ‘ L_player ’ in the L_global L_environment L_arena is L_NASA .
The L_organization has L_initiated L_many of the L_schemes which now are under L_discussion — the L_IGBP , for L_instance , has been L_strongly L_influenced by L_NASA L_proposals .
A L_summary of L_current L_activities and L_future L_plans is L_given in L_NASA ( 1988b ) .
By L_way of L_example , L_current L_programmes are L_collecting L_global L_data on L_stratospheric L_ozone , on L_sea-surface and L_sea-ice L_variables and on the L_earth 's L_radiation L_budget .
L_Approved L_future L_programmes L_include the L_Upper L_Atmosphere L_Research L_Satellite , the L_NASA L_Scatterometer and the L_joint NASA/CNES L_Ocean L_Topography L_Experiment .
In L_addition , L_however , L_funding has L_recently been L_approved for a L_much more L_ambitious L_scheme — the L_Earth L_Observing L_System ( L_EOS ) .

This is L_conceived not as a L_set of L_hardware but as a L_comprehensive L_information L_system L_focused on the L_needs L_identified by the L_ESSC ( L_see above ) and L_anticipating L_somewhat those of L_IGBP .
It will L_collate L_data from the two L_proposed L_space L_station L_polar L_platforms , one L_European L_Space L_Agency L_platform , a L_Japanese one and L_also from the L_manned L_space L_station .
On this L_basis , a L_data L_flow of no L_less than 1 L_terabyte ( i.e. 10&sup12 ; L_bytes ) L_day is L_anticipated by the mid-1990s .
A L_major L_user of L_NASA L_data and L_skills has been the L_UN L_Environment L_Programme .

L_formed in the L_wake of the 1972 L_Stockholm L_conference , L_UNEP L_soon L_spawned the L_Global L_Environment L_Monitoring L_System ( L_GEMS ) as L_well as an L_international L_register of L_potentially L_toxic L_chemicals and a L_global L_network of L_sources to L_locate and L_provide L_technical , L_scientific and L_management L_information on the L_environment .
The L_need for a L_mechanism to L_handle the L_global L_environmental L_data was L_defined in the L_early 1980s and the L_Global L_Resources L_Information L_Database ( L_GRID ) L_resulted .

L_Mooneyhan ( 1988 ) has L_described the L_progress of the L_pilot L_stage of L_GRID which L_culminated in L_approval for a L_full L_operational L_phase ; L_GRID is now L_involved in L_integrating , L_storing and L_exploiting a L_variety of L_global L_environmental L_databases , L_mostly L_acquired from L_NASA .

In L_addition to the L_work being L_carried out in the L_UNEP L_HQ at L_Nairobi and in the GEMS/GRID L_site in L_Geneva , a L_series of L_GRID L_regional L_nodes are now being L_set up L_world-wide , each L_equipped with the same L_hardware and L_software and L_local L_subsets of the L_data .
The L_first of these is in L_Bangkok and another is to be L_opened in L_Latin L_America .

L_Moreover , L_national L_nodes are L_also being L_set up ; the L_recent L_IBM L_gift to L_GRID ( L_see above ) has L_ensured that L_powerful L_microcomputers have been L_installed in L_many L_African L_countries , L_together with L_national and L_continental L_data L_sets .
L_Training of L_unskilled L_staff to L_operate this L_equipment and to L_exploit the L_scientific L_data is now a L_major L_role for L_GRID L_staff .
L_Technical L_aspects and L_problems
It L_follows from L_much of the above that there are L_major L_challenges in L_use of L_environmental L_data .
These are L_best L_considered by L_itemizing L_characteristics of L_contemporary L_environmental L_monitoring and L_prediction :
The L_use of L_secondary L_data , L_rather than L_primary L_data L_collected by the L_data L_analyst ;
The L_need , at L_least with L_data on the L_terrestrial L_environment , for an L_inference L_process to L_extract L_useful L_information from the L_secondary ( and L_often L_proxy ) L_data ;
The L_data L_volumes L_collected are L_often L_voluminous L_even by the L_standards of L_contemporary L_computing L_facilities ;
The L_analyses L_carried out are L_often L_arcane in L_detail to all but a L_small L_group of ‘ L_high L_priests ’ ;
We have only a L_limited L_capacity for L_checking the L_accuracy of L_many L_environmental L_monitoring L_results , L_let L_alone of L_predictions .
Some of these L_characteristics are now L_addressed in L_slightly more L_detail ; it will be L_obvious that such L_problems L_merit a L_paper in themselves .
L_Remote L_sensing as a L_data L_collection L_process
As the L_need for more L_extensive , L_high-resolution L_yet L_consistent and L_up-to-date L_data L_becomes more L_pressing , L_increased L_use of L_remote L_sensing L_seems L_inevitable .

No other L_data L_collection L_methodology L_obviates the L_short L_distance L_variation in L_data L_sets L_induced by L_variations in L_data L_collection and L_aggregation L_methodology L_typically L_encountered between L_adjacent L_nation L_states .

The L_problem is now L_recognized , L_especially in L_Europe , and L_strenuous L_efforts are being L_made to L_harmonise the L_data L_sets ( e.g. through the L_use of L_standard L_classifications , such as that for L_land L_use L_produced by the L_Conference of L_European L_Statisticians in 1989 ) .
At L_present , L_however , L_ground-collected L_environmental L_data are L_far L_less than L_ideal .

L_Recognizing this , L_NASA ( 1988a ) L_concluded that L_forthcoming L_global L_science L_projects would L_need L_land L_surface L_altitude L_data at three L_resolutions : 1 L_km L_resolution in L_XY and 10–100 m L_resolution in Z on a L_global L_basis , 100 m L_XY L_resolution and 1–10 m L_resolution in Z for L_regional L_databases and 10 m L_XY L_resolution and 0.1–1 m in Z for L_local L_studies .

They L_argued that L_existing L_maps and L_digitized L_files from them are L_unable to L_meet these L_needs at L_global or L_regional L_scale and only L_remote L_sensing could L_help in the L_short L_term : the L_availability of L_stereometric L_data from the L_French L_SPOT L_satellite has L_already L_led to L_proposals for L_automated L_creation of L_global L_digital L_elevation L_models with a L_spatial ( L_XY ) L_resolution of about 30 m ( L_Muller 1989 ) .

For L_many L_terrestrial L_purposes , L_however , a L_substantial L_inference L_process must L_take L_place to L_convert the L_radiometric L_measurements into L_useful L_information ( in L_contrast , more L_direct L_measurements of L_sea L_state , etc. are L_possible ) .

The L_value of this L_information is L_inherently L_dependent upon the L_quality of the L_inference L_process and that in L_turn L_depends upon the L_complexity of the L_scene , the L_spatial , L_temporal and L_spectral L_resolution of the L_sensors and the L_particular L_algorithms L_used .

L_Thus L_far , for L_instance , L_accuracies of L_land L_cover ( L_let L_alone what is L_often L_needed , i.e. L_land L_use ) L_determined from L_Landsat and L_SPOT L_imagery for the L_UK have L_rarely been L_higher than 70 per L_cent unless L_trivial L_classifications ( e.g. built/unbuilt L_land ) have been L_used .
One L_solution to this is to ‘ L_densify ’ the L_ground L_control and another is to L_use L_contextually L_based L_classifiers L_rather than the L_traditional , L_spectrally L_based L_ones .

But the L_ground L_conditions in some L_parts of L_Europe L_make L_good L_results L_extremely L_difficult to L_obtain : some L_areas of L_Portugal , for L_instance , have L_field L_sizes of only a few L_metres and L_exhibit L_multi-level and L_multi-seasonal L_cropping .
A further L_difficulty is the L_cost of the L_data in L_relation to its L_anticipated L_benefits .

L_Relatively few cost/benefit L_studies have L_yet been L_carried out except in such L_areas as L_crop L_prediction and L_ocean L_navigation ( where they are L_generally L_shown to be L_highly L_advantageous in L_saving L_someone L_else 's L_money ) .

It may be that a L_study L_commissioned from L_contractors by the L_British L_National L_Space L_Centre will L_provide L_useful L_evidence on the L_cash L_value of L_remote L_sensing ; it is L_particularly L_timely in L_view of the L_appointment of L_Professor L_Pearce ( L_see above ) as the L_adviser to the L_UK L_Secretary of L_State for the L_Environment .
Other L_work on L_assessment of L_costs and L_benefits of such L_data have been L_carried out for the L_French L_government by L_Professor L_Didier ( 1990 ) .

L_Finally , since L_data are L_often L_costly to L_acquire , it L_follows that L_summaries of them e.g. The L_State of the L_European L_Environment L_report ( L_CEC 1988 ) and the L_Environmental L_Data L_Report of the L_UN L_EP ( L_GEMS L_MARC 1989 ) are of L_considerable L_value .

L_Equally , the ‘ L_signposting ’ L_role now being L_adopted by L_UNEP 's L_GRID L_project — which is L_expected to L_offer L_on-line L_access to a L_catalogue of L_environmental L_data L_sets and L_details of the L_responsible L_agencies in 1991 — is to be L_welcomed .
The L_data L_problem and L_partial L_solutions
The L_lack of L_harmonization of L_definitions and L_methods of L_collection of L_environmental L_data have L_already been L_outlined above .
In the L_European L_Community of 12 L_nation L_states , for L_instance , no L_less than eight L_procedures for L_calculating L_potential L_evapo-transpiration have been in L_use !

The L_need for L_harmonization is L_obvious and , in this L_respect , must L_follow from the L_successful L_pioneering L_achievements of L_EUROSTAT in L_harmonizing the L_definitions in L_trade , L_demographic and other ‘ L_social L_science ’ L_statistics ( L_see L_CEC 1990b ) .
An L_additional and L_severe L_problem is that the L_volumes of L_data which are L_already L_collected are L_huge by the L_standards of only a L_decade L_ago .
By 1995/96 , they will be very L_much L_greater , L_notably from the L_EOS L_programme .
L_NASA has L_announced L_plans to L_collect up to 1 L_terabyte ( 10&sup12 ; L_bytes ) L_day .

Since L_remote L_sensing L_data L_sets ( L_especially those L_pertaining to L_terrestrial L_areas of the L_globe ) L_typically L_need L_much L_pre-processing to L_calibrate , L_transform and then L_perform an L_inference L_process and L_hence L_convert L_measurements of the L_radiation L_reflected or L_emitted by L_small L_areas of L_ground into L_useful ( e.g. L_land L_cover ) L_data , the L_processing L_power L_required is L_going to be L_formidable .
Other , L_non-remote-sensing L_data L_sets are L_smaller in L_volume but more L_complex in L_structure and in their L_characteristics .
To L_hold all of the 1/50 000 L_scale L_topographic L_map L_coverage L_alone for the L_European L_Community would L_probably L_require about 3 L_terabytes of L_storage .
L_Parenthetically , the L_form in which the L_data may be L_held can L_affect L_dramatically the L_scale of the L_problem L_faced .

It would be L_technically L_possible , for L_instance , to L_hold in L_less than 1 L_terabyte L_detailed L_information for every L_individual in the L_world , L_akin to that L_collected about L_everyone in the L_UK through the L_Census of L_Population .

In L_practice , L_legislation L_generally L_forbids such L_data being L_held L_thus and L_distributed in L_anything other than L_area L_aggregate L_form ; the L_cross-tabulations L_commonly L_employed ( e.g. to L_give L_tables of L_population L_numbers L_broken down by L_age and L_sex ) L_often L_result in a L_great L_multiplication of the L_data L_volumes .
This all L_presents L_major L_problems of L_data L_storage , L_handling ( L_especially for L_global L_data L_sets ) , L_display and L_dissemination .

L_Fortunately , L_technical L_developments have L_ensured that the L_increase in L_computing L_power per L_unit L_cost has been L_growing at about an L_order of L_magnitude every 6 L_years over the L_last three L_decades .

L_Indeed , this may L_grossly L_under-represent the L_present L_situation : the L_rapid L_spread of L_UNIX-based L_systems L_seems to L_facilitate L_competition and , at the L_time of L_writing , L_performance of L_workstations per L_unit L_cost L_seems to be L_increasing at about 50 per L_cent per L_annum .

L_Moreover , the L_advent of L_low-cost , L_high-density-storage L_devices like L_CD-ROMs may L_well L_make L_substantial L_data L_sets L_available L_even to those with L_modest L_computing L_power : a L_CD-ROM , for L_instance , can L_hold about 600 L_megabytes ( i.e. 10&sup6 ; L_bytes ) , can be L_reproduced L_currently for about £1 and L_read on a L_device L_costing about £400 .
L_Yet , despite such L_revolutionary L_changes in L_technology , L_novel L_solutions will L_still be L_required to L_make L_effective L_use of the L_new L_data L_sets .
One such L_solution is L_Goodchild and L_Yang 's ( 1989 ) L_scheme for a L_hierarchical L_spatial L_data L_structure to L_handle L_data for the L_spherical L_earth .
A L_particular L_problem is that L_little or no L_quantitative L_regard has been L_paid until L_recently to the L_effects of L_quality L_variation in L_environmental L_data .
The L_literature of the L_last few L_years is L_thronged with L_papers L_proposing that these must be L_taken into L_account — but with few L_realistic L_proposals on how this is to be L_achieved .
L_Goodchild ( 1988 ) has L_made L_perhaps the L_best L_summary of the L_problem and L_possible L_solutions to L_date .

L_Finally , L_relatively L_little L_emphasis has been L_given to the L_management of L_data as a L_corporate L_resource , L_available to a L_wide L_community : L_many L_environmental L_data are L_collected on a L_project-by-project L_basis and ‘ L_lost ’ once the L_urgency of the L_initial L_research is over .

L_However , the 1990 L_report of the L_Data and L_Facilities L_Working L_Group of the L_UK L_Inter-Agency L_Committee on L_Global L_Environmental L_Change L_argued L_strongly that L_planning for the L_dissemination and L_maintenance of such L_data was a L_vital L_role .

It L_also L_noted that L_ownership of and L_access to L_environmental L_data was a L_policy L_matter of the L_greatest L_importance ; this may be more L_difficult in ‘ within L_country ’ L_data than with L_global L_data since the L_latter are L_often L_already the L_subject of L_international L_exchange L_agreements at zero L_cost .
L_Global L_environmental L_research and the L_social L_sciences
L_Thus L_far , the L_emphasis has been very L_much on the L_natural L_science L_aspects of L_environmental L_monitoring and L_prediction .
That is L_unremarkable since the L_anticipation of such L_problems and L_assessments of some of their L_causes and L_magnitudes can only be L_made by L_environmental L_scientists .

L_Yet the L_consequences of any L_significant L_changes are a L_matter of the L_utmost L_concern to L_planners and to L_politicians at all L_levels , the L_quantification of the L_costs and L_benefits of L_alternative L_policy L_strategies is very L_much a L_matter for L_economists , and the L_adaptation of L_societies to L_massive L_change is a L_particular L_interest to L_sociologists and L_others .

For L_geographers — who L_span the L_conventional ( and now L_archaic ) L_dichotomy between the L_natural and the L_environmental L_sciences — all of these L_aspects L_need to be L_woven L_together to L_anticipate the L_likely L_spatial L_patterns of the L_effects of L_massive L_change , the L_redistributions in L_trade , L_health and L_wealth which they will L_bring about and the ‘ L_knock on ’ L_effects these L_consequences themselves will have on L_society and the L_environment .

For L_social L_scientists , then , L_environmental L_monitoring and L_prediction are a L_matter of L_considerable L_significance , L_especially as ‘ L_globalization ’ of L_markets and L_economies L_proceeds .

The L_Economic and L_Social L_Research L_Council ( L_ESRC ) L_commissioned two L_reports on L_global L_environmental L_change to L_guide or at L_least L_inform the L_allocation of L_research L_funding .

These L_reports ( L_Pearce 1990 ; L_Turner 1990 ) may be L_taken as L_informed L_views from at L_least the L_economists in the L_UK L_social L_science L_community on the L_social L_science L_aspects of L_global L_environmental L_change .
L_Pearce ( 1990 ) , for L_instance , L_presented an L_economist 's L_views of the L_high-priority L_topics for L_research as L_follows :
The L_theory and L_practice of L_international L_agreements , L_viewed in a L_game L_theory L_context ;
The L_theory of L_optimal L_behaviour under L_scientific L_uncertainty ; ,
L_Cost-benefit L_frameworks , L_especially for L_dealing with L_man-induced L_climatic L_effects ;
L_Definition of the L_impacts of L_climate L_change on L_eastern L_Europe and the L_developing L_countries ;
L_Appropriate L_policies on L_non-carbon L_dioxide L_greenhouse L_gases ;
L_Assessment of the L_ecological L_values of L_tropical L_forest ;
L_Economic L_instruments for L_reducing L_greenhouse L_gases ;
The L_international L_politics of L_climate L_change ;
L_National and L_global L_energy L_options L_given the L_greenhouse L_effect ;
L_Trade and L_global L_change .
L_Turner ( 1990 ) L_argued that the L_priorities are as L_follows :
The L_socio-economic L_consequences of L_sea-level L_rise ;
L_Techniques for the L_valuation of L_environmental L_resources and L_effects ;
