An L_assessment of L_management L_tools , L_institutional L_adaptation and L_policy L_integration in L_regard to L_global L_environmental L_change ;
L_Studies of L_agriculture in L_relation to L_climate L_change ;
L_Understanding of how L_environmental L_issues and L_technical L_change L_interact ;
The L_interrelationship between L_environmental L_ethics and L_economics .
There is , then , no L_shortage of L_social L_science L_research which is L_claimed to be L_necessary if we are to L_cope with L_environmental L_change .
Some of it is being L_carried out : in L_March 1991 L_ESRC L_announced a £6m L_programme of L_research on L_Global L_Environmental L_Change .
L_However , L_perhaps most L_critical of all in the L_early L_stages is L_social L_science L_practice L_rather than L_research .

In the L_USA at L_least , there L_needs to be an L_improvement in L_scientists ' L_understandings of how to L_influence the L_allocation of L_funding for L_remedial L_measures or for further L_research ( L_see L_Kitsos and L_Ashe 1989 ) .
All too L_often , it L_seems that the L_coupling of an as L_yet L_imperfect L_scientific L_understanding to L_policy-making is L_tenuous ( L_see L_Table 9.2 ) .

L_Fortunately , L_considerable L_high-quality L_work has L_already L_begun on the L_legal , L_political and L_institutional L_aspects of L_global L_environmental L_change ( L_see , for L_instance , L_Nitze 1990 ) .
What L_next ?

The L_contents of this L_chapter have L_scarcely L_touched upon such L_important L_environmental L_research as the L_World L_Ocean L_Climate L_Experiment or the L_World L_Climate L_Research L_Programme .
Nor has there been any L_discussion of the L_growing L_requirement in the L_UK ( as L_elsewhere ) to L_carry out an L_environmental L_impact L_assessment for all L_major L_developments .

The L_consequences for some L_nations or L_subgroups in a L_population of being without L_access to L_environmental L_data or the L_tools for L_analysing them while L_others have such L_access are L_potentially L_profound — as the L_European L_Commission has L_recognized in L_issuing a L_directive on L_public L_access to L_environmental L_data ( L_CEC 1990d ) — yet L_space L_limitations have L_also L_precluded their L_discussion .

Despite these L_shortcomings L_dictated by the L_space L_available , what has been L_said should be L_sufficient to L_illustrate the L_enormous and L_diverse L_scope of L_environmental L_monitoring and L_prediction .
Such is its L_diversity that L_measuring the L_total L_expenditure on it L_seems L_quite L_impossible and the L_number of ‘ L_actors ’ L_already L_involved is L_vast .

What is L_clear , L_however , is that L_monitoring is L_rarely a L_simple L_exercise , that the L_time-scales of the L_sponsors of L_monitoring and L_environmental L_research are L_rarely L_long L_term though most L_science is L_inevitably of this L_nature and that the L_increasingly L_multinational L_nature of such L_work L_necessitates a L_degree of L_management not L_always L_present in L_local or L_nationally L_based L_schemes .
In these L_circumstances , it is L_scarcely L_surprising that there is L_evidence of L_international and L_interdisciplinary L_dispute , as L_Terney ( 1989 ) has L_chronicled in L_regard to L_IGBP .

L_Moreover , as L_Newby ( 1990 ) has L_pointed out , the L_complexities of L_environmental L_research have L_created a L_new L_kind of L_relationship between L_research and L_policy : ‘ in the L_past , … the L_relationship was L_predicated on the L_belief that L_science L_provided L_decision-makers with L_objective ‘ L_hard ’ L_facts on which to L_base their L_soft , L_value-ridden L_policies … .
But now we L_find L_scientists L_delivering only ‘ L_soft ’ , L_uncertain ‘ L_facts ’ to L_decision-makers L_facing ‘ L_hard ’ L_decisions . ’

L_Yet , L_even if all of this L_causes L_great L_uncertainty among L_scientists , it is L_still a L_reasonable L_prediction that a L_decade L_ahead will L_see both L_environmental L_monitoring and L_prediction L_treated as an L_everyday L_need and L_activity in L_major L_organizations .

We shall L_also L_see the L_existence of L_binding L_requirements upon L_national L_governments — L_certainly in the L_European L_Community — to L_collect at L_least L_basic L_environmental L_indicators in a L_harmonized L_form ( L_CEC 1990b ) .
More than that , it L_seems L_highly L_likely that the L_social L_science L_aspects of L_environmental L_problems will L_underpin the L_actions of L_governments and L_international L_agencies .

L_Perhaps the L_single most L_important L_conclusion to be L_drawn from this L_review is that the L_monitoring , L_modelling and L_management of the L_global L_environment are L_tasks which L_uniquely L_require the L_integration of L_skills and L_techniques from L_many L_disciplines .
L_Building such L_research L_teams is L_essential .

L_Underlying it all , L_however , is one L_obvious L_fact : that the L_gathering and L_analysis of L_geographically L_distributed L_environmental L_data L_form the L_necessary L_starting-point for L_ensuring the L_success of our L_future on L_earth .

L_Thanks are L_due to L_Tina L_Buckle and L_Jonathan L_Raper for L_remastering the L_diagrams .
The L_UK L_ESRC L_supported the L_work of the L_South L_East L_Regional L_Research L_Laboratory in L_Birkbeck L_College , L_University of L_London , from which this L_review has L_grown .
L_Managing L_natural and L_technological L_hazards
L_Anthony C. L_Gatrell and L_Peter L_Vincent
L_Introduction

Few L_areas of the L_application of L_GIS L_technology can be as L_socially L_significant , or L_environmentally L_relevant , as the L_management of L_emergencies and L_disasters L_due to L_natural and L_technological L_hazards .

Whether L_attempting to L_construct a L_database of L_resources for L_use in L_planning L_responses to L_nuclear L_emergencies , L_developing L_optimal L_routes for L_scheduling the L_safe L_transport of L_hazardous L_substances , or L_monitoring the L_health L_implications of a L_disaster , L_GIS can L_assist in L_identifying L_possibilities and L_formulating L_solutions .
The 1990s have been L_declared the L_International L_Decade for L_Natural L_Disaster L_Reduction .

L_Let us L_hope that G1S can , in some L_small L_way , L_help L_mitigate the L_suffering and L_hardship L_felt by all those L_afflicted by the L_effects of L_hazards which , as we have L_learnt with L_bitter L_recent L_experience in the L_UK , can L_occur in an L_untimely L_fashion in the most L_improbable of L_places .
L_Research on L_hazards is L_multidisciplinary and L_straddles the L_social , L_environmental and L_mathematical L_sciences .

If , for L_instance , we L_wish to L_model the L_dispersal of a L_plume of L_toxic L_gas L_resulting from a L_chemical L_explosion , L_assess its L_possible L_impact on L_human L_health and L_evaluate L_likely L_evacuation L_scenarios of the L_population at L_risk we would L_require , for L_example , a L_knowledge of L_atmospheric L_dispersion L_models , L_epidemiology and L_population L_distribution .
Some L_researchers L_suggest that L_hazards ( and L_emergencies that might L_result ) can be L_regarded as either L_natural or L_technological .

We shall L_elaborate on this L_simple L_division below but L_suggest here that the L_wealth of L_literature on the L_former ( L_see , for L_instance , L_Burton et al. 1978 and L_Perry 1981 ) has L_yet to be L_matched by a L_similar L_volume of L_work on the L_latter .
There are L_signs that this L_imbalance is being L_rectified ( L_Zeigler et al. 1983 ) .

L_Hazard L_research , like few other L_GIS L_application L_areas , is not only L_stretching the L_present L_technology to its L_limits but is a L_quite L_remarkable L_focus of L_international L_effort into L_several L_important L_research-related L_areas such as L_expert L_systems and L_simulation L_studies .
In this L_sense the L_scene is L_clearly one of L_hazard L_problems L_looking for L_improved L_GIS L_rather than for L_GIS L_looking for L_good L_problems , as is all too L_often the L_case .
L_Hazard L_research
What are L_hazards ?

L_Formally , a L_hazard can be L_defined as : ‘ a L_physical L_situation with a L_potential for L_human L_injury , L_damage to L_property , L_damage to the L_environment , or some L_combination of these ’ ( L_Health and L_Safety L_Executive 1989 : 30 ) .
A L_hazard is a L_threat which , L_given a L_set of L_circumstances , may L_become L_translated into a L_realized L_event .

What we L_choose to L_call this L_event L_depends upon L_factors such as its L_magnitude : we L_speak for L_instance of L_accidents , L_emergencies , L_disasters and L_catastrophes , each of which L_carries L_connotations L_concerning the L_scale of the L_event and each of which will have a L_set of L_human and/or L_environmental L_consequences .
On 30 L_March 1956 one of the most L_powerful L_volcanic L_disturbances this L_century , the L_Bezymianny L_eruption , L_occurred .
Few L_people L_noticed the L_event as it L_took L_place in an L_uninhabited L_part of L_Kamchatcka and L_caused no L_known L_casualties .

In L_contrast , the L_extrusion of a L_small L_volume of L_lava from a L_secondary L_cone on the L_slopes of L_Tristan L_da L_Cunha L_became the L_focus of L_global L_interest when , during L_October 1961 , the L_island 's L_lobster L_processing L_plant was L_smothered and the 300 L_people of the L_island 's only L_settlement were L_evacuated to the L_UK .

These two L_contrasting L_events L_emphasize the L_central L_fact that L_even L_natural L_hazards are not L_defined L_solely by the L_characteristics of the L_event but by the L_interaction of those L_events with the L_human L_occupation of the L_threatened L_area .
As L_noted above , the L_simple L_division of L_hazards is between those which are L_natural and those which are L_technological or L_human-induced .

Each of these may be further L_subdivided and the L_typology L_shown in Fig. 10.1 L_draws upon the L_classic L_work of L_Burton and L_Kates ( 1964 ) in L_separating L_geophysical from L_biological L_hazards and L_Zeigler et al. ( 1983 ) in L_distinguishing L_public ( or what we might L_call L_societal ) L_hazards from L_private ( L_individual ) L_ones .
The further L_subdivision of L_natural L_hazards is L_self-explanatory as is that of L_individual L_technological L_hazards .

L_Zeigler L_divides the L_public L_hazards into those which L_result from the L_production of L_raw L_materials and L_manufactured L_goods , those which L_originate in L_transport and L_transmission and those which L_threaten the L_public in their L_role as L_consumers .
The L_United L_Nations L_Disaster L_Relief L_Organization ( L_UNDRO ) has L_produced a L_classification of L_disasters , L_derived on the L_basis of L_case L_data ( L_Table 10.1 ) .
L_UNDRO L_recognizes three L_basic L_types of L_disaster : L_accidents , L_natural L_events , and other L_disasters .
The L_differentiation of L_accidents from other L_types is L_useful in the L_context of L_emergency L_planning and is not so L_clearly L_conveyed by other L_hazard L_typologies .
L_However , the L_temptation in all L_classification L_exercises is to L_produce L_partitional L_schemes and this should L_really be L_resisted here .

It is more L_useful ( L_Johnson 1983 ) to L_adopt a L_non-partitional L_scheme ( fig. 10.1 ) that L_recognizes , for L_instance , L_food L_poisoning as both a L_personal and L_consumer L_hazard , or L_lead L_pollution ( e.g. from L_car L_exhausts ) as both a L_meteorological L_event and L_technological L_hazard ( both L_public and L_private ) .
An L_air L_crash ( as at L_Lockerbie ) L_affects an L_entire L_community L_directly , as L_well as being an L_occupational L_hazard and L_risk to the L_individual L_traveller .
L_Hillslope L_failure ( as at L_Aberfan in L_South L_Wales in 1966 ) is a L_geomorphic L_hazard but may L_arise because of L_raw L_material L_extraction .
L_Dutch L_elm L_disease is a L_floral L_hazard but is L_exacerbated by the L_transport of L_infected L_logs .

L_Hohensemer L_et al. ( 1983 ) L_make the L_important L_point that L_hazards are L_multidimensional in L_nature and L_suggest 12 L_dimensions along which any L_hazard may be L_scored ( L_see L_Table 10.2 ) .
These L_factors will , of L_course , be L_important in L_deciding on the L_role that L_GIS can L_play in L_hazard L_monitoring and L_emergency L_planning .

For L_instance , some L_events will L_persist L_briefly , have L_immediate L_consequences , L_minor L_transgenerational L_effects and have L_little or no L_potential for L_non-human L_mortality ( an L_air L_crash is an L_example ) .

L_Others , such as a L_chemical L_explosion L_involving the L_release of a L_toxic L_gas , may L_persist for a L_week or more , have L_delayed L_consequences , may L_affect a L_future L_generation if the L_toxic L_chemical is L_mutagenic and may have a L_significant L_impact on L_plant and L_animal L_populations .
There may be more L_scope for a L_GIS L_approach in the L_latter than in the L_former L_situations .
The L_Hohensemer L_scheme is not , L_however , beyond L_criticism .
for L_example , can L_hazards L_really be L_thought of as having any L_intentionality ?
L_Industrial L_hazards and L_risk L_assessment
Once L_hazards have been L_identified there may L_follow L_efforts to L_assess the L_hazard L_risk .

By ‘ L_risk ’ we L_understand ‘ the L_likelihood of a L_specified L_undesired L_event L_occurring within a L_specified L_period or in L_specified L_circumstances ’ ( L_Health and L_Safety L_Executive 1989 : 30 ) .
It may , of L_course , be L_easier to L_quantify L_risk for L_natural L_hazards because of L_historical L_records and L_statistical L_estimation of L_recurrence L_intervals .

L_Technological L_hazards are more L_unpredictable and may be L_extremely L_rare , so that it L_becomes L_difficult to L_use L_probability L_concepts to L_quantify L_risk , L_especially those which L_rely on L_notions of L_relative L_frequency .
The L_identification of L_chemical L_hazards L_requires that the L_locations of L_sites be L_known , L_together with the L_dangerous L_substances L_stored or L_processed there .

In the L_UK ( L_see L_Petts 1988 for a L_splendid L_overview ) the L_Health and L_Safety L_Executive must be L_notified of L_sites where L_hazardous L_substances in L_excess of L_threshold L_limits are L_handled .

Such L_substances and L_thresholds L_include , for L_instance , 25 L_tonnes of L_flammable L_liquid L_petroleum L_gas and the L_explosive L_sodium L_chlorate , and 10 L_tonnes of L_toxic L_chlorine L_gas .
Some 1600 L_installations are L_notifiable , along with L_thousands of L_kilometres of L_pipelines ( L_mostly L_high-pressure L_natural L_gas L_transmission L_lines ) .

L_Following a L_number of L_major L_accidents L_involving L_industrial L_activities ( L_including those at L_Flixborough , L_Humberside in 1974 ; L_Beek , the L_Netherlands in 1975 ; and L_Seveso and L_Manfredonia in L_Italy in 1976 ) , the L_EC L_issued a L_Directive on L_Major L_Accident L_Hazards .

The L_Directive , which is L_commonly L_referred to as the ‘ L_Seveso ’ L_Directive , was L_issued in L_June 1982 and in the L_UK its L_requirements were L_embodied in the L_Control of L_Major L_Accident L_Hazard ( L_CIMAH ) L_Regulations ( 1984 ) .

Among other L_things , these L_regulations L_require L_operators of L_hazardous L_installations to L_draw up L_on-site and L_off-site L_emergency L_plans and to L_give L_information to L_members of the L_public who L_live or L_work near such L_installations ( L_Houston 1987 ) .
There are L_presently about 300 L_CIMAH L_sites .
L_However , L_many L_potentially L_hazardous L_chemical L_installations are not L_covered by such L_regulations .

L_Clearly , a L_plant which L_stores 1 L_tonne L_less than is L_required for L_notification L_slips through the L_net , while L_large L_numbers of L_handling L_sites ( L_warehouses , for L_instance ) are not L_covered .
The L_regulations have L_obvious L_implications for G1S L_work , as L_illustrated below .
In L_Halton L_Borough , L_Cheshire , for L_instance , there are 13 L_notifiable L_installations , with over 20 000 L_people L_living within the L_defined ‘ L_consultation L_zones ’ ( L_Petts 1988 ) .

It is L_also L_relevant to L_point out here the L_work of the L_Health and L_Safety L_Executive in L_developing L_techniques for L_quantitative L_risk L_assessment ( L_Health and L_Safety L_Executive 1989 ) .

Such L_techniques L_include the L_use of a ‘ L_risk L_assessment L_tool ’ ( L_RISKAT ) , L_inputs to which L_include L_data on L_wind L_direction and L_speed ; the L_output of which is a L_map of L_calculated L_risk L_contours .
In L_societal L_risk L_assessment ‘ it is L_also L_necessary to L_input L_data on the L_distribution of L_population around the L_installation .
This can be a L_difficult and L_time-consuming L_process , and L_inevitably some L_simplifying L_assumptions are L_needed ’ ( L_Health and L_Safety L_Executive 1989 : 17 ) .
Again , the G1S L_implications are L_clear and are L_discussed below .
L_Hazardous L_waste L_disposal
The L_disposal of both L_nuclear and L_non-nuclear L_wastes has L_proved to be of L_major L_public L_concern in L_recent L_years .

The L_rather L_clumsy L_handling by L_NIREX of the L_search for L_sites to L_store L_low- and L_intermediate-level L_wastes , L_together with very L_recent L_worries about the L_import of L_toxic L_wastes such as L_polychlorinated L_biphenyls ( L_PCBs ) , are but two L_examples of such L_concern in the L_UK .

L_However , while the L_former has been L_given L_considerable L_attention by L_geographers ( L_summarized by L_Openshaw L_et al. 1989 ) there has been L_relatively L_little such L_work in the L_UK on the L_disposal of L_non-nuclear L_wastes .
This L_contrasts with the L_situation in the L_USA ( L_Greenberg and L_Anderson 1984 ) , where the L_clean-up of L_abandoned L_sites is a L_priority .

L_Certainly , in L_terms of the L_volume of L_waste L_generated in the L_UK L_non-nuclear L_hazardous L_industrial L_wastes should be L_high on the L_environmental L_agenda ; while L_less than 1 million L_tonnes of all L_nuclear L_wastes were L_generated in 1985–86 , 10 L_times that L_amount were L_generated of L_hazardous L_wastes ( L_Openshaw et al. 1989 : 13 ) .

L_Attention should be L_drawn to the three L_Annual L_Reports of the L_Hazardous L_Waste L_Inspectorate ( now L_merged with other L_branches of the L_DoE to L_form Her L_Majesty 's L_Inspectorate of L_Pollution ) .

These L_contain some L_valuable L_material on L_disposal L_practices , and L_volumes of L_waste L_generated and L_disposed of by each L_waste L_regulation L_authority ( L_WRA ) — L_counties in L_England , L_districts in L_Wales , L_Scotland and L_Northern L_Ireland .
Each L_WRA is L_required to L_produce a L_waste L_disposal L_plan and these are L_starting to L_appear .

They too L_contain L_useful L_material on , for L_instance , the L_locations of L_sites , though L_individual L_site L_licences must be L_consulted for L_details of what each is L_permitted to L_take in the L_way of L_hazardous L_wastes .

What is not L_known is L_information on the L_locations of L_former L_sites , at which L_quite L_toxic L_materials may have been L_dumped , though L_recent L_work by L_Egger ( 1989 ) in L_Austria has L_mapped a L_vast L_number of such L_sites .
It is these , L_rather than L_existing , L_licensed L_sites which should be a L_focus of L_research L_activity , L_particularly when L_examining L_possible L_links to L_ill L_health .

We L_simply do not have L_enough L_evidence L_yet to L_back up the L_claim that ‘ L_people are L_almost L_certainly L_ill , L_dead , or L_dying because of these L_sloppy L_waste L_disposal L_activities ’ ( L_Openshaw et al. 1989 : 12 ) .
L_Research is in L_progress , L_however , to L_assess L_possible L_health L_effects of L_poor L_incineration ( L_Diggle L_et al. 1990 ) .

L_Particular L_attention should be L_focused on L_hospital L_incinerators , since these have been L_subject to L_Crown L_immunity for L_many L_years and most are L_technically L_ill-equipped to L_burn at L_sufficiently L_high L_temperatures for L_adequate L_disposal of L_wastes ( L_Gatrell and L_Lovett 1991 ) .
We L_need to L_produce an L_inventory of all such L_sites , L_together with a L_publicly L_available , L_comprehensive L_database on all L_sites L_accepting L_hazardous L_industrial L_wastes .
L_Emergency L_planning
It is L_convenient to L_retain the nuclear/non-nuclear L_distinction when L_discussing the L_background to L_emergency L_planning .
L_Nuclear L_emergency L_planning in the L_UK has been L_reviewed by L_Matthews and L_Pepper ( 1981 ) .
L_Nuclear L_power L_stations must L_prepare a L_plan and L_submit this to the L_Nuclear L_Installations L_Inspectorate and L_Health and L_Safety L_Executive for L_approval .
L_Evacuation L_plans are L_required to L_cover an L_area within a L_distance of 2.4 L_km ; these L_detail the L_roles to be L_played by the L_emergency L_services .

The very L_narrow L_emergency L_planning L_zones L_contrast with those in the L_USA ( L_Collins 1981 ) , where L_planning is L_required up to 16 L_km from the L_site to L_cover L_exposure to L_radiation L_plumes .

L_Local L_authorities in the L_UK that have L_declared themselves ‘ L_nuclear-free ’ have been L_highly L_critical of L_British L_planning , L_calling for an L_extension of L_emergency L_zones to at L_least 24 L_km .
L_Zeigler L_et al. ( 1983 ) should be L_consulted for L_material L_relating to L_evacuation L_behaviour in the L_wake of the L_incident at L_Three L_Mile L_Island .

In the L_UK L_little L_work of any L_description L_seems to have been done on L_human L_behaviour in the L_aftermath of L_releases of L_hazardous L_substances , nor is L_much L_available on L_public L_attitudes to L_emergency L_planning .

L_Indeed , no L_major L_studies of L_evacuation L_due to L_hazards have been L_undertaken in L_recent L_times and this is a L_widely L_recognized L_deficiency which no L_research L_funding L_body L_seems L_willing to L_rectify .
In the L_USA on the other L_hand , a L_good L_deal of L_useful L_research in these L_areas has been L_undertaken .

This L_research is L_brought L_together in very L_useful L_reports L_produced by the L_Oak L_Ridge L_National L_Laboratory , L_Tennessee ( L_Sorenson et al. 1987 ; L_Vogt and L_Sorenson 1987 ) and the L_Disaster L_Research L_Centre , L_University of L_Delaware .
L_Perry ( 1985 ) has L_written an L_interesting L_book on L_emergency L_planning and L_evacuation , L_covering both L_natural and L_technological L_hazards .
For him , L_comprehensive L_emergency L_planning and L_management L_involve : L_prevention , L_protection , L_response and L_restoration .
By L_prevention we L_understand the L_elimination or L_reduction in L_risk , L_perhaps by L_adequate L_zoning or L_safe L_routeing of L_shipments , for L_instance .
L_Included in L_protection are L_methods for L_detecting L_likely L_hazard L_events and in L_warning those L_likely to be L_affected .

L_Response L_includes L_search and L_rescue ( L_including the L_need to L_cope with L_secondary L_threats such as L_contamination of L_water L_supplies after an L_explosion , or L_fire L_following an L_earthquake ) .
As L_Perry and L_others have L_noted , L_relatively few L_resources are L_devoted to the L_first two L_aspects , the L_bulk L_going to L_response and L_restoration ( L_rebuilding ) .
It should be L_clear from this L_brief L_description that these L_issues are L_inherently L_geographical .
In one of the few L_studies of L_evacuation L_behaviour after a L_non-nuclear L_hazard L_event L_Liverman and L_Wilson ( 1981 ) L_give L_weight to this L_argument .
In 1979 a L_train L_carrying L_chlorine , L_liquid L_petroleum , L_toluene and L_propane was L_derailed in L_Mississauga , L_Ontario , L_causing a L_series of L_explosions .
This L_led to the L_evacuation of 250 000 L_people which , although L_staggered over L_several L_days , L_led to L_great L_pressure on L_transport L_arteries .

An L_important L_finding was that L_many L_relied on their own L_transport and L_went to L_stay with L_friends and L_relatives some L_distance L_away , L_rather than L_relying on the 19 L_official L_evacuation L_reception L_centres .
Despite this , the L_evacuation was L_successful , L_partly because the L_accident L_occurred at a L_weekend and the L_immediately L_affected L_area was L_sparsely L_populated .

In L_addition , the L_police were L_well L_prepared , L_stimulated L_largely by L_implementing a L_plan L_designed more to L_cope with an L_emergency at the L_nearby L_Toronto L_International L_Airport than for the L_event in L_question .

It is not without L_interest to L_note that in the L_USA there is a L_Federal L_Emergency L_Management L_Agency ( L_FEMA ) , L_established in 1978 , L_charged with L_dealing with all L_types of L_emergency L_planning and L_management .

In the L_UK there is no L_equivalent , though the L_spate of L_disasters in the L_past 4 L_years ( L_involving over 1000 L_lives L_lost ) has L_led to L_several L_calls for such a L_national L_body to be L_established .
L_Natural L_hazards
In this L_short L_space it is not L_possible to L_go into any L_depth on the L_nature of L_particular L_natural L_hazards but only to L_highlight those L_aspects L_relevant to L_GIS .

L_Needless to L_say , the L_study of L_natural L_hazards is L_important , a L_statement L_brought into L_sharp L_focus by the L_fact that L_natural L_hazards L_account for up to 4 per L_cent of L_total L_deaths in the L_world each L_year ( L_Mitchell , 1974 ) .

In 1970 , for L_example , more than 200 000 L_people L_died in the L_cyclone and L_flooding of L_Bangladesh and in 1979 the L_hurricanes L_David and L_Frederick L_caused more than $3bn L_damage in the L_USA .

L_Shah ( 1983 ) L_made a L_comprehensive L_investigation of L_natural L_disaster L_reports for the L_period 1974–80 and L_concluded that both L_disaster L_frequency and L_magnitude ( L_measured in L_terms of L_lives L_lost ) are L_increasing .
L_High L_death L_tolls are L_still a L_characteristic of L_less L_developed , L_low-income L_countries .
L_Surprisingly , L_fog is the L_third most L_important L_hazard in L_Europe after L_floods and L_volcanoes .
L_Research on L_natural L_hazards has a L_long L_tradition in L_geography L_going L_back more than half a L_century .
L_Much of the L_impetus for such L_research L_arose in the L_USA from L_observations on L_river L_basin L_management and the L_need to L_reduce L_flood L_damage .

The L_vast L_majority of L_natural L_hazards L_studies have L_ignored the L_physical L_nature of the L_events per se and have L_concentrated on L_behavioural L_issues such as the L_perception and L_estimation of L_hazards .

This L_emphasis is L_partly L_due to the L_background of the L_researchers L_involved ( L_many are L_human L_geographers and L_sociologists ) and L_partly because it is only L_really since the L_Second L_World L_War that L_major L_hazards have been L_monitored L_systematically , L_culminating , of L_course , in the L_last L_decade or so in the L_use of L_satellite L_technology .
L_Brief L_reference to two L_examples of L_natural L_hazards may L_illustrate the L_potential L_relevance of a L_GIS L_approach , L_applications of which are L_considered below .
L_Jones et al. ( 1989 ) have L_examined the L_distribution of some 8500 L_landslides in the L_UK .
Their L_maps L_show L_clearly an L_increased L_propensity for L_landsliding in the L_north and L_west of the L_UK .
More to the L_point , L_however , is the L_fact that this L_distribution can be L_modelled in L_terms of L_slopes , L_rainfall , L_rock L_types and so on .
In other L_words the L_actual L_hazard L_distribution can be L_understood and L_areas at L_risk L_identified .
The L_potential L_benefits to L_insurance L_companies , L_engineers and L_planners are L_clear .
L_Second , a L_well-known L_winter L_hazard in the L_UK , with L_marked L_spatial L_localization , is L_fog .
L_Predictive L_models of its L_distribution have L_clear L_implications for L_road and L_air L_safety .

L_Perry ( 1981 ) L_describes a L_fog L_potential L_index that is a L_function of L_local L_topography , L_environmental L_features L_affecting L_fog L_formation and L_distance from L_standing L_water L_bodies .

L_Reliance is L_currently L_placed on a L_network of L_monitoring L_stations , L_often L_sparsely L_located and L_frequently outside L_fog-prone L_areas ; L_GIS could L_implement a L_predictive L_model L_based on L_digitized L_map L_features and L_indeed the L_model could L_also be L_used in L_site L_allocation L_studies for L_airports and the L_like .
The L_majority of L_natural L_hazard L_research has L_focused on L_single L_hazards but of L_course any L_area may be L_prone to more than one L_hazard L_type .
This L_idea L_led L_Hewitt and L_Burton ( 1971 ) to L_develop the L_concept of ‘ L_all-hazards-at-a-place ’ .
To L_achieve this they L_concentrated on the M_whole L_spectrum of L_damaging L_events in an L_area and L_explored their L_aggregate L_impact .

The L_implications for L_GIS in the L_development of ‘ L_hazardousness ’ L_indices are L_obvious and if L_time-series L_data are L_available there is the L_potential to L_produce a L_variety of L_probability L_maps .
The L_collection of L_historical L_data on L_natural L_hazards is L_important since it is L_clear that their L_spatial L_pattern L_varies through L_time .
L_Many L_areas that L_appear to be L_hazard-free on L_current L_maps may L_merely by L_passing through a L_temporary L_period of L_quiescence .
This is L_perhaps L_best L_illustrated with L_reference to L_earthquakes .

For L_example , in 1692 , the L_whole of L_southern L_England was L_affected by an L_earthquake whose L_epicentre was L_located in what is now L_Belgium ; a L_good L_deal of L_minor L_structural L_damage was L_inflicted ( L_Morse 1983 ) .
L_Presumably the L_builders of the L_Channel L_Tunnel are L_aware of this ?
L_Environmental L_epidemiology
This is , of L_course , a L_vast L_subject L_area , L_embracing the L_impact of the L_natural and L_technological L_environments on L_human L_health .

It L_covers , for L_instance , the L_associations between L_water and L_air L_pollution and L_ill L_health , L_links between L_geological and L_pedological L_environments and L_ill L_health , as L_well as L_associations between L_specific L_technological L_hazards ( e.g. L_high-voltage L_power L_lines ) and L_possible L_health L_effects .
We can only L_consider a L_small L_fraction of this L_work here ; L_little L_consideration is L_given to L_occupational L_environments , for L_instance .

In the L_UK such L_research is L_widespread though there are L_specialist L_environmental L_epidemiology L_research L_institutes at L_Southampton and L_Cardiff ( L_funded by the L_Medical L_Research L_Council ) , and L_others at the L_University of L_Surrey ( L_Robens L_Institute ) and at the L_London L_School for L_Hygiene and L_Tropical L_Medicine .

The L_latter L_houses the L_Small L_Area L_Health L_Statistics L_Research L_Unit ( L_SAHSRU ) , which has a L_specific L_remit to L_conduct L_research into L_morbidity and L_mortality at L_local L_scales ( L_Elliot 1988 ) .
The L_SAHSRU L_liaises L_closely with L_OPCS .
The L_kinds of L_databases L_used by these L_groups are L_discussed below .
L_Greenberg ( 1983 ) and a L_collection of L_papers in L_Greenberg ( 1987 ) L_review some of the L_literature on L_environmental L_epidemiology .
It L_seems L_worth L_stating at the L_outset that there are two L_ways L_geographical L_research in this L_general L_area can L_proceed .

One is to L_collect L_morbidity and L_mortality L_data ( L_usually the L_latter is more L_widely L_available , though the L_former more L_useful ) and to L_examine L_spatial L_distributions for L_clustering .

This has itself L_generated a L_substantial L_literature ( L_see the L_papers in L_Elliot 1988 for an L_overview ) and is L_nowhere L_better L_exemplified than in L_Openshaw 's L_geographical L_analysis L_machine ( L_see Ch. 2 ) .
We then L_search L_retrospectively for L_evidence of L_possible L_environmental L_associations .
An L_alternative L_approach is to L_begin by L_hypothesizing an L_environmental L_determinant of L_ill L_health and to L_collect L_data to L_test an L_explicit L_hypothesis .
If an L_association is L_suggested then we would L_want to L_collect L_data in other L_areas to L_assess the L_hypothesis further .
Of L_course , these two L_approaches are not L_clear-cut in L_practice ; in L_many L_cases the L_hypotheses of L_interest will have themselves been L_generated by L_inductive L_mapping .

One L_example of an L_hypothesis which has been L_given L_serious L_attention in L_recent L_years is the L_possible L_link between L_electromagnetic L_fields L_generated by L_high-voltage L_power L_lines or L_supply L_cables and L_ill L_health .

Some L_work ( L_Perry et al. 1981 ) L_suggested L_associations with L_mental L_illness and L_suicide , while L_others ( e.g. L_Wertheimer and L_Leeper 1982 ) have L_examined L_links to L_various L_cancers , L_including L_leukaemias .
A L_good L_bibliography is L_provided in L_Perry and L_Pearl ( 1988 ) .

The L_Central L_Electricity L_Generating L_Board ( now L_privatized and L_split into two L_companies ) is L_funding a L_large-scale , 2-year L_project to L_assess L_links to L_childhood L_cancer , while another L_recently L_announced L_study L_aims to L_look at L_links to L_sudden L_infant L_death .

One L_obvious L_problem , with L_implications for any L_GIS L_input , is that the L_effects are L_highly L_localized , with L_little L_measurable L_field L_effect more than a few L_dozen L_metres L_away from the L_route L_centre-lines .
L_Accuracy of L_digital L_data L_collection ( either of the L_power L_lines or L_residential L_locations ) is L_paramount .
There L_seems to be a L_growing L_interest in L_examining L_associations between L_ill L_health and the L_geological L_environment .

L_GIS L_work in this L_field ( e.g. L_Matthews 1989 ) is L_reviewed L_later , but we L_note here the L_work of the L_applied L_geochemistry L_group at L_Imperial L_College ( L_responsible for a L_series of L_atlases on L_regional L_geochemistry ) and the L_existence of a L_Society for L_Environmental L_Geochemistry and L_Health .
One L_area of L_recent L_debate L_concerns L_radon L_gas and its L_links to L_lung L_cancer .

This is L_taken very L_seriously in the L_USA , where the L_Environmental L_Protection L_Agency L_estimates that 10 000–20 000 L_deaths from L_lung L_cancer each L_year are L_due to L_radon L_gas L_exposure .
L_Estimates from L_Scandinavia L_suggest that 10–30 per L_cent of such L_deaths are L_caused by L_exposure to L_radon ( L_Richardson 1988 : 270–81 ) .

The L_gas is L_trapped in L_well-insulated L_houses and is L_produced by the L_decay of L_uranium in L_rocks and L_soil ; L_thus it has been L_measured at L_high L_concentrations in L_parts of L_Cornwall and L_Devon .
There are L_great L_difficulties in L_assessing L_health L_effects , L_however , since L_exposure L_varies L_greatly from L_house to L_house within L_small L_neighbourhoods .

L_Carefully L_designed L_case-control L_studies are L_therefore L_required to L_measure the L_separate L_effect of L_radon L_exposure after L_controlling for L_smoking L_behaviour and other L_risk L_factors .
Other L_health L_concerns which might L_merit L_attention by those L_involved in the L_Regional L_Research L_Laboratory ( L_RRL ) L_initiative L_include L_air and L_water L_pollution .

The L_debate about L_lead L_pollution from L_vehicle L_exhaust L_emissions is L_well L_known ; L_less L_publicity has been L_given to L_PAHs ( L_polychlorinated L_aromatic L_hydrocarbons ) , a L_product of L_combustion L_processes and L_known to be L_carcinogenic ( L_Lioy and L_Daisey 1987 ) .

L_Research at the L_North L_West L_Regional L_Research L_Laboratory ( L_NWRRL ) L_aims to L_create L_buffers around L_busy L_roads and L_junctions and to L_use L_data from the L_Cancer L_Registry to L_examine L_possible L_links between L_proximity to such L_sources of L_pollution and L_prevalence of L_lung L_cancer .

Those with an L_interest in L_health and L_air L_pollution should L_note the L_availability of a very L_detailed L_database from the L_Warren L_Springs L_Laboratory , L_containing L_details of L_smoke and L_sulphur L_dioxide L_emissions at a L_large L_number of L_sites in the L_UK .

The L_possible L_link between L_nitrates in L_water and L_stomach L_cancer is the L_subject of L_much L_debate ( L_Beresford 1985 ) , as is the L_association between L_aluminium L_content and L_Alzheimer 's L_disease .
The L_problems of L_assessing such L_links are , of L_course , L_huge , but there is L_scope for a L_contribution .
The L_role of L_GIS in L_hazard L_management L_scenarios — L_examples

As we have L_already L_implied , L_GIS has a L_role to L_play in all L_aspects of L_hazard L_research , from L_hazard L_monitoring , L_risk L_assessment and L_emergency L_planning to L_coping with an L_event and L_evaluating its L_consequences .

The L_examples L_described below L_illustrate all these , though as L_yet there do not L_appear to be L_many L_instances of L_disasters in the L_management of which L_GIS has L_played a L_significant L_part .
L_Technological L_hazards , L_emergency L_planning and L_GIS
A L_considerable L_amount of L_research has been L_undertaken to L_apply L_GIS L_methods to L_evacuation L_scenarios around L_hazardous L_sites .
L_Much of this L_research has L_concentrated on L_network L_analysis of the L_road L_system .
L_Reference was L_made above to L_so-called L_CIMAH L_sites , L_major L_hazardous L_installations for which L_on-site and L_off-site L_emergency L_plans must be L_prepared .

L_Early L_research at the L_NWRRL L_focused on L_developing a L_GIS for L_use by the L_police and L_county L_emergency L_planning L_officers in L_Cumbria that would L_aid in the L_management of a L_possible L_explosion at a L_chemical L_factory in L_Whitehaven , L_west L_Cumbria ( L_Vincent et al. 1988 ; L_Dunn 1989 ) .
The L_police L_required a L_portable L_system that could be L_implemented on an L_IBM-compatible L_microcomputer .
This was L_written at the L_NWRRL L_using L_FORTRAN 77 and the L_Graphical L_Kernel L_System .
The L_GIS is L_menu-based and is L_exceptionally L_user-friendly ( Pl. 10.1 ) .
It L_opens with an L_outline L_map and the L_superimposition of the L_rather L_rigid L_zones L_used by the L_emergency L_planners .
L_Full L_zoom L_facilities are L_available at any L_stage .
In any L_emergency it is of L_course L_vital to have L_high-quality L_data on the L_distribution of L_population and L_resources .
The L_system L_incorporates L_digitized L_data on the L_distribution of all L_domestic and L_non-domestic L_properties in the L_town L_together with L_digitized L_road L_centre-line L_data .
Both L_sets of L_data were L_provided by L_Pinpoint L_Analysis L_Ltd , who are L_undertaking this L_digitizing L_task for the L_entire L_country .

Other L_spatially L_referenced L_data L_incorporated into the L_system L_include those on the L_distribution of L_schools , L_medical and L_transport L_services which can be L_displayed and L_supplementary L_information about them L_obtained .
The L_GIS L_permits L_population L_estimates to be L_made for any L_arbitrary L_rectangular L_region on the L_map .
Most L_significantly , it L_incorporates a L_shortest L_path L_algorithm which L_uses the L_road L_network to L_find L_optimal L_routes between L_user-defined L_start and L_end L_nodes .

Although L_predating the L_RRL L_initiative by L_several L_years — and , L_indeed the L_emergence of L_GIS as a L_major L_research L_area — we should L_remind ourselves of L_Openshaw 's L_work on L_appraising L_nuclear L_reactor L_sites .

L_Using what would now be L_called L_GIS L_skills , L_Openshaw ( 1980 ) L_examined over 13 000 1 L_km L_grid L_squares in the L_UK which L_intersect the L_coastline and L_related these to L_data from the 1971 L_Census ( which were L_made L_available for such L_grid L_squares ) .
He L_demonstrated that there is an L_abundance of ‘ L_remote ’ L_sites , in L_contrast to the L_official L_view that such L_sites were L_increasingly L_hard to L_find .

He L_suggested that in L_early L_spatial L_searches for L_sites ‘ only a L_small L_number were L_ever L_identified in the L_first L_place because L_rigorous L_searches could not be L_performed by L_manual L_means with L_poor L_quality L_data ’ ( L_Openshaw 1980 : 289 ) .

L_Heywood and L_Cornelius ( 1989 ) have L_shown how L_GIS can be L_used for L_monitoring L_possible L_radiation L_releases and L_thus the L_relevance of L_GIS in L_nuclear L_emergency L_planning and L_monitoring .

They L_propose a L_national L_radiological L_spatial L_information L_system and , in a L_pilot L_project in L_Cumbria , have L_integrated L_several L_layers of L_data within ARC/INFO to L_show what this might L_involve ( Fig. 10.2 ) .
Such L_data L_include those from the L_Population and L_Agricultural L_Censuses as L_well as L_point L_data from L_rain L_gauge L_sites and L_radiation L_monitoring L_stations .
As an L_example , the L_system is L_used to L_determine L_restriction L_zones for the L_movement of L_sheep after the L_explosion at L_Chernobyl in 1986 .
This is done by L_finding L_areas of L_high L_rainfall and L_parishes with L_high L_sheep L_populations .

The L_map L_overlay of L_point and L_area L_information L_shows L_generally L_good L_agreement with the L_restriction L_zones L_imposed by the L_Ministry of L_Agriculture , L_Fisheries and L_Food , with the L_exception of a L_small L_area to the L_south-east of L_Cumbria , L_bordering on L_Lancashire .
The L_British L_government L_carried out a L_review of its L_arrangements for L_handling L_nuclear L_accidents L_overseas L_following the L_Chernobyl L_accident .

The L_DoE , through Her L_Majesty 's L_Inspectorate of L_Pollution ( L_HMIP ) , was L_given the L_task of L_co-ordinating a L_national L_response L_plan , L_installing the L_radiation L_monitoring L_network and L_acting as L_lead L_government L_department in an L_emergency ( L_HMSO 1988 ) .

The L_monitoring L_network has L_become L_known as the L_radioactive L_incident L_monitoring L_network ( L_RIMNET ) and has , as its L_prime L_responsibility , the L_detection of L_abnormal L_increases in L_radiation L_levels within the L_UK of the L_kind that might L_arise from an L_overseas L_nuclear L_accident .
The L_full L_implementation of the L_RIMNET L_system will L_take some L_time .
By the L_end of 1988 L_gamma L_radiation L_dose L_monitors had been L_installed at 46 L_meteorological L_stations as L_part of L_phase 1 of the L_development L_programme .
L_Radiation L_readings are L_taken every L_hour at each L_station and are L_transmitted to a L_central L_computer which L_analyses the L_data .
The L_current L_criterion for L_alert is two L_readings of more than three L_times L_normal L_background , either L_successively at the same L_site or L_simultaneously at two L_adjacent L_sites .

The L_dissemination of L_information in the L_event of an L_incident is L_dealt with at three L_levels : the L_first is the L_normal L_system of L_press L_notices ; the L_second is the L_use of L_teletext and L_viewdata ( L_Ceefax and L_Prestel ) to L_get L_direct to L_members of the L_public at their L_homes or L_places of L_work ; the L_third is the L_use of L_Telecom L_Gold L_electronic L_mail to L_get more L_technical L_details to L_various L_official L_bodies , such as L_water L_authorities ( L_Jackson 1989 ) .
L_Phase 2 of the L_RIMNET L_scheme will be L_completed by the L_end of 1991 when between 80 and 90 L_monitoring L_sites will have been L_established .

L_Given very L_wide L_regional and L_local L_variations in L_deposition , L_questions must be L_raised about the L_effectiveness of such a L_small L_network ; L_local L_authorities will L_need to L_supplement it with their own L_networks .
There are L_important L_analytical L_problems to be L_addressed L_concerning the L_siting of such L_monitoring L_equipment and these are L_elaborated on L_later .

L_Abroad , L_Kaspar ( 1981 ) has L_discussed a L_computer-based L_exercise , with L_GIS L_overtones , L_involving the L_simulated L_evacuation of the L_population L_living in the L_vicinity of the L_Neckarwestheim L_nuclear L_power L_plant in L_Baden Württemberg .

In the L_scenario he L_outlines , an L_area L_affected by L_radioactive L_releases is L_determined , the L_population within that L_area is L_allocated to L_reception L_areas ( with L_capacity L_constraints ) , L_evacuation L_routes are L_identified and L_traffic L_restrictions L_implemented .
L_Little L_detail is L_provided , L_however , and it is L_thus L_difficult to L_evaluate his L_work L_fully .
L_Dangermond ( 1985 ) L_describes the L_use of the ARC/INFO L_NETWORK L_module for L_use in L_emergency L_planning L_situations .
He L_describes how a L_road L_network is L_digitized and L_subsequently L_analysed L_using L_allocation , L_districting and L_routeing L_algorithms .

L_Allocation L_determines which L_arcs in the L_network will be L_allocated to a L_particular L_node or L_centre ; L_districting L_makes it L_possible to L_outline L_rapidly L_sets of L_polygons in L_order to L_define L_specific L_areas of L_interest ( L_districts ) and to L_summarize their L_characteristics ; L_routeing L_provides a L_minimum L_path L_algorithm through the L_network , the L_arcs of which can be L_assigned L_weights L_according to L_road L_conditions , L_road L_capacity and so on .

L_Dangermond L_gives L_several L_examples in his L_paper L_including the L_use of L_NETWORK for the L_allocation of L_emergency L_vehicles , L_optimum L_routeing of L_fire L_engines from L_garages to the L_accident L_scene and the L_movement of L_spills through L_sewers and L_river L_networks .
When L_combined with the other L_facilities in ARC/INFO , L_quite L_complex L_disaster L_management L_scenarios can be L_handled .

For L_example , L_earthquake L_fault L_zones can be L_combined with L_data on L_housing L_density and L_structural L_details to L_predict L_earthquake L_damage L_levels and these L_data then L_related to the L_network L_model .

L_Vincent ( 1989 ) L_illustrates the L_use of ARC/INFO and its L_NETWORK L_module for L_finding L_safe L_routes for L_chlorine L_transhipment on the L_road and L_rail L_systems of L_north-west L_England ( Pl. 10.2 ) .

In this L_case , L_population L_density L_data for a 1 L_km L_buffer on either L_side of L_network L_arcs were L_overlaid on the L_network itself so as to L_act as L_weights for the L_minimum L_path L_algorithm .
L_Chosen L_routes were those which L_minimized L_population L_rather than L_distance .
L_Hazardous L_waste L_disposal

There can be L_little L_doubt that a L_GIS L_approach has L_wide L_applicability in all L_sorts of L_location L_problems where the L_goal is to L_minimize ( L_rather than , as L_conventionally , L_maximize ) L_accessibility to a L_population .
A L_particularly L_good L_application is to the L_search for L_potential L_sites for the L_disposal of L_nuclear and L_non-nuclear ( but L_none the L_less L_hazardous ) L_wastes .
We L_discuss here some L_relevant L_work on the L_siting of L_facilities for the L_disposal of L_nuclear L_wastes before L_examining those for L_non-nuclear L_wastes .

The L_major L_contribution to L_informed L_debate about the L_search for L_sites for the L_disposal of L_nuclear L_wastes has L_come from a L_group of L_geographers ( L_Openshaw et al. 1989 ) and a L_GIS L_approach to this L_problem can L_pay L_high L_dividends .
The L_work of L_Carver ( L_see L_Openshaw et al. 1989 : Ch. 7 ) is an L_interesting L_example .
One L_advantage is the L_ability to L_model a L_range of L_alternatives by L_allowing L_particular L_criteria to L_enter or be L_omitted from the L_polygon L_overlay L_operation .

L_Conceptually , what is L_offered is L_little more than an L_automated ‘ L_sieve L_mapping ’ that L_land-use L_planners have L_used for L_many L_years , but the M_whole L_procedure is L_speeded up by L_many L_orders of L_magnitude L_using L_GIS L_software .
The L_authors L_examine both L_near-surface L_sites and L_deep L_repositories ( which L_use more L_restricted L_population L_criteria and L_allow L_offshore L_locations to L_enter ) .
L_Data L_layers L_include L_geological L_maps , L_conservation L_areas , L_transport L_routes , L_petrochemical L_facilities and L_demographic L_data .

As L_different L_layers are L_added L_sequentially we L_see how the L_proportion of L_available L_land L_shrinks ( Pl. 10.3 ) ; for L_instance , when L_geological L_criteria are L_set in the L_search for a L_deep L_repository , 25 per L_cent of L_land L_area L_remains and the L_addition of the L_population L_density L_layer L_reduces this to 24 per L_cent .
L_However , L_adding a L_proximity to L_transport L_constraint L_lowers this to 12 per L_cent ; and so on .

We can not L_pretend L_GIS is a L_solution to the L_political L_problems of L_negotiation and L_justification but at the very L_least the L_openness of the L_procedures L_goes some L_way towards L_satisfying a L_worried L_public .
L_GIS L_research into L_site L_selection for L_non-nuclear L_hazardous L_waste has been L_almost L_exclusively L_conducted in L_North L_America and has L_yet to be L_matched in the L_UK .

L_Jensen and L_Christiansen ( 1986 ) , L_working in the L_south-eastern L_USA , L_use a L_raster L_approach ( with a L_pixel L_resolution of 20 m&sup2 ; ) and L_Boolean L_overlay to ‘ L_weed out ’ L_particular L_sites , such as those which are L_poorly L_drained , L_environmentally L_sensitive or L_inaccessible ( L_see L_also L_Stewart 1987 ) .
L_Environmental L_monitoring of L_sites for the L_disposal of L_toxic L_waste is of L_particular L_concern in the L_USA .

The L_Comprehensive L_Environmental L_Response , L_Compensation and L_Liability L_Act ( L_CERCLA ) L_legislation of 1980 ( ‘ L_Superfund ’ ) L_requires the L_cleaning up of the L_worst L_landfill L_sites , of which some 800 had been L_identified by the L_Environmental L_Protection L_Agency by 1986 ( L_Foresman 1986 ) .

A L_major L_worry has been the L_threat L_posed by L_groundwater L_pollution and some L_research has been L_conducted on L_using L_GIS to L_monitor this ( L_Merchant et al. 1987 ; L_Barringer et al. 1987 ; L_von L_Braun 1988 ) .

This is an L_important L_topic since 95 per L_cent of L_rural L_households in the L_USA L_consume only L_groundwater , while half the L_US L_population L_consumes at L_least some L_groundwater ( L_Merchant et al. 1987 ) .
L_Clearly , the L_research L_demands L_access to L_exceptionally L_good L_environmental L_data , L_usually in three L_dimensions .
As L_Foresman ( 1986 ) L_suggests , we might L_expect L_remote L_sensing L_technology to L_play a L_major L_role .

L_Merchant et al. ( 1987 ) for L_example , L_use the L_image L_processing L_system L_ERDAS to L_construct an L_index of L_vulnerability to L_groundwater L_pollution ; this L_uses L_variables such as L_depth to L_water L_table , L_soil L_type , L_slope and so on ( L_see L_Estes L_et al. 1987 for a L_similar L_approach ) .

L_Barringer L_et al. ( 1987 ) L_overlay L_data on L_soil L_type and L_geology with that of L_groundwater L_quality ( L_hardness and L_corrosivity L_measures ) and L_build a L_linear L_model which L_shows that the L_background L_environmental L_variables are L_good L_predictors of the L_water L_quality L_indices .
Again , a L_raster-based L_approach is L_used .

A further L_example is L_work by L_von L_Braun ( 1988 ) who L_uses L_pMAP to L_look at L_exposure of L_organic and L_metallic L_compounds in L_groundwater in the L_vicinity of L_Tucson L_airport , L_Arizona .

L_Using L_plume L_models that L_predict the L_movement of L_contaminants she is L_able to L_intersect the L_results with L_data on L_current L_well L_locations and to L_assess which L_water L_supply L_areas are L_worst L_contaminated .

L_Overlaying the L_results with L_residential L_location L_data L_provides ‘ L_maps L_delineating L_location-specific L_exposures for each L_residence in each L_time-period ’ ( L_von L_Braun 1988 ; 1160 ) .
In L_principle , it is then L_possible to L_compare such ‘ L_doses ’ with L_epidemiological L_data , once again L_indicating a L_link from a L_hazard L_event to L_assessment of L_health L_outcomes .

L_Attention should be L_drawn to L_Foresman 's L_comment that the L_US L_Geological L_Survey ( L_USGS ) ( at the L_EROS L_Data L_Centre ) have L_successfully L_linked ARC/INFO to a L_model of L_groundwater L_flow ( L_Foresman 1986 : 260 ) .
This L_kind of L_link between L_GIS and other L_modelling L_programs is to be L_warmly L_welcomed and L_parallels L_work at the L_NWRRL in L_linking L_GIS and L_air L_pollution L_plume L_models .
L_Natural L_hazards and L_disaster L_management
L_Several L_studies in L_recent L_papers have L_shown the L_effectiveness of L_GIS in L_mitigating the L_effects of L_major L_natural L_hazards .
L_Berke and L_Ruch ( 1985 ) , for L_example , L_describe a L_GIS for L_assessing the L_impacts of L_hurricanes on the L_Texas L_Gulf L_coast .
L_Hurricane L_damage through L_high L_winds and L_tidal L_surges L_causes an L_immense L_amount of L_destruction and L_poses a L_major L_threat to L_many L_coastal L_communities in the L_USA .

It has been L_estimated , for L_example , that during the L_mid 1970s some 50 million L_US L_citizens were L_subject to L_hurricane L_winds of over 160 km/h and 6 million were L_subject to L_hurricane L_surge ( L_Brinkman 1975 ) .

The L_system L_described by L_Berke and L_Ruch ( 1985 ) is L_raster-based and has an L_interesting L_modelling L_component L_called L_SLOSH ( L_Sea , L_Lake and L_Overland L_Surges from L_Hurricanes ) .

L_SLOSH is L_able to L_estimate L_still L_water L_surge by L_grid L_cell for L_various L_hurricane L_intensities , L_angles of L_approach to the L_shoreline , L_forward L_movement L_speeds and L_landfall L_locations .
L_Additional L_algorithms are L_used to L_model L_total L_building L_damage L_costs for each L_grid L_cell L_based on L_water-depth and L_speed-depth L_rating L_curves .

L_Hobeika and L_Jamei ( 1985 ) L_describe the L_MASSeVACuation ( L_MASSVAC ) L_simulation L_software L_designed to L_analyse and L_evaluate L_traffic L_evacuation L_plans L_given a L_natural L_disaster in an L_urban L_area .
The L_system L_comprises three L_interrelated L_modules : L_community and L_disaster L_type L_characteristics L_module ; L_population L_distribution L_module ; L_network L_evacuation L_module .
The L_type of L_natural L_disaster L_determines the L_time L_period within which the L_road L_network has to be L_evacuated .
The L_control and L_management L_strategies are L_directly L_correlated to each L_specific L_disaster L_scenario .

L_MASSVAC is L_quite L_flexible and L_various L_user-defined L_road L_network L_options are L_available such as : L_traffic L_signal L_timings on the L_road L_network ; L_one-way L_traffic ; L_reserved L_lanes for L_special L_vehicles such as those of the L_emergency L_services .

L_Hobeika and L_Jamei have L_tested L_MASSVAC on L_various L_evacuation L_scenarios for L_Virginia L_Beach L_City in L_order to L_determine L_evacuation L_times for L_flood and L_hurricane L_conditions .
In L_general , they L_suggest that the L_model L_provided L_reasonable and L_reliable L_evacuation L_times .
L_Southworth L_et al. ( 1989 ) have L_enhanced the L_MASSVAC L_model with the L_addition of a L_colour L_graphics L_module which they L_call L_MVOPL .
This L_module has been L_developed L_using L_IBM 's L_Graphics L_Kernel L_System and L_provides a L_number of L_display L_screens .
The most L_interesting are those which L_portray L_population L_flows as L_scaled L_ribbons on the L_network L_diagram , and L_evacuation L_shelter L_capacities as L_bar L_diagrams .
The L_diagrams are L_updated L_periodically during the L_course of the L_simulation .

In L_dry L_parts of the L_world , such as L_Australia , L_forest and L_bush L_fires are an L_important L_natural L_hazard and some L_attention has been L_given to the L_ways in which L_GIS might L_help L_examine their L_potential L_impacts .

L_Kessell ( 1988 ) L_describes a L_PC-based L_GIS L_called L_PREPLAN ( L_PRistine L_Environment L_Planning L_LANguage ) which is a L_natural L_area L_management , L_land-use L_planning and L_fire L_modelling L_system L_developed for the L_Australian L_National L_Parks and L_Wildlife L_Service , L_PREPLAN L_comprises four L_modules : a L_simple L_raster-based L_GIS ; a L_grid L_cell L_resource L_database ; a L_wide L_range of L_vegetation , L_fuel , L_fire L_behaviour , L_erosion and L_land-use L_models ; L_tabular , L_statistical and L_colour L_graphics L_output L_system .
With this L_system L_real-time L_fire L_growth can be L_modelled , L_taking into L_account L_changes in L_terrain , L_fuel and L_temporal L_changes in the L_weather .

L_Kessell L_points out that L_uncontrollable L_fires are L_recurrent L_phenomena in L_many L_parts of L_Australia , L_causing L_damage in the L_hundreds of L_millions of L_dollars and L_significant L_loss of L_life .
L_Systems such as L_PREPLAN can L_provide the L_user with L_sound L_models of the L_behaviour L_patterns of L_fire and are L_therefore of L_enormous L_value in L_land-use L_planning .
One of the most L_widespread L_natural L_hazards is L_flooding , and the L_potential for L_loss of L_property , L_risk to L_life and L_general L_social L_disruption is L_large .

One L_interesting L_example of a L_GIS L_approach to L_flood L_damage L_estimation is the L_ANUFLOOD L_package which was L_developed in the L_early 1980s L_following L_detailed L_flood L_damage L_studies for L_flood-prone L_coastal L_towns in L_northern L_New L_South L_Wales , L_Australia ( L_Smith and L_Greenaway , 1988 ) .

The L_ANUFLOOD L_system L_requires L_locational and L_building L_type L_data on L_individual L_properties , L_stage-damage L_curves L_relating the L_average L_damage that would L_result from L_overfloor L_flooding to L_differing L_depths for each L_property L_type , and L_lastly , L_flood L_frequency in L_terms of L_flood L_height L_expressed as a L_probability .
L_Output from the L_system is both L_tabular and L_graphical .
Of L_particular L_interest is the L_construction of L_maps L_showing the L_expected L_annual L_amounts of L_damage for L_gridded L_flood-prone L_areas .

L_ANUFLOOD L_also L_contains L_modules which L_permit the L_investigation of L_various L_flood L_damage L_mitigation L_options , such as L_property L_height L_raising , L_levee L_construction and L_flood L_proofing .
L_Environmental L_epidemiology
The L_possibilities L_sketched above L_relate to L_emergency L_planning , the L_search for L_hazardous L_sites , and L_risk L_assessment .
To what L_extent can L_GIS L_help if an L_event L_occurs ?
What , for L_instance , of the L_health L_consequences ?

There is a L_rich L_tradition of L_epidemiological L_work in L_geography and with the L_increasing L_availability of L_spatially L_referenced L_medical L_data the L_scope for L_GIS L_applications is L_wide ( L_Gatrell 1987 ) .

For L_instance , L_Diggle L_et al. ( 1990 ) L_assess the L_hypothesis that L_cancer of the L_larynx is L_associated with L_proximity to a L_now-closed L_incinerator and L_develop a L_statistical L_model from the L_theory of L_spatial L_point L_processes to L_test this .

This would have been L_impossible without the L_link L_provided from L_postcoded L_data ( L_increasingly L_available from L_sources such as L_cancer L_registries ) to L_Ordnance L_Survey ( L_OS ) L_grid L_references .
Such a L_link is L_provided by the L_Central L_Postcode L_Directory , which L_matches all 1.5 million L_unit L_postcodes in the L_UK to L_grid L_references .

When the L_cases of L_laryngeal L_cancer are L_compared with a L_null L_distribution ( L_provided by the L_distribution of L_much more L_common L_lung L_cancer ) the L_hypothesis is L_given L_strong L_support .

Although the L_proposed L_method is L_novel , it is but one of an L_increasingly L_large L_number of L_methods L_designed to L_detect and L_model ‘ L_clusters ’ of L_disease ( L_see , for L_example , L_Cuzick and L_Edwards 1990 ) .
The L_work of L_Diggle L_et al. ( 1990 ) L_examined only a L_single L_point L_source , though it L_generalizes to L_multiple L_sources and to L_linear L_hazards as L_well .
As a L_second L_example of L_health L_work L_linked to L_hazard L_studies we may L_cite the L_research being L_conducted by L_Cross ( 1989 ) on L_childhood L_leukaemia .

There are L_numerous L_hypotheses L_concerning the L_aetiology of this L_disease ( from L_ionizing L_radiation to L_viral L_transmission ) and L_Cross 's L_approach is to L_collect L_digital L_data L_designed to L_test some of these L_hypotheses and to L_use ARC/INFO to L_display and L_analyse L_results .
For L_instance , one L_hypothesis L_concerns the L_role of L_electromagnetic L_radiation , a L_source of which is L_overhead L_high-voltage L_transmission L_lines as L_noted L_earlier .

If these are L_digitized and L_buffer L_zones L_constructed around them ( Fig. 10.3 ) we can L_quite L_easily L_test L_hypotheses about L_prevalence in such L_buffer L_zones as L_compared with L_prevalence L_outside .

L_However , we should L_bear in L_mind the L_earlier L_point about the L_resolution of the L_data , since such L_electromagnetic L_effects have a very L_weak L_effect beyond L_perhaps 50 m ( L_Wertheimer and L_Leeper 1982 ) .

There has been a L_suspicion for L_many L_years that L_high L_rates of L_stomach L_cancer in L_parts of L_Wales may be L_linked to L_soil L_chemistry , L_specifically such L_factors as zinc/copper L_ratios , and to L_lead L_content in L_water L_supplies .
L_Matthews ( 1989 ) has L_used L_data from the L_Regional L_Cancer L_Registry ( L_morbidity L_rather than L_mortality L_data ) and L_data on L_trace L_elements to L_examine this L_link .
Since the L_latter are L_available for a 5 L_km L_raster the L_registration L_data are L_assigned to these L_grid L_squares L_using the L_OS L_grid L_reference .

As with any such L_study there are the L_usual L_problems of L_ecological L_analysis and L_influences of L_migration , L_together with L_issues of L_separating out the L_risk L_factors under L_investigation from L_possible L_confounding L_factors .

In the L_USA , L_Morrill 's L_report on the L_beginnings of a $15m. L_study into the L_possible L_radiation L_doses L_received as L_result of L_radiation L_releases by the L_Hanford ( L_Washington L_State ) L_nuclear L_complex would L_seem to L_cry out for L_GIS L_skills to be L_applied ( L_Morrill 1989 ) .

The L_research L_project will L_employ L_plume L_dispersion L_models in L_order to L_model L_dispersal by L_wind and will L_need to L_integrate this and other L_environmental L_data with L_detailed L_demographic L_records .

To some L_extent this L_line of L_approach was L_anticipated by L_Johnson ( 1981 ) in his L_study of L_exposure to L_plutonium L_fall-out from the L_Rocky L_Flats L_nuclear L_weapons L_plant near L_Denver ( L_see L_Zeigler et al. 1983 : 47–8 ) .
L_Using L_soil L_samples he L_constructed a L_contoured L_risk L_surface and then L_mapped L_excess L_cancers in L_various L_distance L_bands , L_detecting a L_marked L_distance L_decay L_effect .
L_Research L_problems and L_prospects

The L_work L_reviewed above L_suggests that the L_application of L_GIS L_techniques to L_hazard L_assessment , L_emergency L_planning and L_environmental L_monitoring is both L_actually and L_potentially an L_important L_research L_area with L_many L_challenging L_problems .
L_Undoubtedly , the L_GISs of the 1990s will L_look very L_different from their L_rather L_primitive L_ancestors .
L_Computer L_power is L_becoming L_cheaper , L_digital L_data more L_readily L_available , and L_GISs are L_becoming L_hybrid L_systems L_involving other L_technologies .
In this L_last L_section we L_highlight some L_important L_research L_areas as we L_see them .
L_Doubtless there are L_many L_others , such is the L_surge of L_interest in L_GIS L_technology .
L_Data L_availability

We should L_first M_consider the L_availability and L_quality of L_data L_concerning the L_populations who may be at L_risk from the L_storage and L_transport of L_hazardous L_substances , from L_toxic L_air L_pollution , from L_flooding and so on .

Such L_data are L_crucial , either for L_assisting the L_emergency L_services to M_make M_assessments about M_resources they L_need to M_deploy in such L_events , or for M_high-quality L_estimates to be M_made of L_risk .
Within the L_public M_domain in the L_UK we must L_rely in L_general on L_data from the most L_recent L_Population L_Census , the M_lowest M_level being that for L_enumeration L_districts ( L_EDs ) .
As is L_well L_known ( L_Rhind 1983 ) these L_contain on L_average L_perhaps 150–200 L_households and 400–500 L_people .
The M_boundaries L_EDs have not been L_widely L_digitized , unlike the M_higher-level L_electoral L_wards .
L_However , the L_centroids of L_EDs are L_available as 100 m M_grid L_references and L_artificial L_ED ‘ L_polygons ’ can be L_created if L_necessary .
In some L_instances such L_data will L_suffice ; in L_many L_cases they will have to L_suffice as L_nothing L_better is L_available .
But in some L_areas L_EDs are very L_extensive L_physical L_units and the L_shapes will be L_quite L_distorted .
L_Furthermore , the M_scales at which L_population L_estimates are L_often L_required L_means that L_even L_EDs are too M_coarse for L_risk M_assessments .

For L_instance , in L_performing its L_quantitative L_risk M_assessments the L_Health and L_Safety L_Executive will L_rarely M_deal with L_distances from L_hazardous L_sites in L_excess of 1 L_km ( L_Petts 1988 ) and L_census L_data will not M_offer L_sufficient M_resolution for M_accurate L_population L_estimates to be M_made .

It should be M_pointed out , L_however , that the L_National L_Radiological L_Protection L_Board L_currently M_uses 1 L_km M_grid L_square L_resolution L_population L_data from the 1971 L_Census in its L_radiological L_protection L_studies ( L_Hallam L_et al. 1981 ) .

It would L_seem that , despite the L_costs L_involved , they should M_consider L_investing in the very L_detailed L_digital L_data ( L_Pinpoint L_Address L_Code ( L_PAC ) ) L_provided by L_Pinpoint L_Analysis L_Ltd .
This M_area of M_application would L_appear to be an L_obvious M_market for such a L_product .
A L_useful L_research M_exercise would be to L_compare the L_use of L_census and L_PAC L_data in M_deriving L_quantitative L_risk M_assessments and this is an L_interesting L_research L_problem .
L_Even with L_PAC L_data some M_assumptions would L_need to be M_made about L_numbers of L_persons per L_household if L_good L_population L_estimates were to be M_made .
More L_generally , we L_need to M_consider the L_availability of M_large L_databases for L_hazard L_studies and L_emergency M_planning and this is an M_area M_ripe for L_major L_initiatives .

In the L_UK we L_seem to be M_lagging L_well behind the L_USA in the M_construction of L_databases on L_hazardous L_sites and L_especially L_hazard L_events such as those L_involving L_toxic M_releases .

For L_instance , L_Lioy and L_Daisey ( 1987 ) , in their L_work on the L_monitoring of L_toxic L_air L_pollution in L_New L_Jersey , M_construct what they L_term a ‘ M_microinventory ’ for each of three L_towns , L_comprising the L_locations of L_chemical M_plants , L_metal L_processing M_plants , L_paint L_spray L_manufacturers and so on .
Some L_attribute L_information is L_available for these .

More M_closely M_linked to L_GIS is L_work by L_McMaster and L_Johnson ( 1986 ) who L_perform a very L_detailed M_inventory of L_hazardous L_materials ( both L_stored and L_transported ) in L_Santa L_Monica , L_California .

Although the L_raster M_displays are very M_crude it is L_simple to L_answer L_spatial L_queries L_concerning the L_locations of L_people ( for L_instance , L_particular L_age L_groups ) within L_certain L_distances of L_toxic L_hazard L_sites .

We have L_data on some L_hazardous L_sites ( e.g. those M_regulated by L_CIMAH ) in the L_UK but a L_much more L_comprehensive M_approach should be M_adopted , L_especially if we are L_serious in the M_search for L_environmental M_associations with L_chronic L_diseases .
The same is L_true for L_toxic M_releases .

In the L_USA the L_Environmental L_Protection L_Agency M_produces an L_Acute L_Hazards L_Events L_Database while the L_Department of L_Transportation has a L_database M_recording L_details of 25 000 M_releases of L_toxic L_materials ; such L_details M_include L_locational L_information , L_type and L_amount of L_material M_released , L_mode of M_release and L_resulting L_injuries or L_deaths ( L_Cutter and L_Solecki 1989 ) .

Can we not L_use L_GIS L_technology to M_construct ‘ L_risk M_mosaics ’ ( L_Zeigler et al. 1983 ) , at a L_variety of L_spatial M_scales , L_akin to L_Hewitt and L_Burton 's ‘ L_hazardousness ’ of a L_place ?

In the L_UK only a M_handful of L_county L_emergency M_planning L_departments ( L_Cumbria , for L_instance ) have M_built up M_resource L_databases in L_digital M_form and this L_needs to be L_promoted .

Further M_afield , we L_need to M_recognize that some L_disasters ( most L_obviously L_Chernobyl ) will have L_implications for more than one L_country so that L_environmental L_monitoring should M_take M_place with some L_kind of L_international M_co-ordination .

There will L_also be L_movements of L_hazardous L_cargoes across L_frontiers and there are L_clearly L_problems of L_risk M_assessment and M_planning for L_emergencies at or near L_international L_boundaries , or at L_sea and L_airports .
As L_noted above , the L_work of L_Fedra ( 1989 ) is a L_major M_step in this M_direction , and M_links L_need to be M_forged between L_initiatives in the L_UK and the L_rest of L_Europe .
In L_terms of L_databases on L_hazardous L_wastes , L_attention has L_already been M_drawn to the L_waste L_disposal M_plans M_prepared by L_WRAs .
These M_give L_details of L_present L_site L_locations and some L_indication of L_permitted L_wastes , though L_little or no L_information on M_closed and L_abandoned L_sites .
L_However , for L_details of L_disposal the L_individual L_site L_licences must be M_consulted .
The L_former L_Hazardous L_Waste L_Inspectorate M_operated a M_large L_database on all L_sites , with L_details of L_permitted L_wastes , L_including L_allowable L_quantities .
The L_database was L_created by a L_commercial L_company , L_Aspinwalls L_Ltd .
There are L_numerous L_potentially L_usable L_databases for L_environmental L_epidemiological L_work .

L_OPCS , of L_course , is a L_major L_data M_repository for L_medical L_statistics and their L_various L_Monitor L_Series are of L_use , though only at the M_scale of L_district L_health L_authority and above ( L_see L_Gatrell and L_Lovett 1988 for an L_example ) .
L_Regional L_health L_authorities will from L_time to L_time M_produce L_mortality L_data at L_ward M_level .

L_However , if L_cancers are of L_interest it is more L_appropriate to M_obtain L_data from L_regional L_cancer L_registries ; these L_data are L_morbidity L_rather than L_mortality L_data and are L_therefore more M_valuable .
The L_data are L_postcoded and may have some L_occupational L_details .
For L_example , we have L_received L_data from the L_Regional L_Cancer L_Registry in L_Manchester L_comprising all L_cancers of the L_larynx and L_lung L_notified between 1974 and 1984 .
This M_large L_data M_set , to which M_grid L_references have now been L_added , L_comprises L_information about L_nearly 40 000 L_individuals .

It has now been M_copied into L_INGRES , a L_relational L_database L_management M_system , M_permitting L_queries to be M_made about M_subsets of the L_data ; for L_instance , all L_males between the L_ages of 25 and 64 L_suffering from L_laryngeal L_cancer .
Other L_data M_sources on L_cancers are L_independent L_registries of L_malignancies .
An L_example is that on L_leukaemias , L_managed by the L_Leukaemia L_Research L_Fund M_Centre in L_Leeds ( L_Alexander et al. 1989 ) .

It should be M_noted that there are L_frequently L_major L_discrepancies between the L_regional L_registries and the L_specialist L_registries , L_partly because the L_latter M_receive L_notifications M_directly from L_consultants .
L_Indeed , L_working M_directly with L_consultants L_proves L_invaluable in M_gaining M_access to M_high-quality L_morbidity L_data .
Two other L_potential M_sources of L_data are M_worth M_mentioning .
L_First , L_attention should be M_drawn to the L_new L_directive from the L_Department of L_Health to L_regional and L_district L_health L_authorities to L_review the L_health of the L_population .

This L_means in L_practice that L_district L_medical L_officers are M_charged with L_preparing an L_annual L_report , M_presenting and L_interpreting L_epidemiological L_data , L_identifying L_local L_health L_problems and L_evaluating L_service L_outcomes .
L_Lancaster L_University is L_already M_heavily L_involved in the L_work of L_Preston L_District L_Health L_Authority in this L_area .
L_Second , L_family L_health L_service L_authorities ( L_FHSAs ) , are L_also L_required to M_take on these M_roles , but from the M_viewpoint of L_primary L_health L_care L_services .
